  • рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реН рддреБ рд╣рд┐ рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпреЛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛ рджрд╛рдпрдГ283 рд╕реМрджрд╛рдпрд┐рдХрдВ рд╡рд╛ рди рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдиреЛрддрд┐284 ред рд╡реИрдорд╛рддреНрд░реЗрдпреЛ рджрд╛рд╕реНрдпрддреАрддрд┐ рдЪреЗрдиреН рдирд╛рд╕рддрд┐ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рдиреНрддрд░реЗ рджрджрд╛рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдпрдореН ред рднреНрд░рд╛рддреГрд╢рдмреНрджрд╛ рдПрдХрдкрд┐рддреГрдХрд╛рдиреЗрдХрд╛рддреНрдордорд╛рддреГрдХрд╛рд╢реН285 рдЪ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдкреИрддреГрд╖реНрд╡рд╕реНрд░реЗрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реБ рддреВрдкрдЪрд╛рд░рд╛рджреН рд╡рд░реНрддрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдПрд╡рдореН рдПрдХрд╢рдмреНрджрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреЗрдХрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡рдВ рдирд╛рднреНрдпреБрдкрдЧрддрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░рд╕рдорд╛рдЪрд╛рд░рд╢реН рдЪреЗрддрдГ286 рд╢реНрд░реЗрдпрд╛рдиреН ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╣рд┐ рдкрдареНрдпрддреЗ- “рдпрдЪреН рдЫрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдВ рдкрд┐рддреГрджрд╛рдпреЗрднреНрдпрдГ рджрддреНрд╡рд░реНрдгрдВ рдкреИрддреГрдХрдВ рдЪ рдпрддреН ред рднреНрд░рд╛рддреГрднрд┐рд╕реН рддрджреН рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН” (рдиреНрд╕реНрдореН резрей.рейреи) ред рдп рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рд╡рд╢реНрдпрдВ рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдВ рддрджреН рдЛрдХреНрддрд╛рджреН рдЙрджреНрдзреГрддреНрдп рд╢реЗрд╖рдВ рд╡рд┐рднрдЬреЗрд░рдиреНрдиреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдпрдерд╛ рдЪ рдЛрдгрд╛рдкрд╛рдХрд░рдгрд╛рджрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рд╣реНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ, рддрджреНрд╡рддреН рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рджрд╛рдирдореН, рдЕрд╡рд╢реНрдпрдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред “рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рднреНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рдкреНрд░рд╛рджрд╛рдирд┐рдХрдореН”287 (рдХрд╢реН рей.рел,реирез) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдирд╛рддреНрд░ рднрдЧрд┐рдиреАрд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рднрд╛рддреГрд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рд╡рд╛ рд╢реНрд░реВрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрдд рдЗрдпрдореН рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред
  • рдпрддреН288 рддреБ рдкреГрдердЧреН рдЗрддрд┐ рддрджреН рдПрдХреИрдХрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рд╕рдореВрд╣рднрд╛рдЧрдГ289 рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рднреНрдп рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ ред
  • рдЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ290 рдЕрджрджрддрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рдпрд╛рдиреН рди рддреБ рд╣рдард╛рджреН рджрд╛рдкреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред
  • рдпрдд рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рдкрддрд┐рддрд╛рдГ рд╕реНрдпреБрд░реН рдЕрджрд┐рддреНрд╕рд╡ рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпреЛ рд╣рд┐ рдпрддреНрд░ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреНрдпреН рдЖрдВрд╢реЗ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореА рд╕ “рд╣рд░реЗрддреН” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ, рди рдкреБрдирд░реН “рдЕрдиреЗрдирд╛рд╕реНрдореИ рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпрдерд╛ рдиреЛрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ291 рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд╛ рднреНрд░рд╛рддреНрд░реЗ рджрджреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпрдЪреН рдЪреЛрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рддрддреН рдкреБрдирд░реН292 рдЕрд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдорд┐рднреНрдпрдГ рее реп.резрезрео рее
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The term тАШkany─БтАЩ is, as a rule, used in the sense of the unmarried girlтАЩ, as we find in the case where a son is called тАШk─Бn─лnaтАЩ (which means born of a kany─Б, i.e., of an unmarried woman). In another Smс╣Ыti text, тАШan┼лс╕Нh─БтАЩ (тАШunmarriedтАЩ) is the actual word used. From this it is dear that the share here laid down pertains to the unmarried girl.

тАШOf the mine caste.тАЩтАФEach of the brothers should give to the sister of the same caste as himself the fourth part of his own share. That is to say, in a case where the father has left several unmarried girls, the share allotted to ouch of them should be the fourth part of the portion of the brother belonging to the same caste as himself.

The upshot therefore comes to be this:тАФThree parts of the property shall be taken by the sons and the fourth part by the daughter.

Some people have held the following view:тАФThree parts of the property shall be taken by the sons and the fourth part by the daughter.

Others have held the following view:тАФтАЬTruly a great benefit is derived by the daughter from her father:

If the father is alive they have their marriage performed at tremendous expense, and if he is dead, she obtains a share in the property.тАЭ

But the same may be said of the son also. Further, why should there be such objections against what is distinctly laid down by the words of the text?

If the idea of the objector is that, according to custom, the only benefit to which the girl is entitled is that her marriage should be performed,тАФthen our answer is that the direct assertion of the Smс╣Ыti is infinitely more authoritative than custom. As a matter of fact however, the custom referred to is by no means universal; so that when it is only limited in scope, the right course is to adopt the course laid down in the Smс╣Ыti text.

Some people have held the view thatтАФтАЬall that need be given to the girl is what is necessary for her marriage, and not quite the fourth part as mentioned in the textтАЭ

But to such people we address the following remarks:тАФThere is no restriction upon gifts in connection with marriage, as there is in connection with the sacrificial fee, which is fixed at┬╣ twelve hundred.тАЩ The gift in connection with marriage however is not precisely fixed. For it is said.тАФтАШThe father shall marry the girl, clothed and adorned, and he may also give her a dowry;тАЩ and as ornaments are of various kinds, made of gold, jewels, pearls, corals and such substances, it cannot be definitely ascertained how much wealth is to be given on that account, or what sort of ornament is to be given. So that even for the purpose of precisely defining what shall be given, it is only right to say that the brother shall give the fourth part of bis share. Nor does this militate against either any scriptual injunctions or reason.

This same view is supported by other Smс╣Ыti texts also: тАШThe brothers who have already had their sacramental rites performed, should perform the same for the unmarried girls; and sisters should receive from their brotherтАЩs the fourth part of their shoreтАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya 2. 124); and againтАФтАШUntil marriage has not been performed, she shall received a share; after marriage she shall be maintained by her husband.тАЩ

What this last text means is as follows:тАФWhen the property left for the brother and the sister is small, and the fourth part of the brotherтАЩs share is not sufficient for the sisterтАЩs maintenance,тАФin such a case the sister shall enjoy a share equal to her brotherтАЩs, until her marriage; after which she shall receive the fourth part of the share, even though if be small. And in answer to the question as to how that, would maintain the girl, the answer is that тАШafter marriage she shall be maintained by her husband.тАЩ

The term тАШbrotherтАЩ in the present text has been explained as standing for the uterine brother. But what is the purpose of adding this explanation? As a matter of fact, the term тАШbrotherтАЩ without a prefixed qualification is always directly applied to the uterine brother. And the term тАШseverallyтАЩ in the text is also indicative of the same idea.

But in that case the girl that has no uterine brother would have to go without a share in the property; nor could there be any chance for any dowry being provided for her. It might be argued that her step-brother would provide for her. But in the absence of some other text laying down (such a gift), he may not give it

As a matter of fact however, the term тАШbrotherтАЩ is found to be applied to the sons of the same father and several mothers; and it is only to cousins, maternal and paternal, that the term is applied figuratively. If this view is accepted, it saves us from the contingency of attributing several denotations to the single word тАШbrother.тАЩ

The rule laid down in other Smс╣Ыti-texts also supports the allocation of shares set forth in the present text. We read there as followsтАФ^(тАШ)What remains of the ancestral property, after the fatherтАЩs debts have been paid offтАЩ, shall be divided; other necessary payments also being made out of it, such for instance as the gift to the unmarried girls; Here we do not find the words тАШbrotherтАЩ and^(тАШ)sister,тАЩ which might give rise to the doubt (as to the uterine or other kinds of brother being meant).

As regards the term тАШseverallyтАЩ (in the text),тАФit has been added with a view to guard against the possible interpretation that the fourth part of the share of a single brother should be divided among all the sisters.

It might be argued thatтАФтАЬall that this means is that the brothers would incur sin by not giving out of their shares; and there is nothing to force them to give it.тАЭ Hence it is addedтАФтАШThose not inclined to give would be outcasts.тАЩ A man is spoken of as^(тАШ)takingтАЩ a thing only when he is its owner, and no one speaks of such a thing as^(тАШ)to be given to him;тАЩ hence it is that no one speaks of the brothers giving to a brother (both being owners); and whenever the word^(тАШ)givingтАЩ is used, it is only when the recipient is not the owner of the property concerned.тАФ(118)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШIf there are several brothers find only one sister, the former must deduct from their several shares as much money as will make up the fourth part of one brotherтАЩs shareтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 731), which adds the following notes тАШSvebhyoс╣Г┼Ыebhyaс╕етАЩ means тАШfrom out of the share of one brotherтАЩ; the plural number is used in view of the plurality of daughters;тАФтАШsv─Бt sv─БtтАЩ, the repetition is in reference to daughters of diverse castes;тАФthus the meaning comes to be as follows:тАФWhen a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa has wives of all the four castes, and each of these has daughters, then the daughter born of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa wife is to receive the fourth part of the share accruing to the son of the Brahmaс╣Зa wife; similarly the daughter of the Kс╣гatriya wife is to receive the fourth part of the share of the son of the Kс╣гatriya wife. This however, is not the sisterтАЩs тАШrightful inheritanceтАЩ.

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.124), which adds the following explanation:тАФThe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa-sons should give to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa-daughters the fourth part of the share that accrues to them in accordance with their castes,тАФwhereby 4 parts go to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, etc. (see verse 153 below); it does not mean that each brother should give a fourth part out of his own share; what is meant is that the daughter of a certain caste is to receive the fourth part of what is prescribed as the share of the son of that caste;тАФthe last clause тАШpatit─Бс╕е syuraditsavaс╕етАЩ indicates the obligatory character of the rule. For this same reason it is not right to hold that all that the daughter is to receive is money enough for her marriage. It goes on to add that the explanation provided by Asah─Бya and Medh─Бtitha is the right one. Thus it is decided that after the fatherтАЩs death, the daughter is actually entitled to a share.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 494), which adds the following explanation:тАФIt does not mean that the brother should take out a fourth part of his own share and give it to his sister; what is meant is that the daughter of a certaind (certain?) caste is to receive the fourth part of what is prescribed as the share of the son of that caste; which thus is to be given to her, for the purpose of her marriage. Thus the meaning comes to be that out of the тАШfour sharesтАЩ and the тАШthree sharesтАЩ to which the sons of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa wife and those of the Kс╣гatriya wife respectively are entitled,тАФout of the combined total of theseтАФa тАШfourth partтАЩ shall be given to the daughter; so that while it is the тАШfourth partтАЩ that is to be given, the real purpose of this gift is to enable her marriage to be performed. Such is the view of Viс╣гс╣Зu, the Kalpataru and the Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б; while Hal─Бyadha holds the opinion that no stress is meant to be laid on the тАШfourth partтАЩ, all that is meant is that the daughter is to receive what would be needed for the performance of her marriage. And this is the view that appears to be most proper; for whatever the тАШfourth partтАЩ may be, the performance of the marriage would be necessary in any case.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 345), which supplies the following notes:тАФThe meaning is that the brother belonging to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and other castes should each give to the sisters of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa and other castes, the fourth part of his own share; that is to say, (a) in a case where a man has only one wife, and that of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa caste, and from her he has one son and one daughter,тАФthe son shall divide his fatherтАЩs property into two parts, and having divided one of these two parts into four parts, he shall give one of these four parts to his sister and take the rest for himself;тАФwhen there are two sons and one daughter, the property shall be divided into three parts, and one of these three parts being divided into four parts, one of these four parts is to go to the daughter, and the rest the two sons shall divide between themselves;тАФwhen there is one son and two daughters, the fatherтАЩs property shall be divided into three parts, and one of these three parts being divided into four parts, two of these latter parts shall be given to the two daughters, and the rest shall be taken by the son.тАФ(b) But in a case where the man has left one son of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa wife and one daughter of the Kс╣гatriya wife,тАФthe fatherтАЩs property shall be divided into seven parts (тАШfour sharesтАЩ accruing to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa son and тАШthree sharesтАЩ to the Kс╣гatriya son), if there be one, the тАШthree sharesтАЩ (accruing to the Kс╣гatriya son) shall be divided into four parts, one of these four parts shall be given to the Kс╣гatriya daughter, the rest of the property going to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa son; where there are two Br─Бhmaс╣Зa sons and one Kс╣гatriya daughter the fatherтАЩs property is to be divided into eleven parts (4 shares for each of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa sons and three for the Kс╣гatriya if there be one), and the three parts (accruing to the Kс╣гatriya son) being divided into four parts, one of these four parts shall go to the Kс╣гatriya daughter, and the rest of the property shall be divided between the two Br─Бhmaс╣Зa sons. On the same principle is partition to proceed when there are brothers of different castes or sisters in varying numbers; such is the explanation provided by Medh─Бtithi, and approved by Vij├▒─Бne┼Ыwara also;тАФBh─Бruci on the other hand holds that the тАШfourth shareтАЩ only stands for тАШsuch amount as may be necessary for her marriage,тАЩ and that therefore unmarried girls have no right to the inheritance as such. This same view has been held also by the author of the Candrik─Б,тАФof these two views, people may accept the one that appears to be the most reasonable.

It is quoted in Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 36a);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmani (Calcutta, p. 134), which says that the meaning is that тАШeach daughter should receive the fourth part of what forms the share of a son of the same caste as himself,тАЩ and adds that stress is not meant to be laid upon the тАШfourth part,тАЩ what is meant is that so much should be given to her as would suffice for her marriage;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra, 179b), which says that this does not mean that тАШin the case of either form of partition among the brothers, each brother should give to the sister a fourth part of his shareтАЩ; as, if there were so, if there are several brothers to a single sister, she would have a very large property,тАФor if there were a single brother to many sisters, he would have nothing left for himself;тАФall therefore that is meant is that the brother should give to the sisters just enough to suffice for her marriageтАФso says the Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, the Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi and the rest;тАФthis is not right; as the text is clear on the point that by not giving to the sister the fourth part of his share, the brother incurs a sin which is quite different from that incurred in not providing for her marriage; the right explanation is that which has been provided by Medh─Бtithi and the Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б. (It then proceeds to quote these).

It is quoted by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 114), which says that the root тАШd─БтАЩ used makes it clear that the sisters have no claims over the property.

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бlс╣гar─Б (2. 119), to the effect that of the animals mentioned, if an odd one remains after partition, it is to be given to the qldest brother;тАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 686), to the same effect;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 723), which explains тАШviс╣гamamтАЩ as a number different from (not a multiple of) the number of brothers;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 498), which says that the odd animals are not to be partitioned by being sold and the value divided, they should be taken by the eldest brother;тАФand in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 57).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (18.35).тАФтАШUnmarried daughters shall receive shares proportionate to the sonsтАЩ shares.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.124).тАФтАШThe brothers who have already had their sacramental rites performed shall perform the sacraments for those brothers and sisters whose sacraments have not been performed,тАФafter each of them has given to the sister the fourth part of their share.тАЩ

N─Бrada (13.13).тАФтАШThe rest shall take equal shares; and so shall an unmarried sister.тАЩ

Do. (13.33-34).тАФтАШThose brothers and sisters for whom the sacraments have not been performed by their father, must have them performed by their elder brothers, who shall defray the expenses from the paternal property. Or, if no paternal property is left, the rites shall be performed for those by the brothers previously initiated contributing the required funds from their own portions.тАЩ

Vy─Бsa (Apar─Бrka, p. 731).тАФтАШThose sons and daughters that have not had their sacraments performed by the father shall have them performed by their elder brothers, who have already had their sacraments performed, out of the paternal property.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 494).тАФтАШFor unmarried daughters, the fourth part of the property has been ordained, the other three parts being for the sons.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Do., p. 495).тАФтАШWhen the father’s estate is being divided, the unmarried daughter shall receive out of the estate, provision for her ornaments, marriage and dowry.тАЩ

Artha┼Ы─Бstra (p. 33).тАФтАШAmong the brothers, those that are not settled in life shall receive the expenses of settling, and the unmarried sisters, the expenses for their marriage,тАФfrom those brothers that are already settled in life.тАЩ

Brhaс╣гpati (25.21).тАФтАШShould thore be younger brothers whose initiation has not been performed, they must be initiated by the other brothers; the expenses being defrayed out of the property inherited from the father.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЕрдиреВрдврд╛рдирд╛рдВ рднрдЧрд┐рдиреАрдирд╛рдВ рдирд┐рдпрдореЗрди рджрд╛рдирдореН рдЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ, рд╕рд╛рдиреНрддрд╛рдирд┐рдХрд╛рджрд┐рджрд╛рдирд╡рддреН ред “рдкрддрд┐рддрд╛рдГ рд╕реНрдпреБрд░реН рдЕрджрд┐рддреНрд╕рд╡рдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН ред рдПрддрдЪреН рдЪ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдВрд╢рддреЛ рди рд╕рдореБрджрд╛рдпрддрдГ ред рдЙрджреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рдорд╛рддреНрд░рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдВ рджреЗрдпрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдиреБрдкрд░реЛрдзреЗрди, рди рдЪрддреБрд░реНрднрд╛рдЧреЛ рдпрдерд╛рд╢реНрд░реБрддрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рд╣рд┐ рдмрд╣реБрднреНрд░рд╛рддреГрдХрд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрд▓реНрдкрддреНрд╡рд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдзрдирдВ рдмрд╣реБрддрд░рдореН рдЖрдкрджреНрдпреЗрдд, рджреНрд╡реНрдпреЗрдХрдпреЛрд╢реН рдЪ рднреНрд░рд╛рддреНрд░реЛрд░реН рдмрд╣реНрд╡реАрдирд╛рдВ рднрдЧрд┐рдиреАрдирд╛рдВ рджрд╛рдиреЗ рдирд┐рд░реНрдзрдирддреНрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╕рдЬреНрдпреЗрдд ред рди рдЪреИрддрджреН рдЗрд╖реНрдЯрдореН, “рдзрд░реНрдореНрдпрд╛ рдкреГрдердХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ “рдкреНрд░рджрджреНрдпреБрд░реН рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░рдГ рдкреГрдердХреН” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдкрджреЗ рдкреГрдердЧреНрд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН рднрд┐рдиреНрдирдорд╛рддреГрдХрд╛ рдПрд╡реИрддреЗ рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛рднреНрдпреЛ рднрдЧрд┐рдиреАрднреНрдпрдГ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡рджреН рджрджреНрдпреБрд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рее реп.резрезрео рее

B├╝hler

118 But to the maiden (sisters) the brothers shall severally give (portions) out of their shares, each out of his share one-fourth part; those who refuse to give (it), will become outcasts.

119 рдЕрдЬрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХрдВ рд╕реИрдХрд╢рдлрдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЕрдЬрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХрдВ рд╕реИрдХрд╢рдлрдВ
рди рдЬрд╛рддреБ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдордВ рднрдЬреЗрддреН [рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдардГ - рдЕрдЬрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХрдВ рдЪреИрдХрд╢рдлрдВ] ред
рдЕрдЬрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХрдВ рддреБ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдордВ
рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резрезреп рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

One shall not divide an odd goat, or sheep, or an animal with uncleft hoofs; the odd goat or sheep is declared to belong to the eldest.тАФ(119)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдПрдХрд╢рдлрдореН рдЕрд╢реНрд╡рд╛рд╢реНрд╡рддрд░рдЧрд░реНрджрднрд╛рджрдпрдГ ред рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рд╕рдорд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрдпрд╛ рдпрджреН рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддреБрдореН рдЕрдЬрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХрдВ рди рд╢рдХреНрдпрддреЗ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреН рди рддрджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдВрд╢рдкрд╛рддреЗрди рд╕рдорддрд╛рдВ рдирдпреЗрджреН рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░реАрддрдВ рд╡рд╛ рддрддрд╕реН рддрдиреНрдореВрд▓реНрдпрдВ рджрд╛рдкрдпреЗрддреН ред рдЕрдЬрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдкрд╢реБрджреНрд╡рдиреНрджреНрд╡рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╖реИрдХрд╡рджреНрднрд╛рд╡рдГ293 (рдЪреНреЬреНред рдкрд╛рдгреН реи.рек.резреи) рее реп.резрезреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШAnimal with uncleft hoofs;тАЩтАФsuch as the horse, the mule, the ass etc. When the number of cattle available do not admit of division in equal numbers, then the odd animal should be given to the eldest brother; and its value shall not be made good by giving (to the other brothers) other things, nor shall the animal be sold and its value distributed among the brothers equally.

тАШAj─Бvikam;тАЩтАФthe singular form is justified on the ground of its being a copulative compound standing for animals.тАФ(119)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.119), to the effect that of the animals mentioned, if an odd one remains after partition, it is to be given to the eldest brother;тАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 686), to the same effect;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 723), which explains тАШviс╣гamamтАЩ as a number different from (not a multiple of) the number of brothers;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 498), which says that the odd animals are not to be partitioned by being sold and the value divided, they should be taken by the eldest brother;тАФand in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 57).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Baudh─Бyana (2.3.9).тАФтАШThe additional share of the eldest brother is a cow, a horse, a goat and a sheep, respectively, for the four castes.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЕрдЬрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХрдВ рддреБ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рдпрджрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдЕрдорд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддреБрдореН рдЕрд╢рдХреНрдпрдВ рддрдЬреН рдЬреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рди рддрджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдп рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдВрд╢рдкрд╛рддреЗрди рд╕рдорддрд╛рдВ рдирдпреЗрддреН, рд╡рд┐рд░реАрдп рд╡рд╛ рддрдиреНрдореВрд▓реНрдпрдВ рдЦрдгреНрдбрдпреЗрддреН рее реп.резрезреп рее

B├╝hler

119 Let him never divide (the value of) a single goat or sheep, or a (single beast) with uncloven hoofs; it is prescribed (that) a single goat or sheep (remaining after an equal division, belongs) to the eldest alone.

120 рдпрд╡реАрдпрд╛рдЮреН рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдарднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН ...{Loading}...

рдпрд╡реАрдпрд╛рдЮреН рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдарднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ
рдкреБрддреНрд░рдореН рдЙрддреНрдкрд╛рджрдпреЗрджреН рдпрджрд┐ ред
рд╕рдорд╕реН рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН
рдЗрддрд┐ рдзрд░реНрдореЛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрдГ рее реп.резреиреж рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If the younger brother begets a son on the wife of the elder, the division in that case shall be equal; such is the settled law.тАФ(120)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реНрдп рдирд┐рдпреЛрдЧрдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рдкрд┐рддреГрд╡рддреН рд╕реЛрджрд░реЗ рд╜рддрд┐рджреЗрд╢реЗ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреЗ рддрдиреНрдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╕рдорд╕реН рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рди рдЪреЛрджреНрдзрд╛рд░рдореН, рди рдЪ “рдПрдХрд╛рдзрд┐рдХрдВ рд╣рд░реЗрдЬреН рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реГрд╣рдГ” (рдореНрдзреН реп.резрезрен) рдЗрддрд┐, рдирд╛рдкрд┐ “рдпрддреН рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдПрд╡ рджреЗрдпрдореН” (рдореНрдзреН реп.резрезрел) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕рдордГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдХреЗрди ред рдЙрддреНрдкрд╛рджрдХреЗрди рдкрд┐рддреГрд╡реНрдпрдХреЗрдг рдХрдиреАрдпрд╕рд╛ ред рдЕрдирд┐рдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛рд╕реБрддрд╕реНрдп рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрднрд╛рдЧрд╛рд░реНрд╣рддреИрд╡ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЗрджрдВ рдЪ рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрдВ “рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░рдГ рд╕рдореЗрддреНрдп”294 (рдореНрдзреН реп.резрежрек) рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рднреНрд░рд╛рддреГрд╢рдмреНрджреЗ рднрд╛рддреГрдкреБрддреНрд░реЗрдгрд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕рддрд┐ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░рд┐ рд╕рд╣ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ рее реп.резреиреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This verse precludes the idea that the son of the elder brother begotten by the method of тАШauthorisationтАЩ is entitled to the тАШpreferential shareтАЩ that would have been his fatherтАЩs.

тАШThe division in that case shall equalтАЩтАФThat is, there shall be no тАШpreferential share;тАЩ nor shall the eldest receive тАШone moreтАЩ (as laid down in 117), or the тАШsome trifleтАЩ (laid down in 115).

It shall be equal:тАФequal to whom? To that of his begetterтАФhis younger uncle.

The son horn without тАШauthorisationтАЩ is not entitled to any share,тАФas is going to be declared later on.

This text, is indicative of the rule that when the brother is not alive, the division shall be between the surviving brother and his nephew.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse in quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.136), which says that this refers to cases where the brothers (the one dead and his younger brother who beget the son on bis sister-in-law)were not divided, while verse 146 below pertains to cases where they have been divided;тАФand in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 542), which adds the following explanation:тАФThe undivided elder brother having died without a son, if the younger brother begets, by commission, a son on his widow, then, when there comes about partition between this son and his uncle-progenitor, it will be done in equal shares, and the son shall not obtain any special share by reason of his dead father having been the elder brother.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.120-121)
**

Smс╣Ыti (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara).тАФтАШIn the case of there being several sons of the same mother, but from diverse fathers, their shares shall be determined by the shares that should have been their fathers.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдВрд╢рд╛рдкрд╡рд╛рджрд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рд╜рдпрдореН рдЖрд░рдореНрднрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдкрддреНрдпрддрдпрд╛ рддрджрдВрд╢рд╛рдзрд┐рдХреЛ рднрд╛рдЧреЛ рди рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН, рдЧреБрдгрд╡рддреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдХрдиреАрдпрд╕реЛрддреНрдкрдиреНрдирддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрддреНрд╡рд╛рдЪреН рдЪ ред рдирд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдзрд╛рдВрд╢рдГ, рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ “рд╕рдорд╕реН рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН” ред рдХреЗрди, рдкрд┐рддреГрд╡реНрдпреЗрди рдкрд┐рддреБрдГ рдХрдиреАрдпрд╕реЛрддреНрдкрд╛рджрдХреЗрдиреЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдпрдВ рдЪ рдирд┐рдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛рд╕реБрддрдГ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬреЛ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдГ ред рдЕрдирд┐рдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛рд╕реБрддрд╕реНрдп рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдирдВрд╢рд╛рд░реНрд╣рддреНрд╡рдореН рдПрд╡ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдп рддреБ рдЧреБрдгрд╡рддрдГ рдкрд┐рддреБрд░реН рдЗрд╡ рд╕реЛрджреНрдзрд╛рд░реЛ рдзрдгрд╛рдВрд╢ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЪ рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЧрдореНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резреиреж рее

B├╝hler

120 If a younger brother begets a son on the wife of the elder, the division must then be made equally; this the law is settled.

121 рдЙрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЬрдирдореН рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд╕реНрдп ...{Loading}...

рдЙрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЬрдирдВ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд╕реНрдп
рдзрд░реНрдорддреЛ рдиреЛрдкрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред
рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдВ рдкреНрд░рдЬрдиреЗ
рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рддрдВ рднрдЬреЗрддреН рее реп.резреирез рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The Secondary cannot rightly be (equal to) the primary; because in procreation, the father is the primary, therefore he (the secondary) should be treated accordinc, to the law (stated before).тАФ(121)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЙрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЬрдирдореН рдЕрдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдВ295 рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрд╕реНрдп ред рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рдФрд░рд╕рд╕реНрдп рддреБрд▓реНрдп рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдЕрдзреНрдпрд╛рд╣реГрддреНрдп,296 рддрджреН рдзрд░реНрдорддрдГ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рддреЛ рди рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдФрд░рд╕рдГ рдХрд┐рд▓ рдкрд┐рддреГрд╡рдЬреН рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдВрд╢рдВ рдХреГрддреНрд╕реНрдирдВ рд▓рднрддреЗ ред рдЕрдпрдВ рддреБ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬреЛ рд╜рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдореН, рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рддрдВ рднрдЬреЗрддреН ред рдзрд░реНрдордГ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрдХреНрддрд╛ рднрд╛рдЧрдХрд▓реНрдкрдирд╛ ред

  • рдирдиреБ рдЪрд╛рдпрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардГ рдкреБрддреНрд░реЛ рднрд╡рддрд┐, рдХрд┐рдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдФрд░рд╕рд╡рдиреН рди рд▓рднрддреЗ ред

  • рдЕрдд рдЖрд╣, рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдВ рдкреНрд░рдЬрдиреЗ ред рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдЬрдирдХреЛ рд╜рддреНрд░рд╛рднрд┐рдкреНрд░реЗрддрдГ ред рд╕ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдореН рдЕрдкрддреНрдпреЛрддреНрдкрд╛рджрдиреЗ ред рдЕрдпрдВ рдЪрд╛рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдГ рдХрдиреАрдпрд╕рд╛ рдЬрдирд┐рддрдГ ред рдЙрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЬрдирдВ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рд╕рдордореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рд╛рдзреНрдпрд╛рд╣реГрддреНрдп297 рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЛ рдЧрдореНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджреЛ рд╜рдпрдореН, рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдп рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдВрд╢рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрддреНрд╡рд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдиреЛрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЬрдирд╢рдмреНрджрдпреЛрд░реН рдпрддреН рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЖрд▓рдореНрдмрдирдореН рдЖрд╢реНрд░рд┐рддреНрдп рд╡реНрдпрдЦреНрдпрд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ ред

  • рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рдкрдардиреНрддрд┐ “рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рддрдВ рддреНрдпрдЬреЗрддреН” рдЗрддрд┐ ред

  • рддрджреН рдЕрдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН, рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддреНрд░ рд╕рдорднрд╛рдЧрд╕реНрдпреЛрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрддреНрд╡рд╛рдЪреН рдЪрд╛рд╕реНрдп рди рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрд╛рд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛ рее реп.резреирез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The тАШSecondary тАЩтАФ subsidiary i.e., the тАШkс╣гetrajaтАЩ son;тАФтАШto the primaryтАЩтАФto the legitimate, тАШbody-born,тАЩ тАШaurasaтАЩ son,тАФтАШcannot he equalтАЩтАФthis has got to be supplied,тАФтАШrightly,тАЩ according to law. Hence this cannot be right. That is, it is only the тАШlegitimateтАЩ son of the elder brother who is entitled to the тАШpreferential share,тАЩ which would have been his fatherтАЩs; while the son in question, the тАШkс╣гetrajaтАЩ is only a тАШsecondaryтАЩ son.

тАЬTherefore h e should be treated according to law.тАЭтАФThe rule of partition stated before.

тАЬBut if the son in question also happens to be the eldest, wherefore cannot he obtain exactly what would go to the тАШlegitimateтАЩ son?тАЭ

The reason for this is stated:тАФтАШIn procreation the father is t he primary.тАЩтАФThe term тАШfatherтАЩ here stands for the actual progenitor; he is the principal factor in the act of begetting the son. The тАШkс╣гetrajaтАЩ son, therefore, being begotten by the younger brother, is secondary.

The verse can be explained only by supplying the words тАШis not equal to.тАЩ

This verse is purely declamatory, supplementing the foregoing prohibition of the тАШpreferential share;тАЩ and since it is declamatory, it may be explained, by attributing any meaning to the terms тАШprimaryтАЩ and тАШsecondary.тАЩ

Others read тАШtasm─Бd dharmeс╣Зa tam tyajet.тАЩ (тАШTherefore one should rightly abandon him).тАЩ

But this is not right; since everywhere the тАШkс╣гetrajaтАЩ son has been declared to be entitled to an equal share with the other sons.

Then again, since this passage is purely declamatory, it could not be taken as setting forth an optional alternative (to the тАШequal shareтАЩ laid down in other texts).тАФ(121)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШPradh─БnasyaтАЩ.тАФтАШThe principal, body-born, sonтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШThe father, the husband of the widowтАЩ (Kull┼лka, Nar─Бyaс╣Зa and R─Бghav─Бnanda).

тАЬThe subsidiary son has not the same rights as the principal, his dead father, the husband of his widow-mother; it is this father, the husband of the widow, who is the тАШprincipal etc.,тАЩ (Kull┼лka and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa);тАФтАШthe father is the principal, not the mother, hence even though the mother is the elder sister-in-law, yet the son does not have the same right as his dead fatherтАЩ (Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 542) as supplying a reason for what has been said in 120; it adds the following explanation:тАФтАШupasarjanaтАЩ is subsidiary, i.e., the Kс╣гetraja son,тАФit is not lawful that this son should be treated like the principal, the тАШbody-bornтАЩ, son; because in this case (of niyoga) the father, the progenitor-uncle, is the тАШprincipalтАЩ;тАФsuch is the explanation given by the author of the Prak─Б┼Ыa. Lakс╣гmidhara construes тАШUpasarjanamтАЩ as тАШUpasarjanatvamтАЩ; but that makes no difference in the meaning.тАФтАШDharmeс╣ЗaтАЩ, according to the injunction of the scriptures.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.120-121)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.120].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЕрдпрдВ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрдГ ред рдЙрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЬрдирдореН рдЕрдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдВ рдкрд┐рддреБрдГ рдХрдиреАрдпрд╛рдиреН рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд╛ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрд╕реНрдпреЛрддреНрдкрд╛рджрдпрд┐рддрд╛, рдпрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЕрддрдГ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реНрдп рднреНрд░рд╛рддреБрдГ рд╕рдорд╛рдВрд╢рдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдзрд░реНрдорддрдГ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рддреЛ рдиреЛрдкрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪреЛрдХреНрддрдВ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реНрдпрд╛рдВрд╢рджрд╛рдирдореН ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рд╕рддрд┐ рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдиреЛ рд╜рдкрддреНрдпрдкреНрд░рдЬрдиреЗ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рд╡рдХреНрд╖рддреНрдпреН рдФрд░рд╕рдкреНрд░рд╛рдзрд╛рдиреНрдпрдореН, рди рдЪрд╛рдпрдВ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрдГ рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рдЬрд╛рддрдГ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рджрд░реНрдореЗрдг рддрдВ рднрдЬреЗрддреН- рдзрд░реНрдо рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдореН, “рд╕рдорд╕реН рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрддреН ред рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рджреН “рдЕрд░реНрдзреЗрди рддрдВ рднрдЬреЗрддреН” рдЗрддрд┐ рдкрдардиреНрддрд┐ ред рддрджреН рдЕрдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН, рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛рдШрд╛рддрдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рддреН ред рди рдЪрд╛рддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкреЛ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ, рдЕрд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп ред рдЕрд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рддреНрд╡рдВ рдЪ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрде рд╡реЛрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЬрдирдВ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрдГ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд╕реНрдпреМрд░рд╕рд╕реНрдпреН рд╕рдорд╛рдВрд╢ рдЗрддрд┐ рдПрддрджреН рдзрд░реНрдорддреЛ рдиреЛрдкрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ “рдПрдХ рдПрд╡реМрд░рд╕рдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рдГ рдкрд┐рддреНрд░реНрдпрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд╕реБрдирдГ рдкреНрд░рднреБрдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпрддрд╢реН рдЪ рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдГ рдкреНрд░рдЬрдиреЗ рди рдЪрд╛рдпрдВ рддреЗрди рдЬрд╛рддрдГ, рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рд╕рдорд╛рдВрд╢рддреИрд╡ рдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛ ред рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░ [рд╕рдордВ] рдкрд┐рддреГрджрд╛рдирдВ рддрддрдГ ред рдЕрде рд╡реЛрдкрд╕рд░реНрдЬрдирдВ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрдГ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рд┐рдгрдГ рд╕рдорд╛рдВрд╢рдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдзрд░реНрдорддреЛ рдиреЛрдкрдкрджреНрдпрдд рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН рд╕рдорд╛рдирдореН рее реп.резреирез рее

B├╝hler

121 The representative (the son begotten on the wife) is not invested with the right of the principal (the eldest brother to an additional share); the principal (became) a father on the procreation (of a son by his younger brother); hence one should give a share to the (son begotten on the wife of the elder brother) according to the rule (stated above).

122 рдкреБрддреНрд░рдГ рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдареЛ ...{Loading}...

рдкреБрддреНрд░рдГ рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдареЛ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдпрд╛рдВ
рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдард╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдЪ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдЬрдГ ред
рдХрдердВ рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН
рдЗрддрд┐ рдЪреЗрддреН рд╕рдВрд╢рдпреЛ рднрд╡реЗрддреН рее реп.резреиреи рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛ рдкреНрд░рдердореЛрдврд╛ ред рдкрд╢реНрдЪрд╛рджреН рдКрдврд╛ рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдард╛ ред рддрдпреЛрд░реН рдЬрд╛рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдХрд┐рдВ рдорд╛рддреБрд░реН рдЙрджреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рдХреНрд░рдореЗрдг рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдВ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рдЬрдиреНрдордХреНрд░рдореЗрдг рд╡реЗрддрд┐298 рд╕рдВрд╢рдпрдореН рдЙрдкрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдпреЛрддреНрддрд░рддреНрд░ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгреЗрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ рд╕рдВрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддреБрдореН рее реп.резреиреи рее

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдХрд┐рдВ рдорд╛рддреБрд░реН рдЙрджреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рдХреНрд░рдореЗрдг рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдореН рдЙрддрд╛рдкрддреНрдпрдЬрдиреНрдордХреНрд░рдореЗрдгреЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдВ [рд╕рдВрд╢рдп], рдЕрдпрдВ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдХреНрд░рдореЛ рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резреиреи рее

B├╝hler

122 If there be a doubt, how the division shall be made, in case the younger son is born of the elder wife and the elder son of the younger wife,

123 рдПрдХрдВ рд╡реГрд╖рднрдореН ...{Loading}...

рдПрдХрдВ рд╡реГрд╖рднрдореН рдЙрджреНрдзрд╛рд░рдВ
рд╕рдВрд╣рд░реЗрдд рд╕ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдЬрдГ ред
рддрддреЛ рд╜рдкрд░реЗ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╡реГрд╖рд╛рд╕реН
рддрджреН-рдКрдирд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╕реНрд╡рдорд╛рддреГрддрдГ рее реп.резреирей рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШIn case the younger son is born of the elder wife, and the elder one of the younger wife,тАФhow would the partition be made?тАЩтАФIf such a doubt arises,тАФthe son born of the elder wife shall take one bull as his тАШpreferential share;тАЩ the other bulls, which are not so good, shall belong to those who are junior to him, on account of the position of their mothers.тАФ(122-123)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ рдЬрд╛рддрдГ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдЬрдГ рдХрдиреАрдпрд╛рдиреН рд╡реГрд╖рднрд╕реНрдпреЛрдХреНрддреЛ рднрд╛рдЧрд╡рд╛рдиреН ред рддрддреЛ рд╡реГрд╖рд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рдпреЗ рд╡реГрд╖рднрд╛ рдЕрдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рд╕реН рддреЗ рдмрд╣реВрдирд╛рдореН рдПрдХрд╢рдГ рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рджреЗрдпрд╛рдГ ред рдЕрддрд╢реН рдЪ рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдард┐рдиреЗ рдпрд╕реНрдпреИрддрд╛рд╡рджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрдВ рдпрдЪреН рдЫреНрд░реЗрд╖реНрдареЛ рд╡реГрд╖реЛ рдЧреБрдгрдорд╛рддреНрд░реЗрдгрд╛рдзрд┐рдХреНрдпрдВ рди рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрдпрд╛ рддрджреВрдирд╛рдирд╛рдВ рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдЬрд╛рджреН рдКрдирд╛рдирд╛рдореН ред рдХрд┐рдпрддрд╛рдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрд╣ ред рд╕реНрд╡рдорд╛рддреГрддрдГ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдореБрдЦреНрдпрддреЛрдбрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН299 рддреЗрдирд╛рддреНрд░ рдорд╛рддреГрдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдореН рдЖрд╢реНрд░рд┐рддрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ рди рдЬрдиреНрдорддрдГ рее рео.резреирей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

(verses 9.122-123)

тАШElder wjfeтАЩтАФmarried first:тАФтАШyounger wifeтАЩтАФone who was married later.

As between the sons born of these wives, the question arises whether тАШseniorityтАЩ shall he determined by the order in which their mothers have been married?тАФor, by the order in which they were themselves born? Having raised this question, the author answers it in the next verse;тАФthis method being adopted with a view to making the rule more easily comprehensible.тАФ(122)

тАШP┼лrvajaс╕етАЩтАФhe who is horn of the тАШp┼лrv─Б,тАЩ the elder, wife, though himself younger (in age)тАФis entitled to one excellent hull.

The other bulls that there may be,тАФтАШwhich are not so goodтАЩтАФshall he allotted to the other several brothers, one to each.

Hence the тАШpreferential shareтАЩ laid down for the son born of the eldest wife consists of the best bull;тАФthe superiority of his share consisting only in the quality of the bull, not in the number.

тАШThose who are junior to himтАЩтАФi.e., to the son born of the eldest wife.тАФJunior by what?тАФтАШOn account of the position of their mothersтАЩтАФi.e., according to the order of their marriage. Thus the seniority among the sons is determined by the seniority of their mothers, and not by their own age.тАФ(123)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

**(verses 9.122-123)
**

These verses are quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 473), which adds the following explanation: The question here raised pertains to the case where there are several sons born of several mothers belonging to the same caste as the father; the term тАШp┼лrvajaс╕етАЩ (in verse 123) stands for the younger son born of the senior wife, as is clear from the latter half of the verse; which means that the next best bullocksтАФthose not the very bestтАФshall belong to those brothers who are тАШjuniorтАЩ by reason of the junior position of their mothers; i.e., whose mothers are junior to the mother of the aforesaid

brother;тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 461).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.122-126)
**

Gautama (28.14-17).тАФтАШIf a man has several wives, the additional share of the eldest son is one bull;тАФbut if the eldest son also happen to be born of the first-married wife, his additional share shall consist of fifteen cows and one hull. The oldest son born of a later-married wife shall share the estate equally with his younger brothers born of the senior wife. Or the special shares shall be adjusted in each class of sons, according to their mothers.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (25.15).тАФтАШWhen there are many sons sprung from one father, equal in caste and number, but born of different mothers, a legal division may be effected by adjusting the shares according to the mothers.тАЩ

Devala (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 477).тАФтАШAmong sons belonging to castes other than that of the father, seniority is determined by their moral character; between twins, by actual birth, i.e., that one is senior whose face the father sees first.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ рдЬрд╛рддрдГ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдЬрдГ рдХрдиреАрдпрд╛рдиреН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рди рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдЬрд╛рддрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рд╕рдордЮреНрдЬрд╕рдВ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рддрддреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдЕрдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрда[рд╡реГрд╖рд╛ рдПрдХрд╢рдГ] рддрджреВрдирд╛рдирд╛рдореН ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдКрдирд╛рд╕реН рддрджреВрдирд╛рдГ рди рд╡реНрдпрд╕реНрддрдГ, рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рд╕реНрд╡рдорд╛рддреГрддрдГ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рд╕рддрд┐ рдорд╛рддреГрддреЛ рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдореН рдЕрддреНрд░ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдореН, рди рдЬрдиреНрдорддрдГрее реп.резреирей рее

B├╝hler

123 (Then the son) born of the first wife shall take as his additional share one (most excellent) bull; the next best bulls (shall belong) to those (who are) inferior on account of their mothers.

124 рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реН рддреБ ...{Loading}...

рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реН рддреБ рдЬрд╛рддреЛ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдпрд╛рдВ
рд╣рд░реЗрджреН рд╡реГрд╖рдн-рд╖реЛрдбрд╢рд╛рдГ ред
рддрддрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдорд╛рддреГрддрдГ рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛
рднрдЬреЗрд░рдиреНрдиреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдзрд╛рд░рдгрд╛ рее реп.резреирек рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The elder son born of the younger wife may take (fifteen cows with) a bull as the sixteenth; the others may take shares according to the seniority of their mothers; such is the settled rule.тАФ(124)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЙрджреНрдзрд╛рд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдВ рд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдкрд┐рдХрдореН рдПрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдареЛ рдЬрд╛рддрдГ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрджрд╢ рдЧрд╛ рд╣рд░реЗрддреН ред рд╖реЛрдбрд╢реЛ рд╡реГрд╖рднреЛ рд╡реГрд╖рднрд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд╛рджреН рдЧрд╛рд╡реЛ рд▓рднреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдпрдерд╛рд╕реНрдп рдЧреЛрд░реН рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпреЗ рдирд╛рд░реНрде рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛ рдЧрд╛ рд╣рд░реЗрд░рдиреН рд╕реНрд╡рдорд╛рддреГрддрдГ рдпрдереИрд╡реИрд╖рд╛рдВ рдорд╛рддрд╛ рдЧрд░реАрдпрд╕реА рд╕ рдЧрд░реАрдпрд╕реАрдВ рдпрд╕реНрдп рдХрдиреАрдпрд╕реА рд╕300 рдХрдиреАрдпрд╕реАрдореН рдЖрд╣рд░реЗрддреН ред

  • рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдард┐рдиреЗ рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдпрдореН рдЙрджреНрдзрд╛рд░реЛ рд╜рдзрд┐рдХ рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╕реН рддреБ рд╕реНрдерд┐рдд рдПрд╡ ред рдирд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рдирдбреБрддреНрдкреНрд░рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖рдГ ред рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рдГ рдХрдиреАрдпрд╛рдореНрд╕рдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдорд╛рддреГрддреЛ рд╣рд░реЗрд░рдиреН ред рд╕реНрд╡рдорд╛рддреГрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд┐рдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред

  • рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрджреНрд╡рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрддреНрд╡рд╛рдиреН рди рд╡рд┐рд╡реЗрдХреЗ рдпрддреНрдирдГ ред рдЙрдкрдХреНрд░рдордорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдПрддрддреН рее реп.резреирек рее

рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд╛рдиреНрддрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдпрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This verse puts forward another alternative regarding the тАШpreferential shareтАЩ in the ease of sons spoken of in the preceding verses.

If the elder son is born of the younger wife, he shall take fifteen rows, and a hull as the sixteenth. That the fifteen are meant to be cows is indicated by the mention of the hull;тАФthe hull needs the cow as its companion.

The тАШothersтАЩтАФthe remaining sonsтАФshall take the cowsтАФтАШaccording to the seniority of their mothers;тАЩтАФi.e., he whose mother is senior shall take a better cow than the one that is taken by him whose mother is junior.

Or, the verse may be taken as laying down an additional тАШpreferential shareтАЩ for the son born of the elder wife,тАФin addition to what has been laid down in the preceding verse. In this case, there would be no тАШaтАЩ before the word тАШjyeс╣гс╣нh─Бy─БmтАЩ (which, in the former explanation has been taken as тАШajyeс╣гс╣нh─Бy─БmтАЩ).

It would appear to be necessary to consider what is exactly meant by the expression тАШaccording to the seniority of their mothers.тАЩ But, inasmuch as the two verses (in which the phrase occurs) are purely declamatory, we make no Attempt to find out its exact meaning.

What has been said hitherto is only by way of a preface; the settled conclusion is going to be stated now (in the following verse).тАФ(124)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

Medh─Бtithi reads тАШajyeс╣гс╣нh─Бy─БmтАЩ and remarks that it is another тАШspecial share but it adds that this may be only another special share for the son of the senior wife (the reading in this case being jyeс╣гс╣нh─Бy─Бm)

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 473), which reads тАШJyeс╣гс╣нh─Бy─БmтАЩ and remarks that this lays down another special share for the brother who is тАШelderтАЩ by reason of being born of the senior wife.тАФтАШVс╣Ыс╣гabhaс╣гoс╕Нa┼Ыaс╕етАЩ means тАШcows that have a bull for their sixteenthтАЩ, these cows being the animals that are most cognate to the animal mentioned, тАШbullтАФтАШ┼Ъeс╣г─Бс╕етАЩ, the remaining brothers, by reason of the non-seniority of their mothers, should each take a bull which is not the very best.тАФIt goes on to add that, according to the author of the Pr─Бk─Б┼Ыa, what is here stated by Manu is the opinion of тАШothersтАЩ,тАФhis own view being stated in the next verse, where seniority among brothers is made to rest upon the priority of their birth.тАФHal─Бyudha however explains the three verses (122-124) as follows:тАФWhen the younger brother is born of the senior and the elder from the junior wife, then the former shall have the best bull as his тАШspecial shareтАЩ,тАФof the other bulls, which are not the very best, one each should be given to the other brothers, the quality of each being in accordance with the respective seniority of their mothers,тАФand the remainder is to be divided equally among the brothers (123);тАФbut when the elder brother is born of the senior wife, then we have the rule laid down in 124: the cows тАШwith a bull as their sixteenthтАЩ goes to the eldest brother, and each of the other brothers receives as his тАШspecial shareтАЩ one bull, the quality of which is to be determined by the relative seniority of their mothers.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 461).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.122-126)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verses 9.122-123].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЛрдЬреНрд╡рд░реНрдердГ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ ред рдПрддрджреН рдПрдХреАрдпрдорддрдореН, рдордиреБрд╕реН рддреБ рднрдЧрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдЖрд╣ рее реп.резреирек рее

B├╝hler

124 But the eldest (son, being) born of the eldest wife, shall receive fifteen cows and a bull, the other sons may then take shares according to (the seniority of) their mothers; that is a settled rule.

125 рд╕рджреГрд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрд╖реБ рдЬрд╛рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН ...{Loading}...

рд╕рджреГрд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрд╖реБ рдЬрд╛рддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ
рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рддрдГ ред
рди рдорд╛рддреГрддреЛ рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрддрд┐
рдЬрдиреНрдорддреЛ рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резреирел рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Among sons born of equal wives,тАФif there is no other distinction,тАФthere is no seniority on account of their mothers; seniority is declared to be by birth only.тАФ(125)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╕рджреГрд╢рдГ рд╕рдорд╛рдирдЬрд╛рддреАрдпрдГ301 рее реп.резреирел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШEqualтАЩтАФof the same caste.тАФ(125)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬAs this verse and the following one contradict the rules given in verses 123-124, the commentators try to reconcile them in various ways. Medh─Бtithi thinks that verses 123-124 are an Arthav─Бda, and have no legal force, and R─Бghav─Бnanda inclines to the same opinion.тАФN─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Nandana hold that the seniority according to the motherтАЩs marriage is of importance for the law of inheritance (verses 123-124), but that it has no value with respect to salutations and the like, or to prerogatives at sacrifices (verses 125-126). Kull┼лka, finally relying on Govindar─БjaтАЩs opinion, thinks that the rules leave an option, and that their application depends on the existence of good qualities and the want of such. It is, however, probable that according to the custom of Hindu writers, the two conflicting opinions are placed side by side, and that it is intended that the learned should find their way out of the difficulty as they can.тАЭтАФBuhler.

This verse is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (R─Бjan─лti, p. 36);тАФin Nirс╣Зayasindhu (p. 177);тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 461).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.122-126)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verses 9.122-123].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрдГ-

B├╝hler

125 Between sons born of wives equal (in caste) (and) without (any other) distinction no seniority in right of the mother exists; seniority is declared (to be) according to birth.

126 рдЬрдиреНрдордЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдареЗрди рдЪрд╛рд╣реНрд╡рд╛рдирдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЬрдиреНрдордЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдареЗрди рдЪрд╛рд╣реНрд╡рд╛рдирдВ
рд╕реБрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕реНрдореГрддрдореН ред
рдпрдордпреЛрд╢реН рдЪреИрд╡ рдЧрд░реНрднреЗрд╖реБ
рдЬрдиреНрдорддреЛ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдарддрд╛ рд╕реНрдореГрддрд╛ рее реп.резреирем рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In the Subrahmaс╣Зy─Б text also, the invocation has been declared as to be done by the son who is eldest by birth. Between sons conceived as twins, seniority has been declared to be dependent upon birth.тАФ(126)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджреЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рдЬрдиреНрдордЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдарддрд╛рдореН рдЕрднреНрдпреБрдкрдЧрдордпрддрд┐ ред рд╕реБрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреНрдпрд╛ рдирд╛рдо рдордиреНрддреНрд░реЛ рдЬреНрдпреЛрддрд┐рд╖реНрдЯреЛрдореЗ рдЫрдиреНрджреЛрдЧреИрдГ рдкреНрд░рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ рдЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдпрдирд╛рдп “рд╕реБрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреНрдпреЛ рдЗрдиреНрджреНрд░ рдЖрдЧрдЪреНрдЫ” (рдРрддреНрдмреН рем.рей.рез) рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдГ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧрдмрд╣реБрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН302 рдмрд╣реБрд╡рдЪрдирдореН ред рддрддреНрд░реЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░рдердордкреБрддреНрд░реЗрдг рдкрд┐рддрд░рдВ рд╡реНрдпрдкрджрд┐рд╢реНрдп рд╣реВрдпрддреЗ- “рджреЗрд╡рджрддреНрддрд╕реНрдп рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдпрдЬрддреЗ” ред рдЬрдиреНрдорддреЛ303 рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдВ рдореБрдЦреНрдпрдореН ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН304 рддреБ рдорд╛рддреГрд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд╛рджреН рдЧреМрдгрдореН ред рдпрдордпреЛрд░реН рдЧрд░реНрдн рдПрдХрдХрд╛рд▓рдирд┐рд╖рд┐рдХреНрддрдпреЛрд░реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЬрдиреНрдорддреЛ рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдореН рее реп.резреирем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This is a declamatory text, supporting the view that seniority is to be determined by birth.

The тАШSubrahmaс╣Зy─БтАЩ is the name of a mantraтАФtext recited by the Chandogas at the Jyotiс╣гс╣нoma sacrifice,тАФoccurring in the Aitareya Br─Бhmaс╣Зa (63). The plural number in тАШSubrahmaс╣Зy─БsuтАЩ is due to the multiplicity of verses.

In connection with this mantra, the тАШeldest sonтАЩ addresses the invocation to the fatherтАФтАШDevadattaтАЩs father offers the sacrifice.тАЩ (Where it is the eldest brother who names himself).

Thus it is тАШseniorityтАЩ by birth that is real тАШseniorityтАЩ in the true sense; the тАШseniorityтАЩ based upon the position of the mother is only secondary, figurative.

тАШBetween sons conceiced as twins,тАЩтАФthose that have been simultaneously conceivedтАФseniority is determined by birth.тАФ(126)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

For the тАШSubrahmaс╣Зy─Б versesтАЩ see Aitareya Br─Бhmaс╣Зa 6.3.

According to R─Бghav─Бnanda the meaning of the second half is that since between twins the one born first is the last conceived, the right of primogeniture is given to the son born last. This is the view hinted at by a passage in the Uttaracarita, where Lava says of his brother тАШprasvakrameс╣Зa sa k─лla jy─Бy─Бn.тАЩ (Act IV).

This verse is quoted in V─лramitrodya (R─Бjan─лti, p. 37), which adds the following notesтАФThat mantra is called тАШSubrahmaс╣Зy─БтАЩ which, at the Jyotiс╣гс╣нoma sacrifice, is recited for inviting Indra; in this the тАШeldestтАЩ son is represented as addressing the father; and it is the senior by birth that is regarded as the тАШeldestтАЩ; and in a case where the sacrificer has twin sons, even though the conception of both may have been simultaneous, yet the son that is born first is held to be the тАШeldestтАЩ; this is the made clear by a text of DevalaтАЩs where it is declared that of twins, that child is to be regarded as the тАШelderтАЩ whose face is seen first In the Saс╣Гsk─Бra section we find the other view stated (see below).

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 477), which has the following notesтАФThe тАШSubrahmaс╣Зy─БтАЩ is the mantra recited at the Jyotiс╣гс╣нoma by Chandoyas, when the form employed is тАШso and so, the father of so and so is sacrificingтАЩ; and here it is the elder son that is named; and he is the one that is born first.

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Saс╣Гsk─Бra, p. 161), which adds the following notes:тАФBetween twins seniority is determined by birth in the womb; i.e., that child is тАШelderтАЩ who is the first to be born in the motherтАЩs womb; while the one born, i.e. conceived, later is regarded as junior; and it is not that seniority belongs to the child that comes out of the womb first; this conclusion is based on the fact that the child born later has been conceived earlier and would have been born earlier also, had not its passage outside been obstructed by the second child conceived later; the order of conception being the reverse of that of birth. It is only when both children are born simultaneously that seniority belongs to one whose face the father sees firstтАФIt goes on to add that this view has been held by тАШsome peopleтАЩ and in reality seniority must be determined by the priority of actual birth coming out of the womb.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (pp. 461 & 702);тАФand in Saс╣Гsk─Бraratnam─Бl─Б (p. 828), which has the following notesтАФтАШSubrahmaс╣Зy─БтАЩ is the name of a mantra used, at the Jyotiс╣гс╣нoma sacrifice, for inviting Indra; it is recited along with the name of the sacrificerтАЩs son, and the rule is that it is the name of the eldest son that is pronounced; and it is the eldest by age that is taken; so in partition also; and between twins also, though they are conceived simultaneously, yet one that is born first is regarded as the elder of the two.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.122-126)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verses 9.122-123].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдПрдХрдХрд╛рд▓рдирд┐рд╖рд┐рдХреНрддрдпреЛрд░реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рддреЛрдГ ред рдЕрддреНрд░ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН “рд╕рджреГрд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░реА” рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдореН рдЕрд╕рджреГрд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдВ рдордиреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрджреН рдЕрдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН, рдпреЗрди рд╡рд┐рд╖рдорд╕рдореАрдХрд░рдгрдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреНрдпрдореН ред “рд╕рджреГрд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░реА"рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдЪрд╛рддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рдзреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзреЗрдиреЛрдЪреНрдпрдорд╛рдирдВ рди рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡рд┐рдзреЗрд░реН рдЕрд╕рджреГрд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрд╡рд┐xрдЕрдпрддреНрд╡рдВ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрд┐рддреБрдВ рд╕рдорд░реНрдердореН ред рдпрддрд╢реН рдЪ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐, “рдПрддрджреН рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдВ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрд╕реНрдпреИрдХрдпреЛрдирд┐рд╖реБ, рдмрд╣реНрд╡реАрд╖реБ рдЪреИрдХрдЬрд╛рддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдиреНрдирд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрд╖реБ рдиреЛрдмреЛрдзрдд” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрддрд╢реН рдЪреЗрджреН рдЕрд╕рдордЮреНрдЬрд╕рдВ рдкреМрдирд░реБрдХреНрддреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЖрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резреирем рее

B├╝hler

126 And with respect to the Subrahmanya (texts) also it is recorded that the invocation (of Indra shall be made) by the first-born, of twins likewise, (conceived at one time) in the wombs (of their mothers) the seniority is declared (to depend) on (actual) birth.

127 рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░реЛ рд╜рдиреЗрди ...{Loading}...

рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░реЛ рд╜рдиреЗрди рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдирд╛
рд╕реБрддрд╛рдВ рдХреБрд░реНрд╡реАрдд рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдореН ред
рдпрджреН рдЕрдкрддреНрдпрдВ рднрд╡реЗрджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ
рддрдиреН рдордо рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рдзрд╛рдХрд░рдореН рее реп.резреирен рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

He who has no son may make his daughter an тАШappointed daughterтАЩ in the following manner: [He shall mark the declaration]тАФтАШThe child that may bk born of her shall be the performer of my funeral ritesтАЩ.тАФ(127)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпрджреН рдЕрдкрддреНрдпрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ рдЬрд╛рдпреЗрдд рддрдиреН рдореЗ рдорд╣реНрдпрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рдзрд╛рдХрд░рдореН ред рдФрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рджреЗрд╣рд┐рдХрд╕реНрдп рд╢реНрд░рд╛рджреНрдзрд╛рджрд┐рдкреБрддреНрд░рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердГ рд╕реНрд╡рдзрд╛рд╢рдмреНрджрдГ ред рди рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдпрдореН рдПрд╡реЛрдЪреНрдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпрдГ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ рдЧреМрддрдордГ- “рдкрд┐рддреЛрддреНрд╕реГрдЬреЗрддреН рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдореН рдЕрдирдкрддреНрдпреЛ рд╜рдЧреНрдирд┐рдВ рдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдкрддрд┐рдВ рдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯреНрд╡рд╛рд╕реНрдорджрд░реНрдердореН рдЕрдкрддреНрдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрд╡рд╛рджреНрдп ред рдЕрднрд┐рд╕рдВрдзрд┐рдорд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рддреН305 рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХреЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрдХреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН” (рдЧреНрдзреН реирео.резреотАУрезреп) рдЗрддрд┐ рдордиреНрддреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐рдпреЛрдЧреЗрди306 рд╡рд┐рдирд╛рдкрд┐ рднрд╡рддрд┐ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛ ред рди рддреБ307 рд╕рдВрд╡рд╛рджрд╛рднрд╛рд╡реЗрди ред рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрднрд┐рд╕рдВрдзрд┐рдГ308 рд╣реГрджрдпрд╛рддреНрдХреГрддрдореН, рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ309 рд╕ рддреБ рд╡рдЪрдиреЗрди310 рдпрд╛рд╡рдиреН рди рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрд┐рддрд╕реН рддрд╛рд╡рдЬреН рдЬрд╛рдорд╛рддрд╛ рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрджреНрдпреЗрдд ред рдХреБрд░реНрд╡реАрдд рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдореН рдПрд╖ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛ рд╡реНрдпрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ рее реп.резреирен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШThe child that may be born of this girl shall be the performer of my funeral rites.тАЩ The term тАШsvadh─Б,тАЩ stands for the ┼Ъr─Бddha and the other after-death rites; it is not necessary that this shall be; the exact formula uttered. Says Gautama (28.18)тАФтАШThe father, having no son, shall offer sacrifices to Agni and Praj─Бpati, and shall give away the appointed daughter, stipulating that the child shall be for me.тАЩтАФThe opinion of some people is that the daughter becomes appointed by mere intention, (28.19); from which it is clear that the daughter becomes тАШappointedтАЩ even without the pronouncement of any definite formula.

тАЬIn the absence of a distinct stipulation, even though the intention may be present in the fatherтАЩs mind, yet, until it has been clearly declared, the son-in-law may not agree (to surrender the child).тАЭ

It is in view of this that the text saysтАФтАШShall make his daughter an appointed daughter.тАЩтАФ(127)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (─Аc─Бra, p. 475) as a clear indication that the тАШappointmentтАЩ of the daughter is undisputed in a case where it has been done in accordance with a clear agreement between the father of the bride and the bridegroom;тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra 38a);тАФin Vyvah─Бra-Balambhaс╣нс╣н─л (pp, 651 and 633) and by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 223), to the effect that the appointed daughter offers the Ball to her appointing father through her son.

It is quoted in the Vidh─Бnap─Бr─лj─Бta (p. 699)тАФin the Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 561);тАФin the Smс╣Ыticandrik─Б (Saс╣Гsk─Бra, p. 182), as laying down the mode of appointing the daughter;тАФin the Saс╣Гsk─Бraratnam─Бl─Б (p. 414), to the effect that it clearly implies that there should be an express stipulation with the girlтАЩs husband;тАФin Dattakam─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б (p. 7);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 185a), which says that the son that is born of the Appointed Daughter after stipulation, belongs to the father of the girl; though the opinion has been held that this is so also in cases where there has been no open stipulation to the effect.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.127-129, 9.132-133)
**

(See below, verse 139.)

Gautama (23.18).тАФтАШA father who has no male issue may appoint his daughter, offering oblations to Agni and to Praj─Бpati, and addressing to the bridegroom the wordsтАФтАЬFor me be thy male offering.тАЭ Some people hold that the daughter becomes an Appointed Daughter by the mere intention of her father.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (2.3-15).тАФтАШThe male child born of a daughter after an agreement has been made, is to be known as the son of an appointed daughter, and other male offspring to the daughter they call the daughterтАЩs son.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (17.15-17)тАФтАШThe third is the Appointed Daughter;тАФit is declared in the VedaтАФтАЬA maiden who has no brothers comes back to the male ancestors (of her own family); returning she becomes their son.тАЭ With reference to this matter, there is a verse to be spoken by the father when appointing his daughter,тАФтАЬI shall give thee a brotherless damsel decked with ornaments; the son whom she may hear shall he my son.тАЩтАЭ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (15.4-5).тАФтАШThe third is the son of an Appointed Daughter. She is called an Appointed Daughter, who is given away by her father with the words тАЬthe son whom she bears shall be mine.тАЭ She is called an Appointed Daughter, though she has not been given away according to the rule of an Appointed Daughter.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (25.37-38).тАФтАШBoth a sonтАЩs son and the son of an Appointed Daughter lead a man to heaven. Both are pronounced to he equal as regards their right of inheritance and the duty of offering balls of meal. Gautama has declared that a daughter is appointed after offering oblations to Agni and Praj─Бpati; others have said that she is an Appointed Daughter who was merely intended to ho one by a man having no male issue.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 561).тАФтАШJust as the daughter has rights over her fatherтАЩs property, even in the presence of the relatives, so is her son also the owner of the property of his motherтАЩs father.тАЩ

Brahmapur─Бс╣Зa (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 562).тАФтАШA sonless man appoints his daughter as his son,тАФeither in his own mind, or in the presence of the king, the fire, and his relatives;тАФor she may have been so appointed even before her birth and given to her husband on that express understanding;тАФor she may be so given away even after her fatherтАЩs death. Such an Appointed Daughter obtains an equal share in the property of her father.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 559).тАФтАШThe Appointed Daughter is like the son; her son offers Piс╣Зс╕Нa to his fatherтАЩs father as also to his motherтАЩs father; there is no difference, in the world, between the daughterтАЩs son and the sonтАЩs son, so far as benefit is concerned.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 56, 2-128).тАФтАШThe son of the Appointed Daughter is like the body-born son.тАЩ

Devala (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 562, 2-128).тАФтАШThe son of the Appointed Daughter is equal to the son; he inherits the property of his own father, as also that of his motherтАЩs father, who has no son, as if he were his own son;тАФhe shall offer the ball of meal to his own as well as his motherтАЩs father. Whether appointed or not appointed, whichever son the daughter gives birth to, by that son, does her father also become endowed with son; and he may offer the hall to him and inherit his property.

(Devala also reproduces Manu 133.)

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (13.45-13).тАФ(Same as Manu 132, second-half.)

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдпрдереИрд╡реМрд░рд╕рд╛рднрд╛рд╡реЗ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрд╛рджреНрдпрднрд┐рдзрд╛рдирдВ рджрд╛рдпрд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгреЗ рд╜рдВрд╢рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердВ рддрдереИрд╡ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдореН ред рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдпреИрд╡реИрддрддреН рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдирдореН ред рдЕрдирдпрд╛ рд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рджрд╛ “рдпрджреН рдЕрдкрддреНрдпрдВ рднрд╡реЗрджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ рддрдиреН рдордо рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рдзрд╛рдХрд░рдореН” рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбреЛрджрдХрдкреНрд░рджрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрдГ рдкрд░рдХреГрддрд┐рд░реВрдк рдЙрджрд╛рд╣реНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ рее реп.резреирен рее

B├╝hler

127 He who has no son may make his daughter in the following manner an appointed daughter (putrika, saying to her husband), ‘The (male) child, born of her, shall perform my funeral rites.’

128 рдЕрдиреЗрди рддреБ ...{Loading}...

рдЕрдиреЗрди рддреБ рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛рдиреЗрди

рд╡рд┐рд╡реГрджреНрдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╡рдВрд╢рд╕реНрдп

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In ancient times Dakс╣гa Praj─Бpati himself made тАШappointed daughtersтАЩ in this same manner, for the purpose of multiplying his race.тАФ(128)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкреНрд░рдЬреЛрддреНрдкрд╛рджрдирд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдЬреНрдЮрдГ рдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдкрддрд┐рд░реН рджрдХреНрд╖рдГ рд╕ рдПрд╡реЛрджрд╛рд╣реНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджреЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рдкрд░рдХреГрддрд┐рд░реН рдирд╛рдо рее реп.резреирео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Praj─Бpati Dakс╣гa, who was fully conversant with the law relating to the procreation of offspring, is here cited as an example.

This is a declamatory assertion of the nature of тАШParakс╣Ыti.тАЩ тАШTraditionтАЩ of Practice.тАФ(128)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 654), and in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 185a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдкрддрд┐рд░реН рд╣рд┐ рдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдЬреНрдЮрдГ ред рдпрддрдГ рд╕ рдПрд╡реЛрджрд╛рд╣реГрддрдГ рее реп.резреирео рее

128 According to this rule Daksha, himself, lord of created beings, formerly made (all his female offspring) appointed daughters in order to multiply his race.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

He gave ten to Dharma, thirteen to Ka┼Ыyapa, and twenty-seven to King Soma,тАФhaving honoured them with an affectionate heart.тАФ(129)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╕рддреНрдХреГрддреНрдпреЗрддрд┐ ред рдПрддрджреН311 рдЕрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗ ред рджрд╢реЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреЗрдХрдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдХрд░рдгрдореН рдЕрдкреАрдЪреНрдЫрдиреНрддрд┐ рее реп.резреиреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШHaving honouredтАЩтАФThis act of тАШhonouringтАЩ is what is enjoined here.

People have held that the mention of тАШtenтАЩ and more daughters is indicative of the fact that one may have more than one тАШappointed daughter.тАЩтАФ(129)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 654) and in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 185a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╕рддреНрдХрд╛рд░рд╡рдЪрдирдВ рдЪ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░реНрдердВ рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрдореН рдЕрдкрд░реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдХрд░реНрдордгрд┐ рее реп.резреиреп рее

B├╝hler

129 He gave ten to Dharma, thirteen to Kasyapa, twenty-seven to King Soma, honouring (them) with an affectionate heart.

130 рдпрдереИрд╡рд╛рддреНрдорд╛ рддрдерд╛ ...{Loading}...

рдпрдереИрд╡рд╛рддреНрдорд╛ рддрдерд╛ рдкреБрддреНрд░рдГ
рдкреБрддреНрд░реЗрдг рджреБрд╣рд┐рддрд╛ рд╕рдорд╛ ред
рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЖрддреНрдордирд┐ рддрд┐рд╖реНрдардиреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдВ
рдХрдердореН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛ рдзрдирдВ рд╣рд░реЗрддреН рее реп.резрейреж рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The son is as oneтАЩs own self, and the daughter is equal to the son; hence so long as she is there in her own real character, how can anyone else take his property?тАФ(130)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

“рдпрджреН рдЕрдкрддреНрдпрдВ рднрд╡реЗрджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ рддрдиреН рдордо рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН” (рдореНрдзреН реп.резреирен) рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдЕрдкрддреНрдпрдВ рдЪ рдЛрдХреНрдерднрд╛рдХреН ред рдЕрддрдГ рдкрд┐рддрд░рд┐ рдореГрддреЗ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдпрд╛ рдЕрдиреБрддреНрдкрдиреНрдирдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╛ рдзрдирд╣рд░рддреНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрдВ рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗ рд╜рд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджреЗрди ред рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЖрддреНрдордирд┐ рдкреБрддреНрд░рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрдВ рддрд┐рд╖реНрдардиреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдореН рдПрд╡ рдзрдирдореН, рди рдкреБрддреНрд░реЛрддреНрдкрддреНрддрд┐рд╕реН рддрджреАрдпрд╛рддреНрд░312 рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрддреНрдорднреВрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдкрд┐рддреГрд░реВрдкрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдкреБрддреНрд░реЗрдг рджреБрд╣рд┐рддрд╛ рд╕рдореЗрддрд┐ рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдпрд╡рдЪрдиреЛ рджреБрд╣рд┐рддреГрд╢рдмреНрджрдГ рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрд╛рддреН рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдГ рее реп.резрейреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been said that the father shall declareтАФтАШThe child that is born of her shall be mine;тАЩ and a manтАЩ? child inherits his property; so that at the time that the father dies, if the daughter has got no child, it would seem that she cannot inherit his property; it is in view of this that the present text lays down that she shall inherit it

тАШSo long as she is there in her own real characterтАЩтАФof being meant to provide a son.

Or, it. may meanтАФтАШwhile the fatherтАЩs own self is there, in the shape of the daughter.тАЩ

тАШThe daughter is equal to the son.тАЩтАФThough the text uses the generic term тАШdaughter,тАЩ yet from the context it is clear that it is the тАШappointed daughterтАЩ that is clearly meant.тАФ(130)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 591);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Calcutta, p. 152), to the effect that like the son, the daughter also serves the purpose of propagating the fatherтАЩs race;тАФin H─Бralat─Б (p. 179);тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (pp. 663 and 691);тАФin V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 203a);тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 270).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (13.45-11).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

Baudh─Бyana (2.3-14).тАФтАШOne must know a son begotten by the husband himself on a wedded wife of equal caste to be a legitimate son of the body. They quote the following: тАЬFrom the several limbs of my body art thou produced, from my heart art thou born; thou art my very self called a son; mayst thou live a hundred years.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдкрд┐рддрд░рд┐ рдкреНрд░реЗрддреЗ рд╕рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛ рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛ рд╡рд╛ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛ рдзрдирдВ рд╣рд░реЗрддреН рддрджреАрдпрдореН рее реп.резрейреж рее

B├╝hler

130 A son is even (as) oneself, (such) a daughter is equal to a son; how can another (heir) take the estate, while such (an appointed daughter who is even) oneself, lives?

131 рдорд╛рддреБрд╕реН рддреБ ...{Loading}...

рдорд╛рддреБрд╕реН рддреБ рдпреМрддрдХрдВ рдпрддреН рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН
рдХреБрдорд╛рд░реАрднрд╛рдЧ рдПрд╡ рд╕рдГ ред
рджреМрд╣рд┐рддреНрд░ рдПрд╡ рдЪ рд╣рд░реЗрджреН
рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╜рдЦрд┐рд▓рдВ рдзрдирдореН рее реп.резрейрез рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Whatever may be the separate property of the mother is the share of the unmarried daughter alone; and the daughterтАЩs son shall inherit the entire property of the man who has no son.тАФ(131)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпреМрддрдХрд╢рдмреНрджрдГ рдкреГрдердЧреНрднрд╛рд╡реЗрди рдЪ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдзрдиреЗ ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╣рд┐ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛ рдПрд╡ рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рд╛рдпрд╛рдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпрдореН ред

  • рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рд╕реМрджрд╛рдпрд┐рдХрдореН313 рдПрд╡ рди314 рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдзрдирдореН ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╣рд┐ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рддрдиреНрддреНрд░реНрдпрдореН- “рд╕реМрджрд╛рдпрд┐рдХрдВ рдзрдирдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдп рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдгрд╛рдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рддрдиреНрддреНрд░реНрдпрдореН рдЗрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ " (рдХреНрд╕реНрдореН репрежрел) ред
  • рдЗрддрд░реЗ рддреБ315 рднрдХреНрддрднреВрд╖рд╛рджреНрдпреБрдкрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рдирдГ рдЖрдиреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рд┐рдХрд╛рджреН рднрд░реНрддреГрджрддреНрддрд╛рджреН рдзрдирд╛рджреН рдЙрдкрдпреБрдХреНрддрд╢реЗрд╖рдореН рдПрд╡ ред
  • рдпреБрд╡рддреНрдпрд╛ рд╕реНрд╡реАрдХреГрддрдВ рдпреМрддрдХрдореН рдЖрд╣реБрдГ ред рдХреБрдорд╛рд░реАрднрд╛рдЧ рдПрд╡316 ред рдХреБрдорд╛рд░реАрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рджреН рдпрд╛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рдХреБрдорд╛рд░реА рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐317 ред рдПрд╡рдХрд╛рд░рд╕реНрдп рдЪ рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдХрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрдмрд╛рдзрдХрддреНрд╡рдореН ред рдЕрддрд╢реН рдЪ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдХреБрдорд╛рд░реАрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдореН318 рдЕрдкрд┐ рдпреМрддрдХрдореН ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рдЧреМрддрдордГ- “рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдзрдирдВ рддрджрдкрддреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдореН” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддреНрд╡рд╛рд╣ “рджреБрд╣рд┐рддреДрдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрд░рддреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪ” (рдЧреНрдзреН реирео.реирек) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рддрд╛ рдпрд╛ рдКрдврд╛ рдЕрдирдкрддреНрдпрд╛ рдирд┐рд░реНрдзрд╛рдирд╛ рднрд░реНрддреГрдШреЗ рдпрд╛рднрд┐рдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реНрдард╛ рди рд▓рдмреНрдзрд╛ ред
  • рджреМрд╣рд┐рддреНрд░ рдПрд╡ рдЪ рд╣рд░реЗрджреН рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреМрд░рд╕рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдпреНрдЖрдЦрд┐рд▓рдВ рдзрдирдВ рд╣рд░реЗрддреН ред рд╕рддрд┐ рддреНрд╡реН рдФрд░рд╕реЗ рдпрд╛рд╡рд╛рдиреН рдЕрдВрд╢рд╕реН рддрдВ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдЕрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдкреБрддреНрд░ рдПрд╡ рджреМрд╣рд┐рддреНрд░реЛ рди рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддреНрд░, рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╡рддреН рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрд╕реНрдп рдпреМрддрдХрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрддреНрд╡ рдПрд╡ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╕рдВрднрд╡рд╛рддреН рее реп.резрейрез рее
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The term тАШyautakaтАЩ is applied to the separate property of a woman; of which she alone is the sole owner.тАФOthers apply it to only what she receives at marriage, and not to all that belongs to her; it is only over the former that she has an absolute right; as it is said that тАШwomen become their own mistresses, on obtaining presents at their marriage.тАЩ

Others again hold that the term тАШyautakaтАЩ applies to the savings that the young woman makes out of what she receives from her husband for her clothing and ornaments, and also for the daily household expenses.

тАШIs the share of the unmarried daughter only.тАЩтАФSince the text adds the qualification тАШunmarried,тАЩ it is clear that what is said here does not apply to one who has been married. Further, the term тАШeva,тАЩ тАШonly,тАЩ referring to what is well known, sets aside the implications of the context; consequently, what is said here (regarding the motherтАЩs property) cannot apply to the тАШappointed daughterтАЩ (who would be married).
