This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 582);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (p. 300) as attributing the character of the regular тАШsonтАЩ to the son of the co-wife;тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva II (p. 187);тАФagain on p. 388, where тАШekapatn─лn─БmтАЩ is expounded as тАШekaс╕е patiс╕е y─Бs─БmтАЩ;тАФin Hem─Бdri (┼Ъr─Бddha, p. 97);тАФin ┼Ъr─Бddhakriy─Бkaumud─л (p. 459 and 465), to the effect that a womanтАЩs property is inherited (1) by her son, (2) by her grandson, (3) by her great-grandson, (4) by her daughter and (5) by her step-son; and also as entitling the step-son to do the тАШsapiс╣Зс╕Нana,тАЩ тАШamalgamating,тАЩ ┼Ъr─Бddha for his step-mother;тАФin Kс╣Ыtyas─Бrasamuccaya (p. 76), to the effect that the step-son is as good as a son;тАФin Dattakam─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б (p. 14), to the effect that the step-son is a тАШsonтАЩ, even without being тАШappointedтАЩ, because he is constituted by the elements of her own husbandтАЩs body;тАФin Dattakacandrik─Б (p. 50);тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 200), to the effect that if a woman has no son of her own, her afterdeath rites are to be performed by her step-son;тАФin ┼Ъuddhikaumud─л (p. 103);тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 668).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (17, 11).тАФтАШIf among many wives of one husband, one have a son, they all become with son, through that son;тАФthus says the Veda.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (15.41).тАФтАШAmongst wives of one husband also, the son of one is the son of all.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (25.100).тАФтАШThe same rule applies to a plurality of wives; if one of them has male issue, that son shall offer the Ball of meal to them all.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЗрдпрдВ рди рдирд┐рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпреЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЧрдореНрдпрддреЗ ред рди рдЪреИрддрдпреИрдХрд╛рдХрд┐рдиреНрдпрд╛ рджрддреНрддрдХрд╛рджрд┐рдкреБрддреНрд░рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдореН рее реп.резреорей рее

B├╝hler

183 If among all the wives of one husband one have a son, Manu declares them all (to be) mothers of male children through that son.

184 рд╢реНрд░реЗрдпрд╕рдГ рд╢реНрд░реЗрдпрд╕реЛ ...{Loading}...

рд╢реНрд░реЗрдпрд╕рдГ рд╢реНрд░реЗрдпрд╕реЛ рд╜рд▓рд╛рднреЗ
рдкрд╛рдкреАрдпрд╛рдиреН рд░рд┐рдХреНрдердореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ ред
рдмрд╣рд╡рд╢реН рдЪреЗрддреН рддреБ рд╕рджреГрд╢рд╛рдГ
рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗ рд░рд┐рдХреНрдерд╕реНрдп рднрд╛рдЧрд┐рдирдГ рее реп.резреорек рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

On the failure of each superior kind of son, each next inferior one is entitled to inheritance; if there be several of the same class, all shall share the property.тАФ(184)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬKull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda add that, as the son of ┼Ъ┼лdra wife is enumerated among the twelve, and not considered, like the son of Kс╣гatriya and Vai┼Ыya wives, a legitimate son, he inherits only on failure of all other subsidiary sons.тАЭтАФBuhler.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 552), which explains тАШSadс╣Ы┼Ы─Бс╕етАЩ as тАШequal in qualificationsтАЩ;тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (pp. 555, 691 and 698);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 192a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (17.39, 81).тАФтАШThey quote the rule that the last mentioned six sons shall inherit the property of him who has no son mentioned among the first-mentioned six classes. Let the Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas or the subsidiary sons divide the heritage of him who has no son of the first-mentioned six kinds.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (15.28-29).тАФтАШAmong these sons, each preceding one is preferable to the one next in order;тАФand he takes the inheritance before the next in order.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.132).тАФтАШAmong the sons, the succeeding one is entitled to offer the Ball and inherit the property only in the absence of the preceding one.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 552).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

Bс╣Ыhaspati (25.39-41).тАФтАШThe other sons, beginning with the Kс╣гetraja, shall respectively take a fifth, a sixth and a seventh part. The adopted, the cast off, the bought, the appointed and the son by a ┼Ъ┼лdra wife;тАФthese, when pure by caste, and irreproachable in their conduct, are considered as sons of middle rank. The Kс╣гetraja is despised by the virtuous; and so are the son born of the re-married woman, the son of an unmarried damsel, the son received with the pregnant bride and the son secretly born.тАЩ

H─Бr─лta (25.39-41).тАФтАШSons of the ┼Ъ┼лdra wife, sons self-given and sons bought are all as had as the ┼Ъ┼лdra-born.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рд░рд┐рдХреНрдерд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдП рдмреАрдЬрднреВрддреЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд░реЛрдзреЗрди рд░рд┐рдХреНрдерд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧреЗ рд╜рдирд╛рдЧрддреЛ рд╜рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд╢реН рдЪ рд╡рд░реНрдгрдиреАрдпрдГ рее реп.резреорек рее

B├╝hler

184 On failure of each better (son), each next inferior (one) is worthy of the inheritance; but if there be many (of) equal (rank), they shall all share the estate.

185 рди рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░реЛ ...{Loading}...

рди рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░реЛ рди рдкрд┐рддрд░рдГ
рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛ рд░рд┐рдХреНрдерд╣рд░рд╛рдГ рдкрд┐рддреБрдГ ред
рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рд╣рд░реЗрджреН рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдп
рд░рд┐рдХреНрдердВ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░ рдПрд╡ рдЪ рее реп.резреорел рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Sons alone shall inherit the fatherтАЩs property, not brothers or fathers; but the father and brothers shall inherit the property of one who dies sonless.тАФ(185)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬKull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda insert, after тАШwho leave no son,тАЩ тАШnor widow and daughtersтАЩ, and before тАШbrothersтАЩ, тАШwho leaves no parents.тАЩ N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa, who (as also Govindar─Бja and Nandana) reads тАШeva v─БтАЩ, тАШor brothersтАЩ, says that the father inherits the estate of an undivided son leaving no male issue, or the brothers with his permission, and that the estate of a divided son descends to his wife and other heirs mentioned in Y─Бj├▒avalkya II, 135-136.тАЭтАФBuhler.

The first half of this verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.132) to the effect that all sons, тАШbody-bornтАЩ as well as others, are entitled to inherit the fatherтАЩs property. The B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л quotes verse 184 and notes that тАШsonтАЩ cannot be taken as standing for the body-bom sons only; because the rights of the body-born born have been declared in another verse already.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 653);тАФand in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 552), which quotes the first half only;тАФit quotes the second half on p. 592, where тАШaputrasyaтАЩ is explained as тАШwithout sons, primary as well as secondary.тАЩ

The second half is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.136), as laying down that the property of a sonless man goes to his Father or Brother;тАФagain as justifying the conclusion that, if the man leaves a large property, his wife is to receive enough for her maintenance and the remainder is to go to his brother;тАФagain, where the view is expressed that all that is meant is that both the Father and the Brother are entitled to inherit; and no priority or preference is meant to be implied by the order in which the two are mentioned;тАФon this the B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л notes that this view is supported by the use of the particle тАШv─БтАЩ;тАФagain, where it is explained as meaning that brothers inherit only in the absence of the father.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 650 and 651);тАФin Dattakacandrik─Б (p. 61);тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana D─Бyabh─Бga, (p. 253 and 293), to the effect that it is this brother that inherits, not the brotherтАЩs son.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (17.4-8).тАФтАШThe wealth of a man who dies without male issue goes to his wife; failing her, to his daughter; failing her to his father; failing him, to his mother; failing her, to his brother; failing him, to his brotherтАЩs sons; failing them, to his kinsmen; failing them, to Sakulyas; failing them, to fellow-students; failing them to the King, except in the case of the property being a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.135-136).тАФтАШWife, daughters, parents, brothers, brotherтАЩs sons, Sagotras, kinsmen, pupils, fellow-students; among these the succeeding inherits the property of a man dying without male issue, only in the absence of the preceding one. Such is the law for all castes.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (─Аpar─Бrka, pp. 740, 742, 745).тАФтАШThe wife being one half of the manтАЩs body, the man whose wife is alive is himself still alive; and while one half of his body is alive, how can any one else take his property? Hence in the case of a man dying without male issue, even though his father, brothers and Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas may be living, it is his wife who inherits his property. If the man dies without leaving a male issue or a wife, or brother or father or mother, his property shall be divided by his Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas in proportionate shares. If the man leaves no son, his ┼Ъr─Бddha shall he performed by his wife; and in the absence of the wife, by his uterine brother;тАФfailing him, other brothers, or brothersтАЩ sons, or Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas, or Sakulyas, or pupils, or Vedic scholars are entitled to his wealth.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha (Apar─Бrka, p. 741).тАФтАШIf a man dies without male issue, his property goes to his brother; failing him, to his mother and father; or to his senior (or junior) wife.тАЩ

Devala (Do.).тАФтАШThe property of the son-less man shall go to his uterine brothers, or to his daughters of the same caste as himself, or to his father if he he living, or to brothers of the same caste as himself, or to his mother, or to his wife;тАФin this same order.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Do.)тАФтАШIf among brothers, some one should die, or go away as a Renunciate, the other brothers shall divide his property among themselves, except the Str─лdhana; they shall support his wives as long as they continue to be faithful to their husband.тАЩ

Gautama (Do., 742).тАФтАШThe wife should obtain the property of one who dies childless.тАЩ

Vс╣Ыddha-manu (Do.).тАФтАШA widow, without a son, keeping pure the husbandтАЩs bed, and firm in the observance of her duties, shall offer the Hall of meal to him and take his entire property.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Do., p. 745).тАФтАШIf a man dies after partition, without leaving a male issue, his father should take his property, or his brother, or mother, or his fatherтАЩs mother, in due order.тАЩ

P─Бiс╣нh─лnasi (Vivadaratn─Бkara, p. 592).тАФтАШThe property of a son-less man goes to his brother; failing him to his mother and father, or his eldest wife, or Sagotras, or pupils, or fellow-students.тАЩ

─Аpastamba (Do., p. 596).тАФтАШIn the absence of sons, the nearest Sapiс╣Зс╕Нa; failing him, the preceptor; failing him, the pupil.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдп рдПрддреЗ рдФрд░рд╕рд╛рджрдпрдГрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд╛рд╕реН рдд рдПрд╡ рд░рд┐рдХреНрдерд╣рд░рд╛рдГ рд╕реНрдпреБрдГ ред рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрд╛рджрдпреЛ рд╜рдкреНрдпреН рдФрд░рд╕рд╛рд╕рдВрднрд╡реЗ ред рдХреБрдд рдПрддрддреН ред рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдХреГрд╖реНрдЯрддрд░рддреНрд╡реЗ рдкрд┐рддреБрд░реН рднреНрд░рд╛рддреБрд╢реН рдЪ рдиреИрд╡ рд░рд┐рдХреНрдерднрд╛рдЬрдГ рд╕реНрдпреБрдГ ред рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдп рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рд╣рд░реЗрддреН, рддрджрднрд╛рд╡реЗ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░рдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪреМрд░рд╕рд╕реНрдп рдкрд┐рддреГрдзрдирдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреМ рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрд╛рджрд┐рд╕реБрддрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдереЛ рд╜рдпрдореН рдЖрд░рдореНрднрдГ ред рдпрдереНрд╢реН рдЪреЗрджрдореН рдЖрд╣ рее реп.резреорел рее

B├╝hler

185 Not brothers, nor fathers, (but) sons take the paternal estate; but the father shall take the inheritance of (a son) who leaves no male issue, and his brothers.

186 рддреНрд░рдпрд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЙрджрдХрдореН ...{Loading}...

рддреНрд░рдпрд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЙрджрдХрдВ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ
рддреНрд░рд┐рд╖реБ рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ ред
рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдердГ рд╕рдВрдкреНрд░рджрд╛рддреИрд╖рд╛рдВ
рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдореЛ рдиреЛрдкрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резреорем рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

To three should water-libation be offered; to three is the cake offered; the fourth is the giver of these offerings; there can be no fifth.тАФ(186)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

According to Kull┼лka and R─Бghv─Бnanda the verse is meant to indicate the right of the kс╣гetraja and other secondary sons to inherit the estate of grand-father and others dying childless.тАФAccording to Nandana it indicates the right of grand-sons and great grand-sons to inherit before brothers and the rest.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 592);тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 744), as describing the тАШnearest sapiс╣Зс╕НasтАЩ; the sense being that that sapiс╣Зс╕Нa is the тАШnearestтАЩ who makes water-offerings to the same persons (father, grandfather and great-grandfather); so that the uterine brother would be the тАШnearestтАЩ; the son of the uterine brother would he one step removed, as his тАШfatherтАЩ would be different;тАФstill one further removed would be the brotherтАЩs grandson, as his тАШfatherтАЩ and тАШgrandfatherтАЩ would both be different; so on with the others.

It is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva II (p. 134), to the effect that the father, the grandfather and the great-grandfather, irrespective of their wives, are the тАШdeitiesтАЩ (i.e., recipients) of the water and other offerings;тАФand again on p. 195;тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 655);тАФin V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 198b);тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, pp. 157 and 253).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.186-189)
**

[[See Text under 185.]]

M─Бnava-┼Ъr─Бddhakalpa (III).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

─Аpastamba (2.14.2-5).тАФтАШOn failure of sons, the nearest Sapiс╣Зс╕Нa takes the property; failing him, the preceptor; failing him the pupil, who may use it for the teacherтАЩs benefit or enjoy it himself; or the daughter may take the property; on the failure of all relations, let the King take the property.тАЩ

Gautama (28.21).тАФтАШSapiс╣Зс╕Нas, Sagotras, those connected by descent from the same с╣Ъс╣гi, and the wife shall share the estate of a person dying without male issue (or an Appointed Daughter).тАЩ

Do. (28.41, 42).тАФтАШ┼Ъrotriyas shall divide the estate of a childless Br─Бhmaс╣Зa;тАФthe King shall take the property of the other castes.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (1.11.9-15).тАФтАШThe great-grand-father, the grand-father, the father, oneтАЩs own-self, the uterine brothers, the son by a wife of equal caste, the grand-son and the great-grand-son,тАФthese they call Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas; and amongst these, the son and the sonтАЩs son (together with the father) are sharers of an undivided oblation; sharers of divided oblations, they call Sakulyas. If no other relations are living, the property of the deceased man descends to his Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas; on the failure of Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas, the Sakulyas inherit; on the failure of these, the preceptor who takes the place of the spiritual father, a pupil or an officiating priest shall take the property; on failure of these, the King, who shall give that property to persons versed in the three Vedas; but the King shall never take the property of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (17.81-84).тАФтАШThe Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas or the subsidiary sons shall divide the property of him who has no son of the first six kinds; on failure of them, the preceptor and the pupil shall take the property; on failure of these two, the King inherits; but the King shall never take the property of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (17.10-14).тАФтАШFailing brotherтАЩs sons, the property goes to the relations called Bandhu; failing these, to those called Sakulya; failing these, to a fellow-student; failing him, to the King, except when it is Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs property;тАФthe property of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas goes to Br─Бhmaс╣Зas.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2. 135-130).тАФтАШThe wife, daughters, parents, brothers, brotherтАЩs sons, Sagotс╣Ыa, BandhuтАФrelations, pupils, fellow-students,тАФfrom among these in the absence of the preceding, the succeeding inherits the property of the man who dies without male issue. This is the law for all castes.тАЩ N─Бrada (Apar─Бrka,p. 715).тАФтАШInthe absence of daughters, the property goes to Sakulyas and B─Бndhuvas, and then to people of the same caste; and failing all these, to the King. In the absence of all relations, the holy Br─Бhmaс╣Зas learned in the Vedas inherit the property; the property of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shall not be taken by the King; of men of other castes, the property shall be taken by the King.тАЩ

Paiс╣нh─лnasi (Apar─Бrka, p. 716).тАФтАШThe property of the learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa goes to the Assembly, not to the King.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд╕реНрдп рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдХрд░реНрд╖рд╕реНрдп рд╡рд┐рднрд╡рдирд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рд╜рдпрдВ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ рее реп.резреорем рее

B├╝hler

186 To three (ancestors) water must be offered, to three the funeral cake is given, the fourth (descendant is) the giver of these (oblations), the fifth has no connection (with them).

187 рдЕрдирдиреНрддрд░рдГ рд╕рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрд╛рджреН ...{Loading}...

рдЕрдирдиреНрддрд░рдГ рд╕рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрд╛рджреН рдпрд╕реН
рддрд╕реНрдп рддрд╕реНрдп рдзрдирдВ рднрд╡реЗрддреН ред
рдЕрдд рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдВ рд╕рдХреБрд▓реНрдпрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН
рдЖрдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпрдГ рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдп рдПрд╡ рд╡рд╛ рее реп.резреорен рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The property shall always devolve upon him who is nearest to the (deceased) тАШSapiс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ; after these either a тАШSakulyaтАЩ; or the Spiritual Preceptor, or the pupil.тАФ(187)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSapiс╣Зс╕Н─БtтАЩ.тАФтАЬIn the text the word is masculine. Kull┼лka begins by taking it generally as masculine or feminine, then, after giving the law of inheritance for the sons, he begins by taking the wife as the first female inheritor, quotes seven verses of Bс╣Ыhaspati and Vс╣Ыddha Manu, and also Y─Бj├▒valkya (2.135-136) to prove the statement; and ends by giving a list of female sapiс╣Зс╕Нas, after denouncing Medh─Бtithi, because he denies the wife the right of sharing the inheritanceтАЭ.тАФHopkins.

R─Бghav─Бnanda agrees, in substance, with Kull┼лka; but in order to make the rule still more fully agree with Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2. 35-136), he asserts that the cognates (Bandhus) are also implied by the term тАШsakulyaтАЩ.тАФAccording to Nandana, the тАШsakulyasтАЩ are Sam─Бnadakas.

The first half of this verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.136), as lending support to the view that among brothers, the first claim is that of the uterine one, those born of other mothers being a step further removed;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 744) to the effect that the nearer sapiс╣Зс╕Нa has the prior claim,тАФтАШnearnessтАЩ having been described under 186.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 592), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШAnantaraс╕етАЩ, near,тАФтАШdhanamтАЩ, of the man without son,тАФтАШsakulyaтАЩ here stands for Sam─Бnadaka;тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 63), in support of the view that the claim of the sister comes next to that of the grandmother (paternal);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva II (p. 195), which explains the meaning to be that тАШfrom among the Sapiс╣Зс╕Нas of the dead man, the nearest will inherit his propertyтАЩ;тАФin D─Бyakramasaс╣Еgraha (pp. 10 and 28);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 40b);тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (pp. 570 and 662);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Calcutta, p. 154);тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 332), which, explains тАШsakulyaтАЩ as тАШbeyond the Sapiс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ, and also as тАШthe descendant of great-great-grandfatherтАЩ.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.186-189)
**

[[See Text under 185.]]

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.186].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╕рдХреБрд▓реНрдпрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгреЗрди рд╕рдорд╛рдиреЛрджрдХрд╛ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдЖрдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпрдГ рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдпреЛ рд╡рд╛ ред рддрджрднрд╛рд╡реЗ рее реп.резреорен рее

B├╝hler

187 Always to that (relative within three degrees) who is nearest to the (deceased) Sapinda the estate shall belong; afterwards a Sakulya shall be (the heir, then) the spiritual teacher or the pupil.

188 рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН ...{Loading}...

рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрднрд╛рд╡реЗ рддреБ
рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛ рд░рд┐рдХреНрдерднрд╛рдЧрд┐рдирдГ ред
рддреНрд░реИрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдГ рд╢реБрдЪрдпреЛ рджрд╛рдиреНрддрд╛рд╕реН
рддрдерд╛ рдзрд░реНрдореЛ рди рд╣реАрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резреорео рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

But, on the failure of all, the property shall be taken by Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, learned in the Vedas, pure and self-controlled; in this manner the law would not be violated.тАФ(188)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSarveс╣г─БmтАЩтАФтАШOf all the heirs mentioned in the preceding verseтАЩ (R─Бghav─Бnada);тАФтАШof all males and females related in any way to the deceasedтАЩ (Nandana);тАФthe term indicates that other persons, not named here, such as fellow-students and so forth, are also entitled to the inheritance (Kull┼лka).

тАЬN─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa points out that this rule refers solely to the property of a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЭ.тАФBuhler.

This verse is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 675), which says that it refers to any Br─Бhmaс╣Зa neighbour of the deceased;тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.136), to the effect that on the failure of blood-relations, a fellow-student, and a learned Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, the property shall go to any ordinary Br─Бhmaс╣Зa;тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 665);тАФin D─Бyakramasaс╣Еgraha (p. 12);тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 333).

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 597);тАФand in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 354), which makes the same remark as Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.186-189)
**

[[See Text under 185.]]

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.186].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрднрд╛рд╡реЗ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЧрдореНрдпрддреЗ рддрддреНрд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрднрд╛рд╡реЗ рдпрдереЛрдХреНрддрдЧреБрдгрд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдз [рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪ] рд╕рддрд┐ рее реп.резреорео рее

B├╝hler

188 But on failure of all (heirs) Brahmanas (shall) share the estate, (who are) versed the in the three Vedas, pure and self-controlled; thus the law is not violated.

189 рдЕрд╣рд╛рд░реНрдпрдореН рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЕрд╣рд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдВ
рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛ рдирд┐рддреНрдпрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐рдГ ред
рдЗрддрд░реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рддреБ рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ
рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рднрд╛рд╡реЗ рд╣рд░реЗрдиреН рдиреГрдкрдГ рее реп.резреореп рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The property of the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shoved never be taken by the King,тАФsuch is the law; but in the case of other castes, the king shall take the property, in the absence of all heirs.тАФ(189)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

The first half of this verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гav─Б (2.136), which remarks that this only means that the king shall not take the Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs property, and not that even a son may not inherit the Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs property;тАФagain, to the effect that no part of the Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs estate shall be an escheat to the king.

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 675), to the effect that the property of the Kс╣гatriya caste, in the absence of legal heirs, shall go to the king, and not to the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 597);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 355) to the effect that on the failure of legal heirs, the Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs property shall never go to the king, while that of the other castes shall go to the king;тАФin D─Бyakramasaс╣Еgraha (p. 12);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 41a);тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 338).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.186-189)
**

[[See Text under 185.]]

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.186].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЛрдЬреНрд╡рд░реНрдердГ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ рее реп.резреореп рее

B├╝hler

189 The property of a Brahmana must never be taken by the king, that is a settled rule; but (the property of men) of other castes the king may take on failure of all (heirs).

190 рд╕рдВрд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╜рдирдкрддреНрдпрд╕реНрдп рд╕рдЧреЛрддреНрд░рд╛рддреН ...{Loading}...

рд╕рдВрд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╜рдирдкрддреНрдпрд╕реНрдп
рд╕рдЧреЛрддреНрд░рд╛рддреН рдкреБрддреНрд░рдореН рдЖрд╣рд░реЗрддреН ред
рддрддреНрд░ рдпрджреН рд░рд┐рдХреНрдердЬрд╛рддрдВ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН
рддрддреН рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рджрдпреЗрддреН рее реп.резрепреж рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In the case of a man dying childless, if an issue is raised from a member of the same family, all the property that there may be shall be delivered to that child.тАФ(190)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

According to Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda, this verse refers to the case in which a duly authorised widow bears a son to her husband through a sagotra; and the former adds that this practice having been already sanctioned under verse 59, it is mentioned here again with a view to make it clear that the son may be obtained by the widow, not only тАЬfrom the younger brother-in-law or a Sapiс╣Зс╕НaтАЭ, but also from a remoter sagotra.тАФN─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa holds the meaning of this verse to be that the son that the widow bears, even without authorisation, to a sagotra, shall inherit the property of the husband of that widow. He adds that some people apply this rule to ┼Ъ┼лdra females only.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 589), which adds the following notes:тАФThe widow of a deceased person should bear a son from a тАШsagotraтАЩтАФi.e. either from the younger brother-in-law or a sapiс╣Зс╕НaтАФshould make over the property owned by her dead husband to that son, and she should not take it herself; such is the opinion of the P─Бrij─Бta;тАФthe author of the Prak─Б┼Ыa on the other hand holds the meaning to be that the king himself should make the widow bear a son through a sagotra, and hand over to him the fatherтАЩs property;тАФthe final result of both the explanations is the same.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 742), which explains тАШtasmaiтАЩ (which is its reading for тАШtasminтАЩ) as тАШto that childтАЩ;тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 758).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

[See texts under [59], [145 and 146].]

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрд╕реНрдп рджреЗрд╡рд░рд╕рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЗрд╣ рд╕рдЧреЛрддреНрд░рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рддрджреБрддреНрдкрдиреНрдирд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рдзрдирд╛рдВрд╢рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН ред рдЗрддрд░рдерд╛ рд╣рд┐ “рджреЗрд╡рд░рд╛рджреН рд╡рд╛ рд╕рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрд╛рджреН рд╡рд╛” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рджреН рдЕрджреЗрд╡рд░рд╕рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрд╛рддреН рд╕рдЧреЛрддреНрд░рд╛рддреН рдЙрддреНрдкрдиреНрдирд╕реНрдп рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдЬрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдирдВрд╢рд╛рд░реНрд╣рддрд╛ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрдХрд╕реНрдп рджрддреНрддрдХрд╕реНрдп рддреБ рджрддреНрддреНрдХреГрддреНрд░рд┐рдорд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВрджрддреНрддрд╛рдГ рд╕реНрдпреБрдГ рее реп.резрепреж рее

B├╝hler

190 (If the widow) of (a man) who died without leaving issue, raises up to him a son by a member of the family (Sagotra), she shall deliver to that (son) the whole property which belonged to the (deceased).

191 рджреНрд╡реМ рддреБ ...{Loading}...

рджреНрд╡реМ рддреБ рдпреМ рд╡рд┐рд╡рджреЗрдпрд╛рддрд╛рдВ
рджреНрд╡рд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдЬрд╛рддреМ рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ рдзрдиреЗ ред
рддрдпреЛрд░реН рдпрджреН рдпрд╕реНрдп рдкрд┐рддреНрд░реНрдпрдВ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН
рддрддреН рд╕ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдд рдиреЗрддрд░рдГ рее реп.резрепрез рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

But if two sons, born of two men, contend for the property in the motherтАЩs possession, each shall take, to the exclusion of the other, what belonged to his own father.тАФ(191)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

Kull┼лka and Nandana take this verse as referring to the case in which a woman married twice successively two husbands and bore a son to each of them; in this case, on the death of the husbands, the property of each should be given by the mother to his own son.тАФR─Бghav─Бnanda, while accepting this explanation, proposes another:тАФтАШIf two sons begotten by two different men contend for the separate property of their mother, &c., &c.тАЩ.тАФN─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa holds that the verse refers to a contention between a тАШbody-bornтАЩ son and a тАШgolakaтАЩ or тАШPaunarbhavaтАЩ son for the estates of their respective fathers held by their mother.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 588), which notes that the term тАШstr─лтАЩ, according to the P─Бrij─Бta, stands for the prostitute, the re-married widow or the dissolute woman;тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (pp. 483 and 758).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

[See texts under [59], [145 and 146].]

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдпрд╛ рдкреБрдирд░реНрднреВрдГ рд╕рд╛рдкрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╕рдзрдирд╛ рдЪ рдкрд░рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЗ рдкреБрдирд░реН рднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдпрдВ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ ред рдЗрджрдВ рдЪ рдкреБрдирд░реНрднреВрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВрд╢рд╣рд░рддреНрд╡реЗ рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдореН рее реп.резрепрез рее

B├╝hler

191 But if two (sons), begotten by two (different men), contend for the property (in the hands) of their mother, each shall take, to the exclusion of the other, what belonged to his father.

192 рдЬрдирдиреНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЬрдирдиреНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рддреБ
рд╕рдордВ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗ рд╕рд╣реЛрджрд░рд╛рдГ ред
рднрдЬреЗрд░рдиреН рдорд╛рддреГрдХрдВ рд░рд┐рдХреНрдердВ
рднрдЧрд┐рдиреНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рд╕-рдирд╛рднрдпрдГ рее реп.резрепреи рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

When the mother has died, all the uterine brothers and uterine sisters shall divide the motherтАЩs property equally.тАФ(192)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

According to Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda, this rule applies to unmarried daughters only, the married daughters receiving only a fourth of a brotherтАЩs share (see 118 above).тАФN─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa holds that тАШm─Бtrikam rikthamтАЩ refers to property other than the тАШstr─лdhanaтАЩ, and qualifies the тАШsistersтАЩ as тАШwithout sonтАЩ.

This verse is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 667), which adds the following notes:тАФThe meaning of the verse is that the motherтАЩs estate is to go (1) to her own daughters, (2) on their absence to her daughterтАЩs sons, (3) in the absence of these latter to her own sons, not to the sons of her cowives, (4) in the absence of her sons, to the sons of her own son;тАФthe expression тАШsamam sarve sahodar─Бс╕етАЩ is meant to preclude the brothers born of different mothers;тАФthe sons of co-wives being entitled to inherit only in default of the womanтАЩs own sons (or grandsons).

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.145), as asserting the title of both sons and daughters to the estate of their mother; it explains the construction asтАФтАШM─Бtс╣Ыkam riktham sarve sahodar─Бс╕е samam bhajeran san─Бbhayo bhaginya┼Ыca samam bhajeranтАЩ;тАФit does not mean that the тАШsons and daughters together shall divide the property equallyтАЩ; if this were the meaning then the words used would have been тАШbhr─Бtс╣Ыbhagiyaс╕етАЩ or тАШbhr─Бс╣нaraс╕етАЩ;тАФthe term samam is meant to preclude the special additional shareтАЩ (of the eldest brother), and тАШsahodar─Бс╕етАЩ to preclude the brothers born of other mothers:тАФThe B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л reproduces the remarks noted above from the Madanap─Бrij─Бta, attributing it to the Kalpataru.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 721), which remarks that the particle тАШcaтАЩ (тАШbhaginya┼ЫcaтАЩ) denotes option, not combination; and in the option, the first title is of the unmarried daughters;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 515), which adds the following notesтАФтАШSamamтАЩ, without any additional share being allotted to the eldest,тАФтАШbhaginyaс╕етАЩ, those that are unmarried and those that have had no children,тАФтАШSan─Бbhayaс╕етАЩ, uterine;тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 70), which states the opinion of тАШsomeтАЩ that the verse lays down the conjoint title of brothers and sisters to such property of their mother as she had received as presents from her husband;тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Calcutta, pp. 125 and 142), which explains тАШsamamтАЩ as тАШnot in unequal sharesтАЩ,тАФSan─Бbhayaс╕етАЩ as тАШuterineтАЩ, and notes that this refers to unmarried sisters only,тАФin Nity─Бc─Бrapaddhati (p. 296);тАФin V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 216a), which says that the sense is that all uterine brothers and sisters are entitled to equal shares in the motherтАЩs property,тАФand all half brothers and sisters are excluded;тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 126), which has the same note.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.192-193)
**

[[See 131] and the texts there under. Also 198.]

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.117).тАФтАШOf the motherтАЩs property, what remains after paying off her debts, shall be taken by the daughters, and in their absence, by their offspring.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 721).тАФтАШIn the absence of daughters, the motherтАЩs property should go to the sons. What had been given to the woman by her kinsmen shall, in the absence of kinsmen, go to her husband. The str─лdhana shall be divided among her daughters with their husbands and her kinsmen.тАЩ

Gautama (Do.).тАФтАШThe str─лdhana of a woman goes to those of her daughters who are not married or settled in life.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Apar─Бrka, p. 721).тАФтАШThe str─лdhana of a woman goes to her children; her daughter also has a share in it, if she is unmarried; if she is married, she obtains some honorific trifle.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (Do.).тАФтАШThe girls shall divide the motherтАЩs dowry.тАЩ

Artha┼Ы─Бstra (p. 13).тАФтАШThe second dowry, the female child will inherit.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╕рдорд╡рдЪрдирд╛рдиреН рдирд╛рд╕реНрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдВрд╢рдГ ред рднрдЧрд┐рдиреНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рд╕рдирд╛рднрдп рдКрдврд╛ рдЕрдиреВрдврд╛рд╢реН рдЪ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдЕрдиреВрдврд╛ рдПрд╡реЗрддрд┐ рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рддреН ред рдмрдЧрд┐рдиреНрдпрднрд╛рд╡реЗ рддреБ рее реп.резрепреи рее

B├╝hler

192 But when the mother has died, all the uterine brothers and the uterine sisters shall equally divide the mother’s estate.

193 рдпрд╛рд╕реН рддрд╛рд╕рд╛рдореН ...{Loading}...

рдпрд╛рд╕реН рддрд╛рд╕рд╛рдВ рд╕реНрдпреБрд░реН рджреБрд╣рд┐рддрд░рд╕реН
рддрд╛рд╕рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдпрдерд╛рд░реНрд╣рддрдГ [рд╣реН: рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ] ред
рдорд╛рддрд╛рдорд╣реНрдпрд╛ рдзрдирд╛рддреН рдХрд┐рдВ рдЪрд┐рддреН
рдкреНрд░рджреЗрдпрдВ рдкреНрд░реАрддрд┐рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдХрдореН рее реп.резрепрей рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Even to the daughters of those daughters something shall be lovingly given, as is quite proper, out of the property of their maternal grandmother.тАФ(193)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

The grand-daughters should be unmarried (Kull┼лka);тАФтАШwhen the married daughters are dead, their daughters shall be presented at will by their maternal uncles with the share which their mothers would have received as a token of respectтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa);тАФтАШPr─лtip┼лrvakamтАЩ means тАШat the pleasure of the sonsтАЩ (R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФthe gift to the grand-daughters is absolutely compulsory (Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 666) which explains тАШt─Бs─БmтАЩ as тАШof the daughters of the deceased ladyтАЩ;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 722);тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 516), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШT─Бs─БmтАЩ, of the daughters mentioned in the preceding verse,тАФтАШyath─Бс╣Г┼Ыataс╕етАЩ, according as the property is large or small;тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 71) as laying down that some part of the womanтАЩs property should be given to her grand-daughters;тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Calcutta, p. 142);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 216b), which explains тАШyath─Бrhataс╕етАЩ as тАШin consideration of their poverty and other circumstancesтАЩ.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.192-193)
**

[[See 131] and the texts there under. Also 198.]

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.192].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдКрдврд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреВрдврд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪреЗрддрд┐ рдХреГрддрд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рдореН рдПрддрддреН ред рдкреНрд░реАрддрд┐рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдХрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рдиреН рди рдирд┐рдпрддрдВ рджрд╛рдирдореН рдЗрджрдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдпрддреЗ рее реп.резрепрей рее

B├╝hler

193 Even to the daughters of those (daughters) something should be given, as is seemly, out of the estate of their maternal grandmother, on the score of affection.

194 рдЕрдзреНрдпрдЧреНрдиреНрдпреН-рдЕрдзреНрдпрд╛рд╡рд╛рд╣рдирд┐рдХрдиреН рджрддреНрддрдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЕрдзреНрдпрдЧреНрдиреНрдпреН-рдЕрдзреНрдпрд╛рд╡рд╛рд╣рдирд┐рдХрдВ
рджрддреНрддрдВ рдЪ рдкреНрд░реАрддрд┐рдХрд░реНрдордгрд┐ ред
рднреНрд░рд╛рддреГ-рдорд╛рддреГ-рдкрд┐рддреГрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрдВ
рд╖рдбреНрд╡рд┐рдзрдВ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдзрдирдВ рд╕реНрдореГрддрдореН рее реп.резрепрек рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

(1) What is given before the fire, (2) what is given at the time of departure, (3) what is given in token of love, and what is received from (4) the brother, (5) the mother and (6) the father,тАФhas been declared to be тАШStr─лdhanaтАЩ (the exclusive property of the woman).тАФ(194)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 368), which notes that the term тАШsix-foldтАЩ is meant to preclude a lesser, not a larger, number;тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.135-136), as setting aside the view that women have no rights to property except through their husband or son B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л explaining тАШadhyagniтАЩ as that obtained near the fire at the marriage ceremony,тАФтАШadhy─Бv─БhanikamтАЩ as that obtained at the time of her coming to her husbandтАЩs place;тАФIt is quoted again under 2.143, where it is noted that the six kinds mentioned are meant only as denying a lesser number; it goes on to quote K─Бty─Бyana as explaining each of these terms:тАФтАШ(1)That which is given to the girl at the time of marriage near the fire is called adhyagni,тАФ(2) what she receives at the time of being carried away from her fatherтАЩs house is called adhy─Бv─Бhanika,тАФ(3) what she receives as a loving present from her father-in-law or mother-in-law at the time of offering obeisance is called pr─лtidatta,тАФ(4) (5) (6) whatever the married girl receives from her husband or from her parents or brothers is called Saud─Бyika.тАЩ

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 522), which offers the following explanations:тАФтАШAdhyagniтАЩ, what is given by anyone at the time of marriage,тАФтАШadhy─Бv─БhanikaтАЩ, whatever is carried behind her when she is being carried away from her fatherтАЩs house,тАФMedh─Бtithi however holds that adhy─Бv─Бhanika is what she receives from her parents-in-law at the time of returning to her fatherтАЩs place; and this view also maybe accepted;тАФтАШprititaс╕е dattamтАЩ, what she receives from the father-in-law and other elders as a reward for her character, efficiency and other good qualities;тАФthe mention of тАШsix kindsтАЩ is for the purpose of precluding a lesser, not a larger, number; in fact a seventh kind, тАШ─Бdhivedan─лkaтАЩтАФwhat she receives by way of compensation for being superseded by anotherтАФhas also been mentioned by Y─Бj├▒avalkya.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 68), which also remarks that the тАШsixтАЩ are mentioned only for the purpose of denying a lesser number;тАФand in Hem─Бdri (D─Бna, p. 51), which explains тАШadhyagniтАЩ as тАШwhat is given to the woman before the fireтАЩ,тАФтАШadhy─Бv─БhanikamтАЩ as тАШgiven to her by her father and relatives at the time of her marriage,тАЩтАФтАШpr─лtikarmaс╣ЗiтАЩ, тАШgiven by the husband as a token of conjugal loveтАЩтАФandтАФтАШpr─БptamтАЩ as given to her, even after her marriage, by her brother and others.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.194-195)
**

Viс╣гс╣Зu (17.18).тАФтАШWhat has been given to a woman by her father, mother, sons, or brothers, what she has received before the sacrificial fire at the marriage ceremony, what she receives on supersession, what has been given to her by her relatives, her nuptial fee, and a gift subsequent, are called str─лdhana.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.143).тАФтАШWhat is given to a woman by her father, mother, son or brother,тАФwhat is given before the nuptial fire, and what comes to her in connection with her supersession has been called str─лdhana.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 751).тАФтАШWhat is given to a woman near the nuptial fire by gentlemen is called Adhyagni str─лdhana. What the woman obtains at the time of her being taken away from her fatherтАЩs house is called the Adhy─Бv─Бhanika str─лdhana. What is given to her, through affection, by her father in-law or mother-in-law, at the time of her bowing to them, is called L─Бvaс╣Зy─Бrjita. What is obtained by a married woman or her husband at her fatherтАЩs house, either from her parents or her brother, is called Saud─Бyika. Over the Saud─Бyika, the ownership of the woman is absolute and she is free to sell it or given it away, even when it consists of immovable property. What the woman obtains, after marriage, from her husbandтАЩs family, or from her husbandтАЩs parents, is called Anv─Бdheya by Bhс╣Ыgu. While she is alive, neither her husband nor her sons nor her brother-in-law nor her husbandтАЩs kinsmen, have any rights over her str─лdhana; if they take it from her they should he punished.тАЩ

Vс╣Ыddha-Vy─Бsa (Apar─Бrka, p. 752).тАФтАШWhatever the girl obtains, at marriage or after marriage, from her fatherтАЩs or brotherтАЩs house, is called Saud─Бyika. At the marriage of the girl whatever is given with reference to the bridegroom forms the property of the girl, not to be divided by her kinsmen.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Do., p. 752).тАФтАШWhat is given to her, through love, by her husband, that she shall enjoy as site chooses, even after his death, with the exception of immovable property.тАЩ

Do. (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 524).тАФтАШAdhyagni, Adhy─Бv─Бhanika, Bhartс╣Ыd─Бya (inherited from her husband), what is given by her brother and what is given by her mother and what is given by her father,тАФthese are the six kinds of str─лdhana.тАЩ

┼Ъukran─лti (4.5.597).тАФтАШThe Saud─Бyika property is known to be that which comes to a married woman through gifts and dowries, from her parentsтАЩ or husbandтАЩs families, or through presents from parents and relatives.тАЩ

P─Бraskara (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava, Vyavah─Бra, p. 372).тАФтАШThe str─лdhana belongs to the unmarried daughter; the son cannot have it; if the daughter has been married, the son shall share it equally with her.тАЩ

[(See the texts under 192-193.)]

K─Бty─Бyana (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 573).тАФтАШNeither the husband, nor the son, nor the father, nor the brothers have the right to take away or to spend a womanтАЩs str─лdhana; if any one of them takes away the str─лdhana forcibly, he should be made to make it good along with interest, and should also pay a fine; if any one makes use of it with her permission, and in a manner agreeable to her, he should repay it, if he has the wealth to do it. Whatever the woman may have lovingly given to any of the above relations during his sickness or when he was in trouble or harassed by creditors,тАФthat also he may voluntarily repay.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╖рдбреНрд╡рд┐рдзрд╕реНрдп рдирд┐рдпрдорд╛рддреН рдореИрддреНрд░рд▓рдмреНрдзрд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдзрдирддреНрд╡рдВ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдзреНрдпрдЧреНрдиреАрдпрдореН рдЕрдЧреНрдирд┐рд╕рдореАрдк рдЙрд╣реНрдпрдорд╛рдирд╛рдпреИ рджрддреНрддрдореН ред рдЕрдзреНрдпрд╛рд╡рд╛рд╣рдирд┐рдХрдВ рдкрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рдЧреГрд╣рдореН рдЖрдиреАрдпрдорд╛рдирд╛рдпреИ рджреАрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резрепрек рее

B├╝hler

194 What (was given) before the (nuptial) fire, what (was given) on the bridal procession, what was given in token of love, and what was received from her brother, mother, or father, that is called the sixfold property of a woman.

195 рдЕрдиреНрд╡рд╛рдзреЗрдпрдЮреН рдЪ ...{Loading}...

рдЕрдиреНрд╡рд╛рдзреЗрдпрдВ рдЪ рдпрджреН рджрддреНрддрдВ
рдкрддреНрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░реАрддреЗрди рдЪреИрд╡ рдпрддреН ред
рдкрддреНрдпреМ рдЬреАрд╡рддрд┐ рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ
рдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдпрд╛рд╕реН рддрджреН рдзрдирдВ рднрд╡реЗрддреН рее реп.резрепрел рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Also the gift that is subsequently made to her by her loving husband, shall go to her offspring, if she dies while her husband is living.тАФ(195)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

According to N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Kull┼лka what is said here refers also to the тАШstr─лdhanaтАЩ described under 194.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 516), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШAnv─БdheyamтАЩ is going to be defined later on,тАФHal─Бyudha holds that this verse is meant to show that the husband has no connection with the two kinds of property here mentioned, over which the married woman has absolute right, even during her husbandтАЩs life-time.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 70) as laying down the persons who are to inherit the тАШanv─БdheyaтАЩ property of a woman;тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (pp. 755 and 759);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 216b), which explains the force of the locative in тАШpatyau j─лvatiтАЩ to express disregard, the meaning being that the husband has no lights over t├мie property,тАФand adds that all brothers and sisters (married as well as unmarried) are equally entitled.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.194-195)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.194].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЛрдЬреНрд╡рд░реНрдердГ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ рее реп.резрепрел рее

B├╝hler

195 (Such property), as well as a gift subsequent and what was given (to her) by her affectionate husband, shall go to her offspring, (even) if she dies in the lifetime of her husband.

196 рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдо-рджреИрд╡рд╛рд░реНрд╖-рдЧрд╛рдиреНрдзрд░реНрд╡- рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЬрд╛рдкрддреНрдпреЗрд╖реБ ...{Loading}...

рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдо-рджреИрд╡рд╛рд░реНрд╖-рдЧрд╛рдиреНрдзрд░реНрд╡-
рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЬрд╛рдкрддреНрдпреЗрд╖реБ рдпрджреН рд╡рд╕реБ ред
рдЕрдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрддреАрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ
рднрд░реНрддреБрд░реН рдПрд╡ рддрджреН рдЗрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резрепрем рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдПрддреЗрд╖реБ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдзреЗрд╖реБ (?) рднрд░реНрддреБрд░реН рдзрдирдореН рдЕрднреНрдпрдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдпрддреЗ рее реп.резрепрем рее

B├╝hler

196 It is ordained that the property (of a woman married) according to the Brahma, the Daiva, the Arsha, the Gandharva, or the Pragapatya rite (shall belong) to her husband alone, if she dies without issue.

197 рдпрддреН рддреНрд╡реН ...{Loading}...

рдпрддреН рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдзрдирдВ рджрддреНрддрдВ
рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣реЗрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЖрд╕реБрд░рд╛рджрд┐рд╖реБ ред
рдЕрдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрддреАрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ
рдорд╛рддрд╛-рдкрд┐рддреНрд░реЛрд╕реН рддрджреН рдЗрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.резрепрен рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It is ordained that the property of women married by the тАШBr─Бhma,тАЩ the тАШDaiva,тАЩ the тАШ─Аrс╣гa,тАЩ the тАШG─Бndharva,тАЩ or the тАШPr─Бj─БpatyaтАЩ form, shall go to her husband alone, if she dies childless.тАФ(196)

But the property given to a woman on the тАШ─АsuraтАЩ or other (inferior) forms of marriage, has been held to belong to her parents, upon her dying childless.тАФ(197)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

(verses 9.196-197)

тАШVasuтАЩтАФincludes, according to N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa, all kinds of property, тАШstr─лdhanaтАЩ as well as what is not тАШstr─лdhanaтАЩ.

These verses are quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 373), which explains the meaning to be that on the death of a woman married by any of the forms of marriage here named, without leaving any heirтАФbeginning from the daughter down to the sonтАЩs son,тАФher property goes to her husband, and not to her mother or other relations,тАФwhile the property of an heirless woman, who has been married by the ─Аsura, R─Бkс╣гasa or Pai┼Ы─Бca forms, goes to her parents.

They are quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 753), which remarks that the devolution of the property on the husband should be regarded as an optional alternative; it apparently takes тАШ─Бsur─Бdiс╣гuтАЩ of verse 191 as including all those mentioned under 196.

They are quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 519), which explains тАШaprajasiтАЩ as тАШchildlessтАЩ; and the verses to mean that (a) in the case of those married by the forms of marriage mentioned in 196, the property goes to the husband, and (b) in that of those married by the forms mentioned in 197, it goes to her father;тАФit goes on to remark that this refers to what the woman had received at the time of marriage.

They are quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 72);тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva II (p. 186), which explains the meaning to be that the тАШstr─лdhanaтАЩ obtained at the time of the marriage under the forms mentioned in 196 goes to the husband, while that obtained at the time of marriage under the forms mentioned in 197 goes first to her mother, and in her absence to her father;тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 756);тАФin D─Бy─Бkramasaс╣Еgraha (p. 23);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Culcutta, p. 143), which explains тАШapraj─Бy─БmтАЩ as тАШchildlessтАЩ; and by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 141).

Verse 197 is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 219a), which says that the тАШmotherтАЩ being placed first in the compound implies that the father is to inherit the property only after the mother.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 9.196-197)

Viс╣гс╣Зu (17, 19.20).тАФтАШIf a woman, married according to one of the first four forms of marriage beginning with Br─Бhma, dies without issue, her str─лdhana goes to her husband;тАФif she has been married by one of the four reprehensible forms of marriage, her father shall take her property.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.141-145).тАФтАШIf a woman dies without issue, her kinsmen shall obtain what she had got from her kinsmen, or as her nuptial fee or as the Anv─Бdheyaka present; if a woman married according to the four forms of marriage beginning with the Br─Бhma, dies without issue, her property goes to her husband; if she had issue, it goes to her daughters;тАФif she had been married by the other forms of marriage, her property goes to her father.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 518).тАФтАШIn the absence of the daughter, the Str─лdhana of the mother should go to the sons; what was given to her by her kinsmen should go to her husband, in the absence of kinsmen. The sisters along with their husbands shall divide with the kinsmen, the str─лdhana. Such is the lawful law of partition.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдПрддреЗрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЖрд╕реБрд░рд╛рджрд┐рд╖реБ рдХрд▓реНрдпрд╛[рдиреЗрд╖реБ рддрдпреЛрдГ] рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд░реНрдкрдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдВ рдзрдирдореН рее реп.резрепрен рее

B├╝hler

197 But it is prescribed that the property which may have been given to a (wife) on an Asura marriage or (one of the) other (blamable marriages, shall go) to her mother and to her father, if she dies without issue.

198 рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдиреН рддреБ ...{Loading}...

рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдВ рддреБ рдпрджреН рднрд╡реЗрджреН рд╡рд┐рддреНрддрдВ
рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рджрддреНрддрдВ рдХрдердВ рдЪрди ред
рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреА рддрджреН рдзрд░реЗрддреН рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛
рддрджрдкрддреНрдпрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд╛ рднрд╡реЗрддреН рее реп.резрепрео рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The property that may have been given to a woman by her father shall be taken by the daughter of the Br─Бhamaс╣Зa-caste; or it shall belong to the child of that daughter.тАФ(198)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 667), which makes the following remarks:тАФThe term тАШstr─лтАЩ here stands for the step-mother and тАШkany─БтАЩ for the stepdaughter,тАФтАШBr─Бhmaс╣З─лтАЩ stands for higher caste in general, so that the property of a ┼Ы┼лdra step-mother will go to the daughter of her Br─Бhmaс╣З─л or Kс╣гatriya or Vai┼Ыya co-wife, that of the Vai┼Ыya step-mother will go to the daughter of Br─Бhmaс╣З─л or Kс╣гatriya co-wife, and that of the Kс╣гatriya step-mother to the daughter of the Br─Бhmaс╣З─л co-wife,тАФinasmuch as the present texс╣н makes the property inheritable by the step-daughter of a higher caste, it follows that step-daughters of the lower caste are not entitled to inherit the property of the step-mother of a higher caste, so long as this latter has a son.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 372), to the effect that, when a woman dies childless, her property goes to the daughter of that co-wife of hers who is of a higher caste, and in the absence of such a daughter to the children of that daughter.

It is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva II (p. 186), which has the following notes:тАФIn view of the qualification тАШgiven by the fatherтАЩ, the rule must be taken as referring to all that she receives from her father at other times than that of her marriage;тАФthe term тАШBr─Бhmaс╣З─л Kany─БтАЩ stands for daughter in general;тАФor the meaning may be that if a Kс╣гatriya or Vai┼Ыya woman dies childless, her property goes to her step-daughter born of her Br─Бhmaс╣З─л co-wife, and not to her hu┼Ыand.

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.145) to the effect that on the death of a childless woman her property goes to her stepdaughter born of a co-wife of the higher caste, and in the absence of such a daughter, to the child of that daughter. It adds that the term тАШBr─Бhmaс╣ЗiтАЩ stands for the higher caste; so that the property of a childless Vai┼Ыya woman goes to the daughter of her Kс╣гatriya co-wife. The B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds that the property goes to the step-daughter, not to the step-son; and it goes on to reproduce the exact words of Madanap─Бrij─Бta and of Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhva. It remarks that this rule is meant to be an exception to what has gone before, by which the property of the childless woman would go to her husband or brother, etc.;тАФfurther, that the term тАШkatha├▒canaтАЩ is meant to include property even other than that received from her father.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 71), which adds that тАШv─БтАЩ here stands for тАШcaтАЩ; so that the property is to be divided between the step-daughter and the step-daughterтАЩs child;тАФit has been held that the term тАШBr─Бhmaс╣З─лтАЩ stands for equal and higheс╣Ы castes; but we find no authority for this.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 721), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШPitr─БтАЩ, this is mentioned only by way of illustration;тАФтАШKany─БтАЩ, step-daughter;тАФagain on p. 753;тАФand in D─Бyakramasaс╣Еgraha (p. 26).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (13.47.25).

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╖рдбреНрд╡рд┐рдзрд╕реНрдпрд╛[рдкрд┐ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдзрди]рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╛рдореН [рдЕрддреАрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгреЗ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреНрдпреЗ] рд╕рддрд┐ рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рджрддреНрддрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рдирд┐рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдердВ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдзрдирд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдореН ред [рдореГрдд]рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╛рд╢реН рдЪ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдВ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреА рддрджреН рдзрд░реЗрддреН рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛ рдЗрддрд┐ рдирд┐рдпрдорд╛рддреН рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рджрд┐рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдореН [рдЕрдпрдВ рдирд┐рдп]рдордГ ред рдПрддрджреН рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН ред рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреАрдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╡реИрд╢реНрдпрд╛рд╕реВрдврд╛рд╕реНрд╡реН рдЕрд╕рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╕реНрддреНрд░реНрдпреБрдкрд░рдореЗ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджрд┐рдХрдиреНрдпрд╛рднреНрдпреЛ рдзрдирджрд╛рдирдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдореН рее реп.резрепрео рее

B├╝hler

198 Whatever property may have been given by her father to a wife (who has co-wives of different castes), that the daughter (of the) Brahmani (wife) shall take, or that (daughter’s) issue.

199 рди рдирд┐рд░реНрд╣рд╛рд░рдореН ...{Loading}...

рди рдирд┐рд░реНрд╣рд╛рд░рдВ рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрдГ рдХреБрд░реНрдпреБрдГ
рдХреБрдЯреБрдореНрдмрд╛рджреН рдмрд╣реБрдордзреНрдпрдЧрд╛рддреН ред
рд╕реНрд╡рдХрд╛рджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЪ рд╡рд┐рддреНрддрд╛рджреН +рдзрд┐
рд╕реНрд╡рд╕реНрдп рднрд░реНрддреБрд░реН рдЕрдирд╛рдЬреНрдЮрдпрд╛ рее реп.резрепреп рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Women shall never make a hoard out of the family-property common to many, nor out of their own property, without the husbandтАЩs permission.тАФ(199)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬKull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda take the first clause to refer to the property of a united family, and the second to the separate property of the husband.тАФBut according to N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Nandana the translation should be as follows:тАФтАШWives should never take anything (for their private expenses) from their husbandтАЩs property destined for the support of their families, over which many have a claim, nor from their own property which is not str─лdhana, without the consent of their husbandsтАЩ.тАЭтАФBuhler.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 509), which adds the following notes:тАФThe term тАШKuс╣нumbaтАЩ stands for the family-property; hence the meaning is that тАШout of the property that belongs to many persons, women shall not make an extraction, withdrawal, without the consent of the owners of that propertyтАЩ; similarly тАШsvak─БtтАЩтАФi.e., out of the property that belongs exclusively to her husband, and not to the other members of the family,тАФshe shall not make an extraction without the ownerтАЩs consent.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 69), which explains тАШnirh─БraтАЩ as expenditure;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 215a), which explains тАШnirh─БraтАЩ as тАШvyayaтАЩ.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (13.47.24).

K─Бty─Бyana (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 511).тАФтАШAfter her husbandтАЩs death, what the wife inherits from him she may use as she likes; but during his life-time, she shall save that property or spend it on the family.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдирд┐рд░реНрд╣рд╛рд░рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╛рдЪреН рдЪреИрддрддреН рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдпрддреЗ рдпрджрд┐ рдХрд╛рдЪрд┐рджреН рдИрд╢рддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рддрджреНрдзрдирдВ рдирд┐рд░реНрд╣рд░реЗрддреН, рддрддрд╕реН рддрддреНрдкреБрдирд░рд╛рджрд╛рдп рднреНрд░рд╛рддреГрднрд┐рд░реН рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдПрд╡ рее реп.резрепреп рее

B├╝hler

199 Women should never make a hoard from (the property of) their families which is common to many, nor from their own (husbands’ particular) property without permission.

200 рдкрддреНрдпреМ рдЬреАрд╡рддрд┐ ...{Loading}...

рдкрддреНрдпреМ рдЬреАрд╡рддрд┐ рдпрдГ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрднрд┐рд░реН
рдЕрд▓рдЩреНрдХрд╛рд░реЛ рдзреГрддреЛ рднрд╡реЗрддреН ред
рди рддрдВ рднрдЬреЗрд░рдиреН рджрд╛рдпрд╛рджрд╛
рднрдЬрдорд╛рдирд╛рдГ рдкрддрдиреНрддрд┐ рддреЗ рее реп.реирежреж рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The ornament worn by the woman during her husbandтАЩs life-time, her heirs shall not divide; if they divide it, they become outcasts.тАФ(200)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

Buhler mispresents Nandana, being misled by the wrong reading тАШbhartс╣Ыbh─БveтАЩ (while the husband lives) for тАШbhartrabh─БveтАЩ (on the death of the husband). There could be no division of the property by the heirs while the husband was alive.

This verse is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 686), which adds that тАШDhс╣ЫtamтАЩ means тАШpossessed as her own private property, having been given to her as a loving presentтАЩ;тАФand in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 70), which explains тАШdhс╣ЫtamтАЩ as тАШpresented to her by her husband or other relatives and worn by her.тАЩ

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.147) in support of the view that тАШif a woman has been living apart from her husband, her property shall not be taken by her heirsтАЩ;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 509), which notes that the Prak─Б┼Ыa has stated that Medh─Бtithi has explained the meaning to be that тАШthe heirs shall not take even those ornaments that may have been worn by the woman with her husbandтАЩs consent, even though not actually given to herтАЩ;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 752), which adds that this refers to such ornaments as have been worn by the woman constantly;тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva II (p. 184), which also reproduces the aforesaid remark of Medh─Бtithi, that an ornament worn by the woman with her husbandтАЩs consent becomes her property even though not actually given to her;тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 332), which says that the phrase тАШdhс╣Ыto bhavetтАЩ implies that what was not actually worn by her should be divided.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (17.22).тАФтАШOrnaments worn by women during their husbandтАЩs life-time, the heirs shall not divide among themselves; if they divide them, they become outcasts.тАЩ

─Аpastamba (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 509)тАФтАШThe ornaments belong to the wife.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Do., p. 495).тАФтАШWhen the property has been divided by the heirs, the ornaments and the nuptial presents of the mother shall be taken by her daughter.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (Do.).тАФтАШThe motherтАЩs ornaments, as also other formal presents made to the mother, the daughter shall take.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рджрд╛рдпрд╛рджрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рдЖрддреНрдореАрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рддреНрд╡реН рдФрд░рд╕рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рддреЛ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рее реп.реирежреж рее

B├╝hler

200 The ornaments which may have been worn by women during their husbands’ lifetime, his heirs shall not divide; those who divide them become outcasts.

201 рдЕрдирдВрд╢реМ рдХреНрд▓реАрдм-рдкрддрд┐рддреМ ...{Loading}...

рдЕрдирдВрд╢реМ рдХреНрд▓реАрдм-рдкрддрд┐рддреМ
рдЬрд╛рддреНрдпрдиреНрдз-рдмрдзрд┐рд░реМ рддрдерд╛ ред
рдЙрдиреНрдорддреНрдд-рдЬрдб-рдореВрдХрд╛рд╢реН рдЪ
рдпреЗ рдЪ рдХреЗ рдЪрд┐рдиреН рдирд┐рд░реН-рдЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдГ рее реп.реирежрез рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Eunuchs and outcasts, those born blind or deaf, idiots and the dumb, as well as those deficient in any organ, are entitled to no shares.тАФ(201)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

**(verses 9.182-201)
**

(No Bh─Бс╣гya available.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva II (p. 385), as enumerating persons not entitled to inheritance, and hence to the offering of funeral oblations;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 201, and again on p. 366), where тАШnirindriy─Бс╕етАЩ is explained as тАШwhose organs have become deficient through some diseaseтАЩ;тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б, (2.140), which has the following notes;тАФтАШNirindriyaтАЩ is one whose organs have disappeared by reason of some disease;тАФthese persons are debarred from inheritance, being entitled to mere subsistence and clothing; if they are not supported, his relations become degraded. The B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds the following explanations:тАФтАШJ─Бtyandha-badhir─Бс╕етАЩ are those who are blind and deaf by birth,тАФтАШm┼лkaтАЩ is one who is incapable from birth of uttering words,тАФthus are these two distinguished from тАШnirindriya,тАЩ which means those who have lost some organ as the result of disease.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, (p. 487), which adds the following notes:тАФThe term тАШj─БtiтАЩ is added with a view to denote incurability,тАФтАШjaс╕Нa,тАЩ one who is incapable of distinguishing what is his own and what belongs to others,тАФтАШnirindriy─Бс╕етАЩ includes the lame and the like, who are not entitled to the performance of ┼Ыrauta and sm─Бrta rites;тАФand in D─Бyakramasaс╣Еgraha, (p. 29).

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha, (p. 73), which explains тАШnirindriy─Бс╕етАЩ as devoid of the olfactory and other organs;тАФin V─лramitrodaya (R─Бjan─лti, p. 40), which explains тАШnirindriyaтАЩ as one who has lost his organs through disease;тАФand in Madanap─Бrij─Бta, (p. 682), which has the same explanation of тАШnirindriyaтАЩ and adds that all these men have no share in the property, but they have to he supported.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.201-202)
**

Gautama (18.43).тАФтАШAn idiot and a eunuch should he supported.тАЩ

Do. (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 486).тАФтАШAccording to some, even the son born of the wife of equal caste should not receive inheritance if she is addicted to unrighteousness.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (2.3.37-40)тАФтАШGranting food, clothes and shelter, they shall support those who are incapable of transacting business; viz., the blind, the idiot, those immersed in vice, the incurable invalid, and the like;тАФas also those who are neglectful of their duties and occupations;тАФbut not the outcast or his offspring.тАЩ

─Аpastamba (2.14.1).тАФтАШHe should, during his life-time, divide his property equally amongst his sons,тАФexcepting the eunuch, the insane and the outcast.тАЩ

Do. (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 486)тАФтАШAll who are endowed with righteousness are inheritors of property; if one uses wealth unrighteously, him the father shall disinherit, even if he be the eldest son.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (17.52-54).тАФтАШBut those who have entered a different order receive no share;тАФnor those who are eunuchs, insane or outcasts;тАФthe eunuch and the insane have a claim to maintenance.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (15.32-33).тАФтАШOutcasts, eunuchs, persons incurably diseased, and those deficient in organs of sense or action, do not receive a share;тАФbut they should be maintained by those who take the inheritance.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.140).тАФтАШThe eunuch, the outcast, the son of the outcast, the cripple, the insane, the idiot, the blind and one suffering from an incurable disease have no share in the property; but they should be maintained.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Apar─Бrka, p. 749).тАФтАШOne who harbours ill-will towards his father, the outcast, the eunuch and one who has committed one of the minor offences, should not receive any share, even when they are body-born sons;тАФwhat to say of those that are only Kс╣гetraja sons?тАЩ

Do. (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 489).тАФThose suffering from chronic or incurable diseases, the idiot, the insane, the blind and the cripple should be supported by the family; but their sons are entitled to shares in the property.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Do., p. 750).тАФтАШOne born of a wife married irregularly, one begotten by a Sagotra husband, and one who has gone away as a renunciate, do not inherit property.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 486).тАФтАШOne who has been excommunicated ceases to have any claims to inheritance or the funeral offering of food and water.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Do., p. 487).тАФтАШEven though a son may have been born from a wife of equal caste, yet he cannot inherit property if he is devoid of good qualities.тАЩ

Devala (Do., p. 489).тАФтАШOn the fatherтАЩs death, the eunuch, the leper, the insane, the idiot, the blind, the outcast, the outcastтАЩs child and the religious hypocrite, do not share in the inheritance; but food and clothing are given to all these, except the outcast. The sons of these however, if they are free from defects, should receive their share in the property.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрди рдкреАрдард╕рд░реНрдкрд┐рдкрдВрдЧреНрд╡рд╛рджрдпреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рддреН рее реп.реирежрез рее

B├╝hler

201 Eunuchs and outcasts, (persons) born blind or deaf, the insane, idiots and the dumb, as well as those deficient in any organ (of action or sensation), receive no share.

202 рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ ...{Loading}...

рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреБ рдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреНрдпрдВ
рджрд╛рддреБрдВ рд╢рдХреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рдордиреАрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛ ред
рдЧреНрд░рд╛рд╕рд╛рдЪреНрдЫрд╛рджрдирдореН рдЕрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрдВ
рдкрддрд┐рддреЛ рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрджрджрджреН рднрд╡реЗрддреН рее реп.реирежреи рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

But it is fair that the wise man shall give even to all these food and clothing to the best of his ability; if he does not give it at all, he becomes an outcast.тАФ(202)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрддреНрд╡реЗрди рджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рддрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрдВ рдпрд╛рд╡рдЬреНрдЬреАрд╡рдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рд╢рд░реАрд░рдзрд╛рд░рдгрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЧреНрд░рд╛рд╕рд╛рдЪреНрдЫрд╛рджрдирд╕реНрдп рднреГрддреНрдпрд╛рджреЗрд╕реН рддрджреБрдкрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рдирдГ рдкрд░рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рдХрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рд╡реЗрддрдирджрд╛рдирдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдореН ред рди рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдзрд╛рджреЗрдГ рдкрд░рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рдХрдореН рдЕрдиреНрддрд░реЗрдг рдЬреАрд╡рдирд╕рдВрднрд╡рдГ ред рдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рджрд╛рд░рдХрд░рдгрдВ рдорддрдВ рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╕рднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рднрд░рдгрдВ рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рд╢рдХреНрддреНрдпрд╛499 рдзрдирд╛рдиреБрд░реВрдкреЗрдг рднреЛрдЬрдирд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐ рджреЗрдпрдореН ред рдкрддрд┐рдд рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╡рд╛рджрдГ рее реп.реирежреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШAll theseтАЩтАФEunuchs and the rest.

тАШAt allтАЩтАФthroughout life.

тАШFood and clothingтАЩтАФbeing necessary for the keeping of the body; it is implied that he should provide enough to enable them to engage the necessary servants and other attendants; specially because in the case of the blind and the rest, living would be impossible without a servant. Those again for whom marriage is permitted, the provision made should include that for their wives also.

тАШTo the best of his abilityтАЩтАФthe food and clothing provided shall be in accordance with the manтАЩs own wealth.

тАШOutcastтАЩтАФthis is purely declamatory.тАФ(202)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШAtyantamтАЩтАФтАШFor lifeтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and Kull┼лka);тАФтАШat allтАЩ (taken with тАШadadatтАЩ, тАШnot givingтАЩ) [N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa].

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б, (2.140) to the effect that if the persons mentioned in the preceding verse are not properly maintained the persons responsible become тАШdegraded,тАЩтАФтАШatyantamтАЩ means тАШfor lifeтАЩ; it goes on to add that these persons are debarred from inheritance only if they are found to have the said disqualifications before the division of the patrimony,тАФnot after the partition has taken place; and that if the said disqualifications are subsequently removed by medication, they get their share in the property. It concludes by saying that the said disqualifications are applicable in the case of women also.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, (p. 487), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШSarveс╣г─Бm,тАЩ of the eunuch and the rest,тАФтАШatyantam,тАЩ for life;тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha, (p. 73), to the effect that those who are not entitled to inheritance are yet entitled to maintenance throughout life;тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava, (Vyavah─Бra, p. 366), which explains тАШatyantamтАЩ as тАШfor lifeтАЩтАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta, (p. 682), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШSarveс╣г─Бm,тАЩ those not entitled to inheritance,тАФтАШatyantam,тАЩ for life;тАФthe said disqualifications are effective bars only if found before partition, not if they are found after partition, or if they are cured by medication, or if the necessary expiatory rites are duly performed;тАФin Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л, (p. 349 and 575);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya, (Vyavah─Бra, 221b).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.201-202)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.201].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрд╛рддреН рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рд╕рд╛рдЪреНрдЫрд╛рджрдирджрд╛рдирдВ рдпрд╛рд╡рдЬреНрдЬреАрд╡рдореН рее реп.реирежреи рее

B├╝hler

202 But it is just that (a man) who knows (the law) should give even to all of them food and raiment without stint, according to his ability; he who gives it not will become all outcast.

203 рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рддрд╛ ...{Loading}...

рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рддрд╛ рддреБ рджрд╛рд░реИрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН
рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рдХрдердВ рдЪрди ред
рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЙрддреНрдкрдиреНрди-рддрдиреНрддреВрдирд╛рдореН
рдЕрдкрддреНрдпрдВ рджрд╛рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ рее реп.реирежрей рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If the eunuch and the rest should somehow happen to have longing for a wife, the child of such of them as have issue is entitled to inheritance.тАФ(203)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рддрд╛ рд╕рдВрдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧреЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ рд░рддрд┐рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрдореН ред рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╕рддреНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╣реЗрддреН ред рддрддреНрд░реНрдУрддреНрдкрдиреНрдирд╕рдВрддрд╛рдирд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрддреНрдпрдВ рдкреБрддреНрд░реЛ рджреБрд╣рд┐рддрд╛ рд╡рд╛ рджрд╛рдпрдВ рд░рд┐рдХреНрдерд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ ред рджреБрд╣рд┐рддреБрд░реН рдпрд╛рд╡рд╛рдиреН рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЧреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдГ ред

  • рд╡рд╛рддрд░реЗрддрд╛рд╕реН500 рддреБ рдпрдГ рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдп рднрд╡рддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ рдореИрдереБрдиреЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ ред рдХреБрддрдГ рдкреБрдирд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдп рддрдиреНрддреВрддреНрдкрддреНрддрд┐рдГ501 ред
  • рдЙрдХреНрддрдВ рдЪ502 “рдпрд╕реН рддрд▓реНрдкрдЬрдГ503 рдкреНрд░рдореАрддрд╕реНрдп рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╕реНрдп рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐рддрд╕реНрдп” (рдореНрдзреН реп.резремрен) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд░рд╛рдЧрдкреНрд░рдпреБрдХреНрддрддрд╛ рд╡рд╛рдиреЗрди504 рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЗрди рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╕реНрдп рджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рддрд╛ ред рдзрд░реНрдордкреНрд░рдпреБрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡реЗ рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрдирдзрд┐рдХреГрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдХрд░реНрдорд╕реБ рдХреБрддреЛ505 рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рдГ ред рдЙрдкрдиреЗрдпрддрд╛ рдЪ рдЬрд╛рддреНрдпрдиреНрдзрдкрдЩреНрдЧреВрдирд╛рдВ рд╡рд╛рддрд░реЗрддрд╕рдГ рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╕реНрдп506 рджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рддрд╛ ред рдЙрдиреНрдорддреНрддрд╛рджрдпрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреБрдкрдиреЗрдпрд╛рдГ, рдХреБрддрд╕реН рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рдГ ред

  • рдЖрджрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдЪреЛрдХреНрддрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЗ рдЪрд░рд┐рддрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рдпрджрд┐ рд╣рд┐ рдЖрджрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рдПрд╡ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпреЗрд░рдиреН рдкрддрд┐рддреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпреЗрдд ред рддрдЪреН рдЪ рд╕реНрдореГрддрд┐рд╡реЛрд░реЛрдзрд╛рдиреН рдиреЗрд╖реНрдЯрдореН ред

  • рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдХреГрддрд╛рдзреНрдпрдпрдирд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдХреГрддрд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЙрдиреНрдорддреНрддрд╛рджрд┐рд░реВрдкреЗ рд╕рдореБрдкрдЬрд╛рддреЗ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рдПрд╖ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдГ ред

  • рдирдиреБ рдЪ рдХреГрддрд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рддрд╛ рддреБ рджрд╛рд░реИрд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рдиреЛрдкрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред

  • рдиреИрддрджреН рдПрд╡рдореН, рдХреГрддрд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЬрд╛рдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд┐рддрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ рд╕рдВрднрд╡рд╛рддреН ред
