  • рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реИрд╕реН рддреБ рдзрд░реНрдореНрдпреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣реЗ рд╜рд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдВ рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрдореН ред рддрддрд╢реН рдЪ рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрдорд╛рд░реНрддреЗрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд╛рддреН рддрджрд░реНрдереЛ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣реЛ рд╜рд╕рддреНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд┐рддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдпреБрдХреНрдд рдПрд╡ ред рд╢реНрд░реМрддреЗрд╖реБ рддреБ рдЬрд╛рддрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдзрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╕реНрдп рдирд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рдГ ред рдпрд╕реНрдп рдЪ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдХрддреНрд╡рдВ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдВ рддрджреН рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рее реп.реирежрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШLongingтАЩтАФdesire to meet, with a view to sexual intercourse. When there is such longing, the man shall marry. And if there is issue from the marriage, the тАШchildтАЩтАФwhether a son or a daughter тАФтАШis entitled to inheritanceтАЩтАФto. a share in the property.

The share to which a daughter is entitled has already been explained.

тАЬIn the case of the eunuch of the тАШairyтАЩ (infructuous) тАШsemen,тАЩ the desire for sexual intercourse is there; but, how could he have any тАШissueтАЩ?тАЭ

It has already been declared above (167) thatтАФтАШif a son is born to the wife of a dead man, a eunuch, an invalid, etc.тАЩ (which shows that such men can have a тАШsoil-bornтАЩ son, and this is possible only if they have wives).

Or, the verse may be taken as indicating that in the case of such men, marriage could only he prompted by lust. If marriage wore prompted entirely by religious motives, how could there be any marriage for the men mentioned, being as they are not entitled to the performance of any religious rites? Then again, the person born blind, the lame, and the eunuch of the тАШairy semen,тАЩ have been declared to be fit for the Initiatory Ceremony; the lunatics and others of that kind however are not fit for that ceremony; how then can there be any marriage in the ease of those latter?

тАШAnd the restтАЩтАФstands for only those already mentioned above (i.e., the invalid, etc); but if the phrase тАШand the restтАЩ were taken as including all, then the тАШoutcastтАЩ also would become included, which, bring contrary to Law, would be undesirable.

Or, the present rule may be taken as referring to the case where the man becomes insane or otherwise disabled, after he has been тАШinitiatedтАЩ and тАШmarried.тАЩ

тАЬBut the clause тАШif they happen to have, longing for a wifeтАЩтАФcould not apply to the ease of those who are already married.тАЭ

Not so; тАШlonging for a wifeтАЩ (which has been explained as meaning desire for sexual intercourse) is quite possible in the case of married men.

The older writers have found in the present rule something that is usefully applicable to the case of also such marriages as are contracted for purely religious purpose?. So that for the eunuch also,тАФwho is entitled to the performance of such rites as are prescribed by Smс╣ЫtisтАФit is only right that there be marriage, even in the absence of sexual desire. As for the rites prescribed in ┼Ъrutis, it is only one who has already got a son that is entitled to the тАШlaying of fireтАЩ (which is a necessary accompaniment for those rites); so that the eunuch can never be entitled to them. And it has been already explained what really prompts the marriage in such cases.тАФ(203)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШKatha├▒canaтАЩ.тАФThis indicates that the eunuch and the rest are not worthy to marry (Kull┼лka).

тАШApatyamтАЩ.тАФThe Kс╣гetraja son (Kull┼лka, R─Бghav─Бnanda and Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 488), which explains тАШtantuтАЩ as child;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 750), to the effect that marriage is legal for the persons enumerated in 201; it remarks that in view of the epithet тАШj─БtiтАЩ, тАШbornтАЩ, in the term тАШj─БtyandhaтАЩ, the present verse cannot be taken as referring to cases where the disabilities appear after marriage; it comes to the conclusion that the disability to inheritance cannot thus be due to their not marrying and hence not being able to perform religious rites; it must be due to the mere authoritative assertion of the law.

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (Saс╣Гsk─Бra, p. 195) as indicating that the marriage of the said persons is sanctioned.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

[[See Texts under 201-202.]]

Gautama (28.44).тАФтАШThe male offspring of the idiot receives his fatherтАЩs share.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (15.34-38).тАФтАШOf the idiot and the rest the legitimate sons receive a share;тАФbut not the children of an outcast,тАФprovided they are born after the commission of the act that rendered the parents outcasts.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.141).тАФтАШOf the eunuch and the rest, the Body-born and the Kс╣гetraja sons, if they are free from defects, are entitled to shares; and their daughters should be maintained till they are made over to their husbands.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (Apar─Бka, p. 751).тАФтАШOne born of the outcast is an outcast, except the female child.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 419).тАФтАШThe sons of these are entitled to shares.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Do., p, 491).тАФтАШThe son of a wife married irregularly is entitled to inheritance when he belongs to the same caste as his father; so also is the son born of a regularly married wife, even though she may have been of a different caste; but the son of a woman married in the reverse order is not entitled to a share; to him his kinsmen should give food and clothing.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдЪрд╛рддреНрд░ рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рдиреН рди рдмрд╣реБрд╡реНрд░реАрд╣реМ рддрджреНрдЧреБрдгрд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдЪ рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╛рджреН рдЕрдкрд░реЗ рддреБ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдпреЗрди рдзрд░реНрдордкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рд░реНрдердВ рджрд╛рд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ рдпрддрд╕реН рддрджреН рдЕрднрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреН рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╕реНрдп рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ ред рдЕрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдирдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд╛рджреН рдЖрдзрд╛рдиреЗ ред рдЕрде рд╕реНрдорд╛рд░реНрддрдХрд░реНрдорд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реЛ рджрд╛рд░рд╕рдВрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ ред рддрддрдГ рдХреНрд▓реАрдмрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдВ рддрджреНрдЧреБрдгрд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдмрд╣реБрд╡реНрд░реАрд╣рд┐рдгрд╛ рее реп.реирежрей рее

B├╝hler

203 If the eunuch and the rest should somehow or other desire to (take) wives, the offspring of such among them as have children is worthy of a share.

204 рдпрддреН рдХрд┐рдореН ...{Loading}...

рдпрддреН рдХрд┐рдВ рдЪрд┐рддреН рдкрд┐рддрд░рд┐ рдкреНрд░реЗрддреЗ
рдзрдирдВ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдареЛ рд╜рдзрд┐рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐ ред
рднрд╛рдЧреЛ рдпрд╡реАрдпрд╕рд╛рдВ рддрддреНрд░
рдпрджрд┐ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдиреБрдкрд╛рд▓рд┐рдирдГ рее реп.реирежрек рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Whatever property the eldest brother acquires after the death of the father, a share of that shall belong to the younger brothers, if they are devoted to learning.тАФ(204)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдкрд┐рддреГрдХреНрд░рдорд╛рдЧрддрд╛рдиреН рдорд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рджреН рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛рдорд╛рддреНрдпрдкреБрд░реЛрд╣рд┐рддрд╛рджреЗрд░реН рд╡рд╛507 рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рд╛рджреН рд╡рд╛ рдХрдпрд╛рдЪрд┐рджреН рдпреБрдХреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐рдХреЛрддреНрдкрддреНрддрд┐рдВ рдЬрдирдпреЗрддреН рддрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рдзрд╛рд░рдгрдореН ред рдиреИрд╡ рдордиреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН “рдордпреИрддрджреНрдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛ рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЧреН рдЕрдиреБрдкрд╛рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрдВ508 рдордпреИрддрд▓реН рд▓рдмреНрдзрдВ рдордореИрд╡реИрддрддреН” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдиреБрдкрд╛рд▓рд┐рди рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рджреН рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдЬреАрд╡рд┐рдирд╛рдВ рд╢рд┐рд▓реНрдкрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реБрдХрдкреНрд░рднреГрддреАрдирд╛рдореН рдПрд╖ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рд╡реИрджреНрдпрдирдЯрдЧрд╛рдпрдирд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН рее реп.реирежрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If the eldest brother acquires more properly, either through some hereditary friend, or from the king or his ministers or his priests, or out of the farm, by the employment of special methods,тАФsuch property shall be common to all the brothers; and the eldest brother shall not entertain any such notion as thatтАФтАШthis property, which was not acquired by our father, has been acquired by me, through my own efforts, and hence it is mine only.тАЩ

тАШDevoted to learningтАЩ;тАФthis shows that the rule here laid down pertains to mechanics, artisans and others who subsist by learning; such as physicians, dancers, musicians and so forthтАФ(204)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This refers to a united familyтАФas rightly remarked by Kull┼лka.

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 507), which explains the meaning to be that, if after the death of the father, the eldest brother should happen to acquire some property by means of exceptional learning or such other means, in that property the acquirer shall have two shares, and each of the younger brothers one share, if they are devoted to study.

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.118), which notes the explanation of the verse as that тАШon the death of the father, or even during the fatherтАЩs life-time, if any brother, eldest, youngest or the middle one, happen to die, his shares are to go to the other brothers, and that, the implication is that wealth obtained from friends and so forth is partibleтАЩ,тАФand then goes on to criticise it as unwarranted, and concludes that the verse sets forth an exception to the general rule that property acquired by each brother separately is impartible.

It is quoted by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 192), which adds that the younger brothers are as much entitled to inherit the property of the eldest brother as that of the father,тАФbut with this difference that the fatherтАЩs property they inherit even when they are not learned, but to the brotherтАЩs property only those are entitled who are learned.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.204-208)
**

Gautama (28.30 31).тАФтАШWhat a learned co-parcener has acquired by his own efforts, he may, at his pleasure, withhold from his unlearned co-parceners. Unlearned co-parceners shall divide their acquisitions equally.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.116, 118-119).тАФтАШIf one is able to support himself and does not desire a share in the fatherтАЩs property, he shall be separated after having been given some little trifle; the law is that the division, equal or unequal, should be exactly as the father makes it.тАФIf among co-parceners some one has, by himself acquired some property, without detriment to the paternal property,тАФand if he has obtained friendly or nuptial gifts,тАФall such property shall not go to the co-parceners. If the ancestral property had been taken away by strangers, and subsequently one of the co-parceners recovers it, he shall not give it to the other co-parceners; similarly whatever one may have gained by learning.тАЩ

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (13.105.11.)

Viс╣гс╣Зu (18.42).тАФ(Same as Manu 208.)

с╣Ъс╣гya┼Ыс╣Ыс╣Еga (Apar─Бrka, p. 724).тАФIf one of the co-parceners recovers the landed property previously lost, the other co-parceners shall receive their share of it, after having given the fourth part of it to the recoverer.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Do.).тАФтАШIf some one, living upon food given by a stranger, has acquired learning, and by means of learning thus acquired, he acquires some property, that property is what is called the gain of learning; and such property is not divided; what one obtains from a pupil, or from officiating at sacrifices, or by answering doubtful questions, or by putting questions, or by expounding his own knowledge or by teachingтАФthis also is called the gain of learning; such property is not to be divided, etc., etc., etc. The learned shall not give to the unlearned any part of what he has gained by learning, but they shall give a share to those who are superior, or even equal to them in learning.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 507).тАФтАШThose who acquired learning in the family itself, either from their father or from their brothers,тАФif such persons acquire property by their learning or by bravery, that shall be dividedтАФsays Bс╣Ыhaspati.тАЩ

Vy─Бsa (Apar─Бrka, p. 725).тАФтАШWhat is acquired by learning or by bravery, or as a present in marriage,тАФall this shall not be sought after by co-parceners at the time of partition.тАЩ

Vy─Бsa (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 510).тАФтАШWhat was given to one by the grandfather or the father as a loving gift, as also what was given by the mother, should not be taken away from him.тАЩ

Do. (Do., p. 502).тАФтАШThe property that one has acquired by his own effort, without drawing upon the paternal property,тАФas also what he has gained by his learning,тАФall this he shall not give to his co-parceners.тАЩ

N─Бrada (Do.).тАФтАШThe learned shall not give to the unlearned any part of his gain of learning, unless he wishes to do so; provided that he had acquired those gains without employing any part of the paternal property for that purpose. The brother who supports the family of the brother while the latter is acquiring learning, should, even though he be unlearned, obtain some share of the property acquired by that learned brother. (Then it reproduces Manu 204.)тАЩ

Do. (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 501).тАФтАШThe property acquired by bravery, or inherited from oneтАЩs wife, or that acquired by learning,тАФthese are declared to be not liable to division; so also what may have been given by the father as a loving gift, or what the mother may have given through love, out of her own property.тАЩ

Do. (Do., p. 508).тАФтАШIn a joint family whatever conveyances or weapons one member acquires through bravery and such qualities, in that the brothers also shall have shares ; i.e., the acquirer shall have two shares and the rest, one share each.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Do., p. 503).тАФтАШThere shall be no division of the dwelling-house, of water-vessels, of ornaments, of such women and clothes as have been used, and of water-drains,тАФso says Praj─Бpati.тАЩ

Gautama (Do., p. 508).тАФтАШAmong brothers living in the joint family, what the learned acquires by learningтАФthe unlearned also shall divide equally.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (Do.).тАФтАШThose who may have specially worked to acquire the property shall receive two shares.тАЩ

Brhaс╣гpati (25.77-78).тАФтАШIf among re-united co-parceners, anyone should acquire property through learning, valour, or other independent effort of his own, a double share must be given to him; the rest shall take equal shares. Whatever has been given to one by the paternal grandfather, or the father, or the mother, all that shall not be taken from him; he shall keep likewise the property acquired by valour, and also the wealth of his wife.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард▓рдмреНрдзрд╕реНрдп рд╡реИрджреНрдпрд╛рдГ рд╕рдиреНрддреЛ рднрд╛рдЧрд┐рдиреЛ рдпрд╡реАрдпрд╛рдВрд╕рдГ, рди рддреБ рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдард▓рдмреНрдзрд╕реНрдп рдЬреНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдиреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рд▓реН [рд▓рднреНрдпрддреЗ] рее реп.реирежрек рее

B├╝hler

204 Whatever property the eldest (son) acquires (by his own exertion) after the father’s death, a share of that (shall belong) to his younger (brothers), provided they have made a due progress in learning.

205 рдЕрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдиреН рддреБ ...{Loading}...

рдЕрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рддреБ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ
рдИрд╣рд╛рддрд╢реН рдЪреЗрджреН рдзрдирдВ рднрд╡реЗрддреН ред
рд╕рдорд╕реН рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН
рдЕрдкрд┐рддреНрд░реНрдп рдЗрддрд┐ рдзрд╛рд░рдгрд╛ рее реп.реирежрел рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

But if all of them are unlearned, and the property is acquired by their labour,тАФthe division in that case shall be equal, the property being not ancestral. such is the settled rule.тАФ(205)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрд╡рд┐рдзреНрдпрд╛ рдХреГрд╖рд┐рд╡рд╛рдгрд┐рдЬреНрдпрд╛рд░рд╛рдЬреЛрдкрд╕реЗрд╡рд╛рджрд┐509 ред рддрддреНрд░ рдИрд╖рдиреНрдиреНрдпреВрдирд╛рдзрд┐рдХрднрд╛рд╡реЛ рди рдЧрдгрдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рдпрджрд┐ рдХреЗрдирдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдмрд╣реНрд╡рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрдВ рддрджрд╛рд╕реНрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рд╛рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрддрд╛510 ред рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реНрдп рддреБ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдВрд╢рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╛рд░реНрдердВ рд╡рдЪрдирдореН ред рдИрд╖рджрд╛рдзрд┐рдХреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╕рдорд╛рдВрд╢рдХрд▓реНрдкрдирд╛ ред рдЕрдкрд┐рддреНрд░реНрдп рдЗрддрд┐511 рд╣реЗрддреБрд╡рдЪрдирд╛рджреН рдЕрдирдкрддреНрдпрдзрдирд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдПрд╖ рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдГ рее реп.реирежрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШUnlearnedтАЩтАФi.e., devoted to agriculture, trade, service of the king and so forth.

In this case no intention is to be paid to the larger or smaller amount of property acquired by them. But even so, if some one of them happens to acquire a very large property, that of course is not to be divided among others.

This verse is in reality meant to be prohibitive of the тАШpreferential shareтАЩ of the eldest, brother.

If the difference in the properties acquired by them is small, the shares shall be equal.

тАШThe property being not ancestralтАЩ;тАФthe addition of this reason clearly indicates that this same rule applies also to the ease of the property of a childless person.тАФ(205)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШApitryeтАЩ.тАФThis is construed by Nandana as apitryaс╕е in the sense тАШsince the division has not been made by the fatherтАЩ;тАФthis rule refers to acquisitions by trade (Medh─Бtithi, Kull┼лka and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa), by agriculture (Medh─Бtithi, Kull┼лka and Nandana), or service of the king (Medh─Бtithi).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 507), which explains the meaning to be as follows:тАФIn a case where all the brothers are unlearned, if they acquire wealth, this wealth, which is not inherited from the father, is to be divided equally among them, and there is not to be any additional share to any one on the ground of any additional amount of work that he may have done.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 57), which has the following notes:тАФтАШ─кh─Б,тАЩ agriculture and the rest,тАФтАШapitrye,тАЩ which does not form part of the ancestral property.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 727);тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Calcutta, p. 137), which explains тАШ─лh─БтАЩ as тАШagriculture and the rest,тАЩтАФand тАШsamaс╕етАЩ as тАШnot unequal,тАЩ which precludes the special share of 20 per cent.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.204-208)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.204].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдИрд╣рд╛рддрдГ рдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рддрдГ рдХреГрд╖реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдд рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗ рдЪреЗрдЪреН рдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯрдиреНрддреЗ рд╕рдорд╕реН рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН, рди рддреБ рдЧреБрдгрд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рдГ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рджреН рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдХрд▓реНрдк рдЖрд╢реНрд░рдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ рее реп.реирежрел рее

B├╝hler

205 But if all of them, being unlearned, acquire property by their labour, the division of that shall be equal, (as it is) not property acquired by the father; that is a settled rule.

206 рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдзрдирдиреН рддреБ ...{Loading}...

рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдзрдирдВ рддреБ рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп
рддрддреН рддрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рдзрдирдВ рднрд╡реЗрддреН ред
рдореИрддреНрд░реНрдпрдореН рдФрджреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рд┐рдХрдВ рдЪреИрд╡
рдорд╛рдзреБрдкрд░реНрдХрд┐рдХрдореН рдПрд╡ рдЪ рее реп.реирежрем рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The gains of learning shall be the sole property of the man by whom they have been acquired; as also friendly presents, marriage.тАФpresents, and presents received in connection with the тАШhoneyтАФmixture.тАЩтАФ(206)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрдпрд╛512 рдЕрдзреНрдпрд╛рдкрдирд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╢рд┐рд▓реНрдкрдХреМрд╢рд▓реЗрди рд╡рд╛, рддрдерд╛ рдорд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рддреН, рдЕрд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрдореН ред рдФрджреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рд┐рдХрдВ рд╕рд╛рдиреНрддрд╛рдирд┐рдХрддрдпрд╛ рд▓рдмреНрдзрдВ рдЪреИрд╡ ред рдорд╛рдзреБрдкрд░реНрдХрд┐рдХрдореН рдЖрд░реНрддреНрд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдпреЗрди513 ред рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдзрдирдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рдпрд╛рдЬрдиреЗрди514 рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддреЗрдиреЛрдкрд╛рджреАрдпрдорд╛рдирддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рднреЗрджреЗрди рд╡реНрдпрдкрджрд┐рд╢реНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╢реНрд╡рд╢реБрд░рдЧреГрд╣рд▓рдмреНрдзрдореН рдФрджреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рд┐рдХрдореН рдЕрдкрд░реЗ, рдЙрджреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддреЗрди рдпрддрд╕реН рддрд▓реН515 рд▓рдмреНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.реирежрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШLearningтАЩтАФteaching, etc., as also proficiency in an art.

тАШFriendly presentsтАЩтАФPresents received from friends.

тАШMarriageтАФpresentsтАЩтАФin the shape of dowry and the like.

тАШIn connection with the honey-mixtureтАЩтАФi.e., in consideration of priestly functions. Though this also is a тАШgain of learning,тАЩ yet it has been mentioned separately, because it is obtained by means of the special kind of work of officiating at sacrifices.

тАШMarriageтАФpresentsтАЩтАФstand for all that is received from the father-in-lawтАЩs house. Others explain it to mean any presents that are made to one in connection with his marriage.тАФ(206)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАЬInstances in which land was given as Vidy─Бdhana occur in the inscriptions, see, e.g. Indian Antiquary XII, p. 195b, l. 6.тАЭтАФBuhler.

тАШAudv─БhikamтАЩтАФNandana is misrepresented by Buhler; he says nothing about тАШstr─лdhanaтАЩ here.тАФтАШWhat is received at oneтАЩs marriage from the brideтАЩs relativesтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa),тАФor тАШfrom anybodyтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, тАШothersтАЩ).

тАШM─БdhuparkikamтАЩ.тАФтАШFee given for a sacrificial per formanceтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШany present, e.g., a silver vase, received along with the Honey-mixtureтАЩ (Kull┼лka, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

This verse is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 499), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШVidy─БdhanaтАЩ and тАШaudv─БhikaтАЩ are going to be described later on,тАФтАШMaitraтАЩ is what isobtained from a friend,тАФтАШM─БdhuparkikamтАЩ is what is obtained as a mark of respect at the time of the offering of the Honey-mixture,тАФтАШtasyaiva bhavetтАЩ should be impartible;тАФin D─Бyakramasaс╣Еgraha (p. 35);тАФand in Vyavah─Бra-B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л (p. 476).

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 55);тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 724), to the effect that what one has acquired entirely by his learning he shall not give to his co-sharers;тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Calcutta, p. 135), which explains тАШmaitramтАЩ as тАШwhat has been obtained as a friendly presentтАЩ;тАФand тАШM─БdhuparkikamтАЩ as the arhaс╣З─Б offerings received at the time of Madhuparka-offering;тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, pp. 168 and 179).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.204-208)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.204].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдФрджреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рд┐рдХрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгреЗрди рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рд╢реНрд╡рд╢реБрд░рдЧреГрд╣рд╛рд▓реН рд▓рдмреНрдзрдВ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.реирежрем рее

B├╝hler

206 Property (acquired) by learning belongs solely to him to whom (it was given), likewise the gift of a friend, a present received on marriage or with the honey-mixture.

207 рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдгрд╛рдВ рдпрд╕реН ...{Loading}...

рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдгрд╛рдВ рдпрд╕реН рддреБ рдиреЗрд╣реЗрдд
рдзрдирдВ рд╢рдХреНрддрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдХрд░реНрдордгрд╛ ред
рд╕ рдирд┐рд░реНрднрд╛рдЬреНрдпрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдХрд╛рджреН рдЕрдВрд╢рд╛рддреН
рдХрд┐рдВ рдЪрд┐рджреН рджрддреНрддреНрд╡реЛрдкрдЬреАрд╡рдирдореН рее реп.реирежрен рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Among brothers, if any one, being quite competent through his own profession, does not desire the property, he shall be debarred from his share, after a little has been given to him by way of maintenance.тАФ(207)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпреЗ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░рдГ рд╕рд╣ рд╡рд╕рдиреНрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрдорд╛рдирдкрд┐рддреГрдзрдирд╛рд╢реН рдЪ рдХреГрд╖реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд░рдиреНрддрд┐ рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдпрджреНрдпреН рдПрдХреЛ рди рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд░реЗрддреН рддрд╕реНрдпреЗрдпрдВ рдирд┐рд░реНрднрд╛рдЬреНрдпрддрд╛ рдкрдареНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╕ рдирд┐рд░реНрднрд╛рдЬреНрдпрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдХрд╛ рдЕрдВрд╢рд╛рджреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рднрд╛рдЧрд╛рдиреН рдиреЗрддрд╡реНрдпреЛ рд╜рдкрд╕рд╛рд░рдпрд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рд╕реНрд╡рдХрд╛рджреН рдЕрдВрд╢рд╛рджреН рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрдВ рддрджреАрдпрд╛рджреН рдзрдирд╛рджреН рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗрдгреЛрддреНрдкрдиреНрдирдВ рддрддреН рддрд╕реНрдп рди рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН, рди рддреБ рдореВрд▓рд╕реНрдп516 рдкреИрддреГрдХрд╕реНрдп рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рди рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрдг рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдирд┐рд░реНрднрд╛рдЬреНрдпрдореН, рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛрдкрдЬреАрд╡рдирдВ рдХреНрд▓реЗрд╢рдлрд▓рдореН рдЖрддреНрдордиреЛ рдЧреГрд╣реАрддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдореИ рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред

  • рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдирд┐рд░реНрднрд╛рдЬреНрдпрдГ рдкреГрдердХреН рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдГ рд╕рд╣ рд╡рд╕реНрддреБрдВ рди рджреЗрдпрдореН517 ред рдХрджрд╛рдЪрд┐рджреН рдЙрддреНрддрд░рдХрд╛рд▓рд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рд╕рд╛рдзрд╛рд░рдгреНрдпреЗрди рдзрдиреЗрдирд╛рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рд╕рдорд╛рдВрд╢рддрд╛ ред рддрддреНрд░ рднрд╛рдЧрдХрд▓реНрдкрдирд╛ рдирд╛рд░рджреЗрди рджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рддрд╛ ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рдЪрдиреЗрдиреЛрджреНрдЧрддрд╕реНрдп рдирд┐рд░реНрдЧрддрд╕реНрдп518 рднреВрдпрд╛рдиреН рднрд╛рдЧреЛ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрддреЗ рд╜рдиреБрдХреНрддрд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрд╡рд▓реНрдк рдЗрддрд┐ рее реп.реирежрен рее
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

When several brothers are living together, and jointly manage their ancestral properly by cultivation and other means, if any one of them does not help in the management,тАФit is the debarring of such a brother that is declared here.

тАШHe shall be debarredтАЩтАФ set asideтАФтАШfrom his shareтАЩ in the nett profits of the estate. These profits shall not he given to the said brother; he however is not to be debarred from the main ancestral estate. But the profits also shall not be wholly taken away from him; a part of his share of the profits shall be taken by the others, in exchange for their own labour, and the remainder shall he given to him тАШby way of maintenance.тАЩ

Or тАШnirbh─Бjyaс╕етАЩ may mean тАШshall he separated,тАЩ тАШnot allowed to live jointly.тАЩ Because, it is just possible that after some time ho may acquire more property and become entitled to an equal share (?) In such a case what the allotment of shares shall be has been indicated by N─Бrada, whose declaration shows that the man is to have a larger share in the property named, and only a small share in what is not. so named. (?)тАФ(207)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 720), which explains тАШSvak─Бd aс╣Г┼Ы─БtтАЩ as тАШfrom the property acquired by the brothersтАЩ;тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva II (p. 171), in the sense that one, who, by reason of his own capacity (to earn) is not desirous of any share in the ancestral property, shall be given some such tiling as a seer of rice, and be separated from the family, as a safeguard against trouble arising from his sons and descendants;тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 110).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.204-208)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.204].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЕрджрджрддрд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреБ рдиреИрд╡ рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзреЛ рд╜рд╕реНрддрд┐ рее реп.реирежрен рее

B├╝hler

207 But if one of the brothers, being able (to maintain himself) by his own occupation, does not desire (a share of the family) property, he may be made separate (by the others) receiving a trifle out of his share to live upon.

208 рдЕрдиреБрдкрдШреНрдирдиреН рдкрд┐рддреГрджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЕрдиреБрдкрдШреНрдирдиреН рдкрд┐рддреГрджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдВ
рд╢реНрд░рдореЗрдг рдпрджреН рдЙрдкрд╛рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрдореН ред
рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдИрд╣рд┐рддрд▓рдмреНрдзрдВ рддрдиреН
рдирд╛рд╜рдХрд╛рдореЛ рджрд╛рддреБрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддрд┐ рее реп.реирежрео рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If one of them acquires something by his own effort, without interfering with the patrimony,тАФthat property, being acquired by his own labour, he need not give to others, unless he himself wishes it.тАФ(208)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рджрд╛рдирдореН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░рд┐рдХреНрддрд╕реНрдп рдХреГрд╖реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд▓рдмреНрдзрд╕реНрдпрд╛рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрддреЛрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред

  • рдирдиреБ рдЪрд╛рдпрдореН рдПрд╡ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЛ рди рд╡рдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдИрд╣рд┐рддреЗрди рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯрдпрд╛ рдпрд▓реН рд▓рдмреНрдзрдВ рддрдиреН рдирд╛рдХрд╛рдореЛ рджрд╛рддреБрдореН рдЕрд░реНрд╣рддреАрддрд┐ ред рдХрд┐рдВ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдзрдирд╛рджрд┐рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреЗрди ред

  • рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдордиреНрддреНрд░реЗ519 рд╡рд┐рд╡рд╛рд╣рд╛рджреМ рди рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдИрд╣реЛрдкрдкрддреНрддрд┐рд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рднреЗрджреЗрди рд╡реНрдпрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ рее реп.реирежрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been already declared that a man need not give what he acquires by his learning; this verse lays down that he need not give what he himself acquires by agriculture and other means.

тАЬThis verse alone would have been enough:^(тАШ)the man need not give, unless he wishes it, what he acquires by his own labourтАЩ; what was the need for the other verse making special mention of the тАШgains of learningтАЩ?

The answer to this is that there is no individual^(тАШ)effortтАЩ or тАШlabourтАЩ involved is the case of^(тАШ)friendly presents,тАЩ тАШmarriage presents,тАЩ and the like; hence it was necessary to have a distinct verse referring to these.тАФ(208)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШ─кhitalabdhamтАЩ.тАФтАШObtained by such labour as agriculture and the likeтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, Kull┼лka and Nandana);тАФor тАШby any occupation entailing troubleтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

тАШAnupaghnanтАЩ.тАФтАШWithout usingтАЩ (Nandana);тАФтАШwithout living upon (R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШwithout detriment toтАЩ (Kull┼лka).

Nandana says that the rule given in this verse may be reconciled with that given in 205 by assuming that the latter presupposes that all brothers exert themselves according to their ability.тАФBuhler.

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.118), which explains тАШ┼Ъrameс╣ЗaтАЩ as тАШby service, by fighting and so forthтАЩ;тАФand it reads the second line totally differently, the meaning of which is тАШthat shall not be given to the co-sharers, norwhat is gained by learningтАЩ.тАФThe B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds that тАШanupaghnanтАЩ is to be construed as тАШanupaghnat─Б.тАЩ

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 723), which explains тАШ┼ЫramaтАЩ as тАШsoldiering, agriculture and so forth;тАЩтАФand тАШ─лh─БтАЩ as тАШwork without much labourтАЩ;тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 501);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 377), which explains тАШ┼ЫramaтАЩ as тАШagriculture and so forthтАЩ and notes that тАШpitс╣ЫdravyamтАЩ here means тАШundivided propertyтАЩ;тАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 685), which explains тАШ┼Ыrameс╣ЗaтАЩ as тАШby service, soldiering and so forthтАЩ;тАФby J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 178);тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 220b), which explains тАШ┼Ыrameс╣ЗaтАЩ as тАШby service and other means.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.204-208)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.204].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рддреН рдХрд╛рдорд╕реНрдп рджрд╛рдирдореН рдЕрдиреБрдЬрд╛рдирд╛рддрд┐ рее реп.реирежрео рее

B├╝hler

208 What one (brother) may acquire by his labour without using the patrimony, that acquisition, (made solely) by his own effort, he shall not share unless by his own will (with his brothers).

209 рдкреИрддреГрдХрдиреН рддреБ ...{Loading}...

рдкреИрддреГрдХрдВ рддреБ рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдореН
рдЕрдирд╡рд╛рдкреНрддрдВ рдпрджреН рдЖрдкреНрдиреБрдпрд╛рддреН ред
рди рддрддреН рдкреБрддреНрд░реИрд░реН рднрдЬреЗрддреН рд╕рд╛рд░реНрдзрдореН
рдЕрдХрд╛рдордГ рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрдореН рее реп.реирежреп рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If the father recovers a lost ancestral property, he shall not, unless he so wishes, share it with his sons,тАФbeing, as it is his self-acquired property.тАФ(209)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрджреН рдЕрд░реНрдердпрдиреН рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛520 рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрдВ рддрджреН рдЖрдХрд╛рдореЛ рди рд╡рд┐рднрдЬрдиреАрдпреЛ рд╜рдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреИрд░реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкреБрддреНрд░реИрдГ ред

  • рдХрдГ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЬреАрд╡рддрд┐ рдкрд┐рддрд░рд┐ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдХрд╛рд▓рдГ ред

  • рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрджрд╛ рддрд╛рд╡рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреН рд╡рд┐рднрдЬрддреЗ, рддрджреЛрдХреНрддрдореН521 “рдорд╛рддреБрд░реН рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреЗ рд░рдЬрд╕рд┐” (рдиреНрд╕реНрдореН резрей.рей) рдЗрддрд┐ “рдЬреАрд╡рддрд┐ рд╡реЗрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐”522 (рдЧреНрдзреН реирео.реи) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрдерд╛ “рдкрд┐рддрд░реНрдпреН рдЕрдкрдЧрддрд╕реНрдкреГрд╣реЗ,“рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреЗ рд╡рд╛рдкрд┐ рд░рдордгреЗ”523 (рдиреНрд╕реНрдореН резрей.рей) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛ рддреБ рдпрджреИрд╡ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╛рдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛ рднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐, рддрджреИрд╡524 рддреЗ рдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣рдзрдирд╕реНрдпреЗрд╢рддреЗ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪреЛрдХреНрддрдореН-

  • рднреВрд░реН рдпрд╛ рдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣реЛрдкрд╛рддреНрддрд╛ рдирд┐рдмрдиреНрдзреЛ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдореН рдПрд╡ рд╡рд╛ ред

  • рддрддреНрд░ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕рджреГрд╢рдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпрдВ рдкрд┐рддреБрдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдп рдЪреЛрднрдпреЛрдГ рее (рдпреНрдзреН реи.резреирек)

  • рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЪ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпреЗ, рдпрд╛рд╡рджреН рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╛рд╕реН рддрд╛рд╡рддреН525 ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдерд╛ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рднрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗ526 рдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣рдзрдирднрд╛рдЬрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рддреНрд╡рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдХрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрд╕реНрдп ред рдмрдиреНрдзрдХреНрд░рдпрд╛рджрд┐рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╕реБ рдкрд┐рддреГрдзрдирдВ рдЬрд╛рддрдкреБрддреНрд░реЗрдг рди527 рдирд┐рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН ред рдпреЛрдЧрдХреБрдЯреБрдореНрднрднрд░рдгрд╛рджреМ рддреБ рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдпреЛрдЧреЛ рджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рддрдГ ред рдЖрдЪрд╛рд░реЗрдг рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЪрд╛рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдореН528 рдЕрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпреЗ “рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рдЪрд╛рдХрд╛рдореЗрди рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдиреН”529 (рдЧреНрдзреН резрел.резреп) рдЗрддрд┐ рдирд┐рдиреНрджрд╛рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рджреН рдмрд▓рд╛рджреН рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЬрдпрдиреНрддрдГ рдкрд╛рдкрд╛ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрдореАрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрдерд╛рд╕рддреНрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣реЗрдг530 рднрд╡рддрд┐ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпрдореН, рджреЛрд╖рд╕реН рддреБ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕реНрдп, рддреЗрдирд╛рдиреНрд╡рдпрд╛рдЧрддрдореН рдЗрддреАрджреГрд╢рдореН рдЕрд╢реБрджреНрдзрдореН рдПрд╡ ред рдЕрддрдГ рд╕рдВрднрд╡рддреНрдпреН рдЙрдкрд╛рдпрд╛рдиреНрддрд░реЗ рди рдкрд┐рддрд╛рд░реНрдердиреАрдпрдГ ред рдЕрдзрд░реНрдореЛ рд╣рд┐ рддрдерд╛ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред

  • рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдзрдирдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд╛рдиреН рдЧреБрдгрд╡рддрдГ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреН рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдПрд╡ ред рдЙрдХреНрддрдВ рдЪ “рд╡рдпрд╕рд┐ рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрдГ рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреН рд╡рд┐рднрдЬреЗрддреН ред рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардВ рд╢реНрд░реЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдВрд╢реЗрдиреЗрддрд░рд╛рдиреН рд╕рдореИрд░реН рдЕрдВрд╢реИрдГ” (рдЪреНреЬреНред рдиреНрд╕реНрдореН резрей.рек) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рди рдЪреИрддрддреН рдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣рдзрдирд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдореН ред рди рд╣рд┐ рддрддреНрд░ рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╕реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд╛рдВрд╢рджрд╛рдирд╛рдп рдкреНрд░рднрд╡рддрд┐, рддреБрд▓реНрдпрд╛рддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЙрднрдпреЛрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпрд╕реНрдп ред рдпрддреН рддреНрд╡реН рдЗрджрдореН- “рдиреНрдпреВрдирд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдзрд░реНрдореНрдпрдГ рдкрд┐рддреГрдХреГрддрдГ рд╕реНрдореГрддрдГ” (рдпреНрдзреН реи.резреиреж) рдЗрддрд┐, рддрддреН рдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣реЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕реНрд╡рд▓реНрдкрдпрд╛ рдорд╛рддреНрд░рдпреЗрдЪреНрдЫрдиреНрддрд┐ ред рдпрддреНрд░ рди рдкрд░рд┐рдкреВрд░реНрдгрдВ рднрд╛рдЧрджреНрд╡рдпрдВ рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЗ рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд╡рд╛рдж рдПрд╡ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рее реп.реирежреп рее
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If in addition to what he has inherited, the father recovers such ancestral property as had become lost, he shall not, unless he wishes it, share it with his sons, even after these latter have attained their majority.

тАЬBut what would he the occasion for partition among sons while the father is still alive?тАЭ

The answer to this is that such an occasion would arise when the father himself proceeds to make the division among his sons. This is what has been thus declared (by Gautama, 28.2)тАФтАШWhen their mother has ceased to menstruate, and when the father, though living, desires it, the sons shall divide the propertyтАЩ;тАФand again тАШWhen the father has ceased to have any longings, and when he has ceased to have intercourse with his wifeтАЩ (N─Бrada 13.3).

As a matter of fact, if there were no such restrictions, the son would become entitled to their grandfatherтАЩs property as soon as they were born; as it has been declared thatтАФтАШover the property movable or immovable, that has been left by the grandfather, both the father and the son have the same right.тАЩ Having this right, all the sons are entitled to equal shares in their grandfatherтАЩs property; since shares only follow the right.

The father, after the birth of his son, shall not invest his ancestral property in mortgages or purchases; but using it for the proper maintenance of his family however has been permitted. In actual practice, even though, under the circumstances, the sons have a right over the ancestral property, yet from the deprecatory assertionтАФтАШthe sone (son/one?) who divide the property against their fatherтАЩs wish are to be deprecatedтАЩтАФit follows that the sons who force the partition on their father incur a sin. Such as even though one may acquire property by receiving constant gifts, yet the act of acquiring such property is blameworthy. Similarly, even though the property (thus shared with the unwilling father) is the hereditary property of the sons, yet it is open to censure. For this reason, so long as they have any other means, the sons should never ask their father for a partition; as such asking would be immoral.

As a matter of fact, even in the case of the fatherтАЩs self-acquired property, he himself divides it among his sons as soon as they have attained their majority and he finds them duly qualified. It has also been declared thatтАФтАШwhen the father has reached old age, he shall himself divide the property among his sons, allotting to the eldest a preferential share, and equal shares to the rest,тАЩ (N─Бrada, 13.4). This, however, does not apply to the property that may have boon left by the grandfather; because, out of that, the father has no power to allot any тАШpreferential shareтАЩтАФthe right of both parties over it being equal.

As for the declarationтАФтАШunequal division has been declared to be legal, when made by the fatherтАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, 2.116),тАФthis has been taken to apply to a certain extent to the grandfatherтАЩs property also. In a case where there are no two full shares, there would be an exception, in the case of self-acquired property. (?)тАФ(209)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse has been taken by N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa to imply that ancestral property may be divided by the sons even during the life-time of the father, even though the latter may be unwilling.

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.121), which explains the meaning as follows:тАФтАЬIf a property was acquired by the grandfather, but taken away by some one else and not redeemed during his life-time, when such property has been redeemed by the father (the grandfatherтАЩs son), this is as good as тАШself-acquiredтАЩ by the father, and hence the father may not divide this with his sons, unless he is himself willing to do soтАЭ; and it takes this to imply that in the case of other kinds of ancestral property the sons may force partition on the father.тАФThe B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л adds that тАШsv─БrjitamтАЩ being explained as тАШas good as self-acquiredтАЩ, the explanation of it given by тАШMedh─БtithiтАФas тАШacquired by his own learning &c.тАЩтАФbecomes unacceptable.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 461), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШPaitс╣ЫkamтАЩ, ancestralтАФтАШanav─БpyamтАЩ (which is its reading for тАШanav─БptamтАЩ), which is hard to be recovered by the father; such property being тАШself-acquiredтАЩ by the father, he shall not divide it with his sons, except when he is quite willing.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 339), which has the same explanation as Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б;тАФin D─Бyatattva (p. 9);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra 35a);тАФin Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Calcutta, p. 126), to the effect that in regard to the property acquired by the father, independently of his ancestral property, sons have no voice, he himself being the sole disposer of it;тАФin V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 177b), which explains тАШsvayam─БrjitamтАЩ, (1) as тАШsvayamarjitamivaтАЩ, тАШit is as if it were his self-acquired propertyтАЩ; and (2) as giving the reason for the law laid down, тАШsince,тАЩ тАШit is his self-acquired propertyтАЩ;тАФand says that тАШak─Бmaс╕етАЩ implies that if the father so wishes, he may divide the property among his sons;тАФand by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 201).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (18.43).тАФтАШIf a man recovers a property which could not before be recovered by his father, he shall not, unless by his own free will, divide it with his sons; as it is an acquisition made by himself.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.119).тАФтАШIf one recovers an ancestral property that had been taken away by others, he shall not give it to his co-parceners; nor what he has acquired by his learning.тАЩ

с╣Ъс╣гya┼Ыс╣Ыс╣Еga (Apar─Бrka, p. 724).тАФтАШIf one of the co-parceners recovers landed property that had been lost, the other co-parceners also shall have shares in it, alter making over to him a fourth part as his special share.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava-Vyavah─Бra, p. 339).тАФтАШIf a property that belonged to the grandfather but became lost, is recovered by the father by his own effort, or what is acquired by him by his valour or learning,тАФover that property the fatherтАЩs right is absolute.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Do.).тАФтАШWhat had become lost,тАФif that is recovered by the father through his own effort,тАФall that the father cannot he forced to share with his sons.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣рдзрдирд╕реНрдпреЗрддрд░реЗ рд╜рдкреАрд╢рдд рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдирдпрд╛ рд╢рдЩреНрдХрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рдЕрдиреЗрди рдЪ рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗрди рд╕рддреНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддреМ рд╡рд┐рддреНрддрдВ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рд╡рд┐рднрдЬрдиреАрдпрдореН ред рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрд╕реНрдпреИрддрджреН рджрд░реНрд╢рдирдореН ред рдЬреАрд╡рдкрд┐рддреГрдХрд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрд╕реНрддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрддрджреН рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрддрд┐ рее реп.реирежреп рее

B├╝hler

209 But if a father recovers lost ancestral property, he shall not divide it, unless by his own will, with his sons, (for it is) self-acquired (property).

210 рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдГ рд╕рд╣ ...{Loading}...

рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдГ рд╕рд╣ рдЬреАрд╡рдиреНрддреЛ
рд╡рд┐рднрдЬреЗрд░рдиреН рдкреБрдирд░реН рдпрджрд┐ ред
рд╕рдорд╕реН рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдЬреН
рдЬреНрдпреИрд╖реНрдареНрдпрдВ рддрддреНрд░ рди рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.реирезреж рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If brothers, living together, after having divided once, happen to make a second partition, the division in that case shall be equal; in such cases there is no тАШprimogeniture.тАЩтАФ(210)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╕реНрдкрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдердГ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХрдГ ред рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдзрд░реНрдореЗ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрд╕реНрдпреЛрджреНрдзрд╛рд░рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╛рд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН, “рдЕрдкрд┐рддреНрд░реНрдп рдЗрддрд┐ рдзрд╛рд░рдгрд╛” (рдореНрдзреН реп.реирежрел) рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН ред рдкрд┐рддреНрд░реНрдпрд╕реНрдп рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдзрдирд╕реНрдпреЛрджреНрдзрд╛рд░рдГ ред рдЗрд╣ рддреБ рднреВрддрдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдЧрддреНрдпрд╛531 рдкрд┐рддреНрд░реНрдпрдВ рдирд╕реНрддреАрддреНрдпрд╛рд╢рдЩреНрдХрдпрд╛ рд╡рдЪрдирдореН рее реп.реирезреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The meaning of the verse is quite clear. It is meant to forbid the тАШpreferential shareтАЩ which would appear to be the standing rule in connection with all partition; specially in view of what has been said above (205) regarding тАШthe property being not acquired by the fatherтАЩ(205). It is only out of all kinds of property acquired by the father that there is to be a тАШpreferential share.тАЩ In the present case, however, the property might in a sense be regarded as тАШacquired by the father,тАЩ and hence, the possibility of the тАШpreferential share,тАЩтАФwhich, therefore, has had to be expressly denied.тАФ(210)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.139);тАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 678), to the effect that in the case noted there is no unequal division;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 748), which adds that this prohibits only that unequal division, which is in the form of additional shares for the eldest brother,тАФand not other kinds of unequal division; so that each brother obtains, on partition, that part of the property which was his when they entered into joint life.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 601), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШSaha j─лvantaс╕етАЩ, living after joining together,тАФтАШsamastatra vibh─Бgaс╕етАЩ, i.e., there is to be no additional share for the eldest, and so forth.

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 65), which mentions two opinionsтАФone, is that which has been set forth in Apar─Бrka, and another that there is to be absolutely equal division all round;тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Vyavah─Бra, p. 41b);тАФby J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, p. 342), which says that the equal partition is meant for brothers of the same caste as the father;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 210a), which explains the implication of the last clause to be that there is no unequal division due to seniority, but there is unequal division on other grounds.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (18.41).тАФтАШIf brothers, who after a previous division of the estate, live again together as parceners, should make a second partition, the shares must be equal in that case; and the eldest has no right to an additional share.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.120).тАФтАШWhen a property has been acquired by several brothers in common, it shall be shared equally by all.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (25.73).тАФтАШWhen brothers formerly divided are again living together through affection, and arrange a second partition, the right of primogeniture does not accrue in that case.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдпреЛ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардГ рдирд╛рд╕реМ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдВрд╢рдВ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдпрддреНрд░ рддреБ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардГ рд╕рд╣ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╛рдВрд╢реЗрди рд╕рдВрд╕реГрдЬреНрдпрддреЗ рддрддреНрд░ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рдЬреНрдпреНрд╖реНрдард╛рдВрд╢ рдЙрджреНрдзреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ рее реп.реирезреж рее

B├╝hler

210 If brothers, (once) divided and living (again) together (as coparceners), make a second partition, the division shall in that case be equal; in such a case there is no right of primogeniture.

211 рдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдЮреН рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардГ ...{Loading}...

рдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардГ рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдареЛ рд╡рд╛
рд╣реАрдпреЗрддрд╛рд╜рдВрд╢рдкреНрд░рджрд╛рдирддрдГ ред
рдореНрд░рд┐рдпреЗрддрд╛рд╜рдиреНрдпрддрд░реЛ рд╡рд╛рдкрд┐
рддрд╕реНрдп рднрд╛рдЧреЛ рди рд▓реБрдкреНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.реирезрез рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If the eldest or the youngest of the brothers should be deprived of his shares,тАФor if either of them dies,тАФhis share does not become lost.тАФ(211)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдгрд╛рдВ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдЯреНрдГрдЕрдГ рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдареЛ рд╡рд╛ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд╛ **рдЕрдВрд╢рдкреНрд░рджрд╛рдирд╛рджреН рдзреАрдпрддреЗ **ред рдЕрдВрд╢рдкреНрд░рджрд╛рдирдВ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдХрд╛рд▓рдГ ред рд╣реАрдпрддреЗ рдкрд╛рддрд┐рддреНрдпрд╛рджреНрдпрд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрд╛рд░реНрдердВ532 рдЪ рд╣реЗрддреБрдореН рдЖрд╕рд╛рджрдпреЗрддреН ред рдореНрд░рд┐рдпреЗрдд рд╡рд╛ ред рддрд╕реНрдп рднрд╛рдЧреЛ рди рд▓реБрдкреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрд╕реНрдпреЗрдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрддреНрддрд┐рдГ рее реп.реирезрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If among the brothers, тАШthe eldest or the youngestтАЩ brother тАШshould be deprived of his shareтАЩтАФby being found to be debarred on account of having become an out-east or stone such disability,тАФor тАШif he diesтАЩтАФтАШhis share does not become lostтАЩ;тАФhow this share shall be disposed of is explained in the following verse.тАФ(211)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШH─лyet─Бс╣Г┼Ыaprad─Бnataс╕е,тАЩтАФтАШOn account of having become an outcast and so forthтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi),тАФтАШby becoming an asceticтАЩ (Kull┼лka and Nandana),тАФтАШby having emigratedтАЩ (Nandana),тАФтАШby becoming an eunuch after the first partitionтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

тАШBh─Бgo na lupyate.тАЩтАФтАШHis share must not be divided by his co-parceners among themselvesтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa); тАШthe disposal of his share is prescribed in the next verseтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, R─Бghav─Бnanda).

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2. 139), which explains the meaning as follows:тАФтАШamong united brothers, if, at the time of partition, oneтАФeither the eldest or the middle or the youngestтАФshould happen to be disqualified from receiving his shareтАФeither by entering another stage of life or by committing such heinous sins as the killing of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, or if he happen to die,тАФthen his share is not lost, i. e., it has to be set aside, and not divided among his co-parcenersтАЩ.

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 678), which adds the same explanation as Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б; but as grounds of disqualification, it mentions тАШentering of another life-stage or becoming an outcastтАЩ; it adds that the next verse lays down what is to be done with the share thus set aside.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 749), which explains тАШamс╣гhaprad─БnaтАЩ as partition; and points out that тАШh─лyateтАЩ means disqualification by reason of тАШrenunciationтАЩ, тАШbecoming an outcastтАЩ and so forth; his share however is not lost, does not disappear,тАФit has to be determined and disposed of as laid down in the next verse.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 601), which explains as follows:тАФтАШHence among united brothers, if anyone should take to renunciation, or by some such cause become deprived of his share, or should happen to die, his share does not disappearтАЩ;тАФand in D─Бyatattva (p. 55).

It is quoted in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 67), which explains тАШh─лyateтАЩ as тАШby reason of entering another state or becoming an outcastтАФand in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 362), which adds the following explanation:тАФтАШAmong united brothers, who are sons of different mothers, if any one,тАФeither the eldest or the middle or the youngestтАФshould be deprived of his share at the time of partitionтАФby reason of his having gone to a foreign country and such other causesтАФhis share does not disappear; it has to be set aside, and not divided among the co-parceners.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.211-212)
**

Viс╣гс╣Зu (17.17).тАФтАШA re-united co-parcener shall take the share of his re-united co-parcener who has died without issue; and a uterine brother that of his uterine brother; and they shall give the shares of their deceased co-parceners and uterine brothers to the sons of the latter.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (2.138).тАФтАШBetween two re-united co-parceners, if one should die, the other shall take his share; hut in the event of a posthumous son being born to the former, the living co-parcener shall make over the dead fatherтАЩs share to that son. Similarly in the case of two re-united uterine brothers.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (25.74-76).тАФтАШWhen anyone brother should die, or anyhow renounce worldly interests, his share is not lost; it is allotted to his uterine brother. If there be a sister, she is entitled to a share of his property. This is the law regarding the property of one destitute of issue, and who has left no wife or father. When two co-parceners have again become united, they shall mutually inherit their property.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 603).тАФтАШAmong brothers, if anyone, without issue, should renounce the world, or die,тАФthe remaining brothers shall divide among themselves all his property, except the str─лdhana.тАЩ

K─Бty─Бyana (Do., p. 605).тАФтАШThe shares of re-united co-parceners shall be taken by re-united co-parceners; those of brothers living separately by those living separately;тАФin both cases, if there is no wife or other heir.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдкреНрд░реЛрд╖рд┐рддрд╕реНрдп рдореГрддрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд╛ рднрд╛рдЧрдореН рдЙрджреНрдзреГрддреНрдп рее реп.реирезрез рее

B├╝hler

211 If the eldest or the youngest (brother) is deprived of his share, or if either of them dies, his share is not lost (to his immediate heirs).

212 рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рднрдЬреЗрд░рдВрд╕реН ...{Loading}...

рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рднрдЬреЗрд░рдВрд╕реН рддрдВ
рд╕рдореЗрддреНрдп рд╕рд╣рд┐рддрд╛рдГ рд╕рдордореН ред
рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░реЛ рдпреЗ рдЪ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛
рднрд╛рдЧрд┐рдиреНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рд╕-рдирд╛рднрдпрдГ рее реп.реирезреи рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

His uterine brothers, coming together, shall divide it equally; as also the united brothers and consanguineous sisters.тАФ(212)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░реЛ рдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рд╕реН рддреЗ533 рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпреБрдГ ред рднрдЧрд┐рдиреНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рд╕рдирд╛рднрдпрдГ ред рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛ рдЕрдкреНрд░рддреНрддрд╛рд╕реН534 рддрд╛ рд╣рд┐ рд╕рдирд╛рднрд┐рд╡реНрдпрдкрджреЗрд╢реНрдпрд╛рдГ ред рдкреНрд░рддреНрддрд╛рдГ535 рдкреБрдирдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреЛрддреНрд░рднрд╛рд╡рдореН рдЕрдиреБрднрд╡рдиреНрддреАрддрд┐ рди рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдгрд╛рдВ рд╕рдирд╛рднрдпрдГ ред рдпреЗ рдЪ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЪрд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рднрдЧрд┐рдиреАрдВ рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрд┐рдиреЛрддрд┐ ред рди536 рддреНрд╡реН рдЗрдпрдореН рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ “рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпреБрд░реН рдпреЗ рдЪ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░рдГ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрдерд╛ рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╕рдЬреНрдпреЗрдд ред рд╕рдиреНрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛ рдЕрд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдГ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╢реН рдЪ рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛, рдпрддреНрд░ рд╕рдиреНрддрд┐ рддрддреНрд░реЛрднрдпреЛрд░реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧреЗрди рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧрдВ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпреБрдГ ред рди рдЪреЗрджрдВ рд╡рд┐рд░реБрдзреНрдпреЗрдд ред

  • рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╕реН рддреБ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯреА рдирд╛рдиреНрдпреЛрджрд░реНрдпреЛ рдзрдирдВ рд╣рд░реЗрддреН ред

  • рдЕрд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡рд╛рджрджреНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпреЛ рдирд╛рдирдпрдорд╛рддреГрдХрдГ537 рее ( рдпреНрдзреН реи.резрекрей)

рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдпрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рд╕рд╛рдкрддреНрдиреЛ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд╛ рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рддреНрд╡реЗ рди рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгрд╛рддрд┐, рдпрджрд╛ рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпреЛ рд╜рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рдордзреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдпреЗрди рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрдГ рд╕ рдПрд╡ рдирд╛рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╣реН, рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрддреНрд╡реЗ ред рддрджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН “рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдирд╕реН рддреБ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯреА рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╕реНрдп рддреБ рд╕реЛрджрд░рдГ” (рдпреНрдзреН реи.резрекреи) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпрджрд╛ рддреБ рд╕реЛрджрд░рд╛ рдиреИрд╡ рд╕рдиреНрддрд┐ рддрджрд╛ рдпреИрд░реН рдПрд╡ рд╕рд╛рдкрддреНрдиреИрдГ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╕реН рдд рдПрд╡ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпреБрд░реН рди рддреНрд╡реН рдЗрддрд░реЗ ред рдиреЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╕рд╣ рд╡рд╕рддрд╛рдВ рдорд╣рд╛рдирд┐рдХрдЯрдореН рдЖрд╡рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рд╛рдВрдирд┐рдзреНрдпрдВ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдпреЛрддреНрдердВ рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН538 рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдпрдд рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрд╣реБрдГ ред

  • рддреЗрди рд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддрд░рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдкреНрд░рдореАрддреЗ539 рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдп рдПрд╡ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдпрд╛рдиреН рдирд╛рд╕реНрдп рднрд╛рдЧрдГ рдкрд░рд┐рд▓реБрдкреНрдпрддреЗ ред
  • рди рдЪреИрддрдЪреН рдЪреЛрджрдиреАрдпрдореН “рдиреИрд╡рд╛рд╕реНрдп рддрджрд╛рдиреАрдВ рднрд╛рдЧ рдЙрддреНрдерд┐рддрдГ рдкрд░рд┐рд▓реЛрдкреЛ540 рд╡рд╛ рдЪрд┐рдиреНрддреНрдпрддреЗ” ред
  • рдпрдд рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН- “рд╕рдореБрддреНрдкрдиреНрдиреЗ рд╡рд╛рдЪреНрдпрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореА” рдЗрддрд┐ ред “рдЕрдиреАрд╢рд╛рд╕реН рддреЗ рд╣рд┐ рдЬреАрд╡рддреЛрдГ” (рдореНрдзреН реп.резрежрек) рдЗрддрд┐ рее реп.реирезреи рее

рддрддреНрд░ рдкреБрддреБрд░реН рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдВ рд╕рдордирдиреНрддрд░рдореН рдПрд╡ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдореНрдпрдВ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрддрд┐ ред[^релремрео]

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The property shall be taken by those тАШuterine brothersтАЩ who may have been тАШunitedтАЩ with him in property;тАФalso тАШconsanguineous sistersтАЩтАФi.e., those that are unmarried; it is only these that are called тАШconsanguineous, san─БbhiтАЩ (which is the term used in the text); those that are married go over to the тАШfamilyтАЩ of their husbands, and hence no longer remain тАШconsanguineousтАЩ to their brothers.

тАШAnd those brothers that are unitedтАЩ.тАФThe particle тАШca,тАЩ тАШand,тАЩ includes the тАШsistersтАЩ also.

This should not he taken to mean that the property shall be taken тАШby the uterine brothers, and also by such brothers as may be united.тАЩ As in that case those others also who are not uterine, but united, would be entitled to a share in the property. Among the uterine brothers, there may he some that are united and others that are not united; and where there are uterine brothers, united and not united, it is these that would divide the property among themselves.

Nor would this militate against the following textтАФтАШA brother born of another mother, even though united, shall not take the property of his half-brother; while a uterine brother, even though not united, shall take it, but not the brother born of a different mother.тАЩ (Y─Бj├▒avalkya, 2.139). The meaning of this is as follows:тАФтАШEven though united, the half-brother does not receive the property, if a uterine brother is there, even though not united; while among the uterine brothers, he alone shall receive it who is united, and not any other, notwithstanding his uterine character.тАЩ This is what has been declared in the textтАФтАШOf one who is united with another brother, this united brother shall receive the property; and the uterine brother that of another uterine brother.тАЩ (Yaj├▒─Бvalkya, 2.138). When, however, there are no uterine brothers at all, then the property shall be taken by such half-brothers as may be united, and none others. Among uterine brothers, even when separated, there is always some sort of тАШproximity,тАЩ due to their living near one another; so that the function of the uterine brother would, in a general way, be accomplished by even those that may have separated. Hence it is that, among such uterine brothers also as may have separated, if one dies, his property shall go to the other uterine brother, whose share in the property can never totally disappear.

It would not be right to argue against this thatтАФтАЬat the time in question the share of the separated brother can never come up at all, and hence there is nothing that would disappear or not disappear.тАЭ Since it has been declared that тАШthe son becomes the owner of the property as soon as he is bornтАЩ (so that the ownership of all brothers over the ancestral property is innate in them);тАФbut so long as the parents are alive, they have no mastery over itтАЩ (9.104); which shows that all the sons acquire ownership immediately after the fatherтАЩs death.тАФ(212)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

The share of a deceased or disqualified united brother goes first to the reunited brothers of the full blood and to such sisters of the full blood as are not married, next to such brothers of the full blood as had not been reunited, and finally to the reunited half-brothers (Medh─Бtithi and Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФfirst to the reunited full brothers, secondly to the reunited half brothers, then to the full sisters (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Nandana).

The said persons inherit the property only on the failure of sons, wives, daughters and parents (Kull┼лka, R─Бghav─Бnanda and N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

According to N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa what is here said refers to the property of one who dies before partition; but according to others to that of a reunited brother only.

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (2.139), which adds the following explanation:тАФтАШThis verse lays down the manner of disposing of the share set aside in accordance with the preceding verse; which is as follows:тАФThe uterine brothers shall divide it; i.e., it shall be divided equally among all his uterine brothers, those that were united with him as well as those not so united and those who may have gone to foreign lands; they should all come together and divide the said property equally among themselves;тАФalso those step-brothers who had been united with him, and his uterine sisters; all these should divide it equally among themselves.тАФThe B─Бlambhaс╣нс╣н─л has the following notes:тАФThat the un-united full brothers are meant by the first half is shown by the mention of the тАШunitedтАЩ in the second half;тАФthat the second half refers to half brothers is shown by the mention of тАШuterineтАЩ brothers in the first half;тАФthe half-brothers meant here must be understood to be of the same caste as the original owner.

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 679), which has the following notes:тАФThe mention of тАШuterineтАЩ in the first half and of тАШbrothers,тАЩ in the second half indicate that the latter stands for half-brothers;тАФthe mention of тАШunitedтАЩ in the second half, and the omission of it in connection with the тАШuterine brothersтАЩ indicate that the uterine brothers meant are those that were un-united. Thus then the meaning of this verse comes to be this:тАФThe property that has been set aside as the share of the disqualified person, shall be divided equally by his un-united uterine brothers, who should allтАФeven those who may have gone to other landsтАФcome together for the division; as also the step-brothers of the same caste as the original owner, who were united with him, and also his uterine sisters. All these, beginning from the un-united uterine brothers and ending with the uterine sisters, should divide the property equally among themselves. That the half-brothers meant here are those of the same caste as the owner is shown by the fact that for the brothers of different castes, different shares have been laid down.

It is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 749), which adds the following explanationтАФThe said share should be taken by those uterine brothers who were united with the original owner, and not those who were not united, even though they be his uterine brothers; if there be no united uterine brothers, then it shall be divided among all his uterine brothers equallyтАФwithout any inequality due to seniority and so forth;тАФif there be no uterine brothers, then it shall go to the uterine sisters;тАФand if there be no uterine sisters, then it shall go to the step-sisters and step-brothers.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 601), which adds the following notesтАФтАШSodary ─Бс╕етАЩ qualifies тАШbhr─Бtaraс╕етАЩ (of the second line); so that the meaning is that among his тАШbrothersтАЩ only those will divide the said property who fulfill the conditions of being both тАШuterineтАЩ and тАШunited and also the uterine sisters who are unmarried.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 362), which explains the meaning to be that the said property shall be taken by the un-united uterine brothers, and the united half-brothers, and the uterine sisters,тАФall coming together, even those who may have gone to other lands; it being divided among these equally;тАФand in Viv─Бdacint─Бmaс╣Зi (Calcutta, p. 158), as countenancing the view that brothers, even though uterine, have no share, if they did not live jointly.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 9.211-212)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 9.211].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЕрд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдгрд╛рдВ рд╕реЛрдж]рд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдВрд╕реН рддрдВ рд╡рд┐рднрдЬреЗрд░рдиреН рди рд╕рд╛рдкрддреНрдирд╛рдГ, рд╕рддрд┐ рддреБ рд╕рдВрд╕рд░реНрдЧреЗ рдпреЗ рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╕реН рддреЗ рд╡рд┐рднрдЬреЗрд░рдиреН, рди рд╕реЛрджрд░реНрдпрд╛ рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдГ рее реп.реирезреи рее

B├╝hler

212 His uterine brothers, having assembled together, shall equally divide it, and those brothers who were reunited (with him) and the uterine sisters.

213 рдпреЛ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдареЛ ...{Loading}...

рдпреЛ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдареЛ рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдХреБрд░реНрд╡реАрдд
рд▓реЛрднрд╛рджреН рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдиреН рдпрд╡реАрдпрд╕рдГ ред
рд╕реЛ рд╜рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЕрднрд╛рдЧрд╢реН рдЪ
рдирд┐рдпрдиреНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рд░рд╛рдЬрднрд┐рдГ рее реп.реирезрей рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If an eldest brother, through avarice, defrauds the younger ones, he shall lose his тАШseniorityтАЩ and his share, and shall also be punished by the king.тАФ(213)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдХрд╛рд░реЛ рд░рд╛рдЬрдкреВрдЬрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрд╡рдЬреНрдЮрд╛, рдкрд░реЗ рдзрдиреЗрди рд╡рдЮреНрдЪрдирдореН541 ред рдЕрдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдареЛ рдмрдиреНрдзреБрд╡рддреН рдкреВрдЬреНрдп рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН ред рди рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрдг рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдард╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ542 ред рдЕрднрд╛рдЧрдХрддреНрд╡рдВ рдЪ рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдЯреНрдГрдЖрдВрд╢рд╛рдирд░реНрд╣рддреНрд╡рдореН543 ред рдирд┐рдпрдиреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ544 рдЕрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛрдкрджреЗрд╢рд╛рддреН, рд╡рд╛рдЧреНрджрдгреНрдбрдзрд┐рдЧреНрджрдгреНрдбрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдореН, рдзрдирджрдгреНрдбрдВ545 рдЪрд╛рд░реНрдерд╛рдиреБрд░реВрдкреЗ рд╜рдкрд░рд╛рдзреЗ рее реп.реирезрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШDefraudingтАЩ consists in cheating them out of their share in the property, as also that of the honours etc., that may be conferred by the king.

тАШLoses his seniorityтАЩ;тАФi.e., is to be treated as an ordinary kinsmen (as laid down in 110). This does not preclude all that is due to him as the eldest brother.

He loses also his тАШshareтАЩтАФi.e., the тАШpreferential shareтАЩ due to him as the eldest brother.

тАШPunished.тАЩтАФAs the special form of punishment to be inflicted has not been specified, he shall be reprimanded or censured or fined, in accordance with the exact nature of his offence.тАФ(213)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣г─Бra (2. 126) as having been understood by some people to mean that тАШmisappropriationтАЩ of the entire property is wrong only for the eldest brother, and not for the younger brothers. This view, it says, is wrong; the verse clearly implying that, just as it is wrong for the eldest brother who is in the place of father for the younger brother to misappropriate the property, so it is also for the younger brothers, who are as тАШsonsтАЩ to the eldest brother.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Vyavah─Бra, p. 383), which takes it to mean that when even the eldest brother, who is independent, is held to commit a wrong if he does the mis-appropriation, it is all the more culpable in the case of the younger brothers, who are not independent.

It is quoted in Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 478), which explains тАШvinikurv─лtaтАЩ as тАШshould defraud,тАЩ and тАШajyeс╣гс╣нhaс╕етАЩ as тАШnot to be respected as the eldest brotherтАЩ;тАФand in Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 58), which remarks that the term тАШjyeс╣гс╣нhaс╕етАЩ stands for all the heirs to a property, the meaning being that when the eldest also is held culpable, how much more so the younger brothers?

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (13.105.7).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдХрд░рдгрдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреЗрди рдпрд╡реАрдпрд╕рд╛рдВ рдиреНрдпрдХреНрдХрд░рдгрдВ рдзрдиреЛрдкрдпреЛрдЧрд╢реН рдЪ рддрд╛рдиреН рдЕрддрд┐рд╕рдВрдзрд╛рдп ред рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдареЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕реБрддрд░рд╛рдВрдирд┐рдпрдиреНрддрд╡реНрдп рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ рее реп.реирезрей рее

B├╝hler

213 An eldest brother who through avarice may defraud the younger ones, shall no (longer hold the position of) the eldest, shall not receive an (eldest son’s additional) share, and shall be punished by the king.

214 рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рдПрд╡ ...{Loading}...

рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдХрд░реНрдорд╕реНрдерд╛
рдирд╛рд╜рд░реНрд╣рдиреНрддрд┐ рднреНрд░рд╛рддрд░реЛ рдзрдирдореН ред
рди рдЪрд╛рд╜рджрддреНрддреНрд╡рд╛ рдХрдирд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрднреНрдпреЛ
рдЬреНрдпреЗрд╖реНрдардГ рдХреБрд░реНрд╡реАрдд рдпреМрддрдХрдореН рее реп.реирезрек рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

All brothers addicted to evil deeds are unworthy of having property; and the elder brother shall not have a separate hoard without making a contribution to his younger brothers.тАФ(214)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╡рд┐рдХрд░реНрдорд╕реНрдерд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖рд┐рджреНрдзрд╛рдЪрд░рдгрд╛рдГ рдЕрдирд╛рджреЗрд╢рдХреГрддрд╛ рдЕрдХреГрддрджрд╛рд░рд╛ рджрд╛рд╕реАрднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдГ ред рдкрддрд┐рддрд╕реНрдп рдкреГрдердХреН рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╛рддреН, рдЕрднреНрдпрд╛рд╕реЗ рд╡рд░реНрддрдорд╛рдирд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдПрд╖рд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рди рдЪрд╛рджрддреНрд╡рд╛ рдЙрдкрдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН рдПрд╖рд╛рдВ рдзрдирд╛рджрд╛рдиреАрдпрдореН рдЕрдЩреНрдЧреАрдХреГрддреНрдп рдпрджрд┐ рдпреМрддрдХрдВ рдпрд╛рдВ рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдВ рдирдпреЗрддреН546 ред рдХреБрдЯреБрдореНрдмрд╛рд░реНрдереЗ рдЪрд╛рдиреБрддрд┐рд╖реНрдардорд╛рдирд╛рдирд╛рдВ рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдгрд╛рдВ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзреНрдпреБрдкрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдВ рд╕реНрдерд╛рдкрдпреЗрддреН “рдпрджрд╛547 рддреЗ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ рдХреБрддрд╕реН рддрджреН рдзрдирдореН548 рдЗрддрд┐ рддрджрд╛ рдореВрд▓рдВ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпрд┐рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдорд┐” рдЗрддрд┐ рддрд╛рджреГрд╢рдВ549 рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рд╕рд╣рд┐рддрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рджрд╛рдкрдпреЗрддреН ред рдпрджрд┐ рддреБ рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдПрд╡ рдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдгрд╛рдВ рджрд░реНрд╢рдпреЗрддреН “рдЗрджрдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрдВ рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рддрджреН рдпрдерд╛рдВрд╢рдВ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдгреАрдд, рдЕрд╣рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕реНрд╡рддрд╕реН рддрддреН рдкреГрдердХреНрдХреГрддреНрдп рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд┐рдВ рдиреЗрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдорд┐” рдЗрддрд┐, рддрджрд╛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рднрд╛рдЧрдГ, рддрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рддрджреН рдпреМрддрдХрдореН рее реп.реирезрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШAddicted to evil deedsтАЩтАФ doing such acts as are forbidden.

When all the brothers are working for the benefit of the whole family, if the eldest brother surreptitiously takes possession of and invests the property, under the impression that he would show them the тАШprincipalтАЩ if they ask for it,тАФthen he should he made to hand over to all the brothers, the principal along with the interest that may have accrued to it. But if at the very outset, he lays the whole property before his brothers and says openlyтАФтАШHere is the property, each of you take your share, I shall separate mine and earn interest on it,тАЩтАФthen they are not entitled to the interest thus earnad; which belongs exclusively to the eldest brother, and forms his тАШspecial hoard.тАЩтАФ(214)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШVikarmasth─Бс╕е.тАЩтАФтАШAddicted to gambling, drinking and similar vicesтАЩ (Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШwho following despicable modes of living, such as cattle-breeding, serving ┼Ы┼лdras and the likeтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).

тАШYautakam.тАЩтАФтАШSeparate hoardingтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi and Kull┼лka;тАФтАШshall not, out of the common property, give a dowry to his daughterтАЩ (Nandana).

The first half of this verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 720 and p. 749);тАФin Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara (p. 480), where тАШVikarmasth─Бс╕етАЩ is explained as тАШaddicted to gambling and so forthтАЩтАФand it is noted that others have explained it as meaning тАШbehaving in a manner calculated to ruin the familyтАЩ;тАФin Vyavah─Бramay┼лkha (p. 73), in the sense that so long as well-behaved sons are present, the property cannot go to the ill-behaved ones;тАФand in V─лramitrodaya (Vyavah─Бra 222a).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

[[See texts under 201-202.]]

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (13.105.10).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

Gautama (28.40).тАФтАШAccording to some, the son of a wife of equal caste even does not inherit, if he be living unrighteously.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (2-3.38-39).тАФтАШThose immersed in vice, those who neglect their duties and occupations are only entitled to maintenance.тАЩ

─Аpastamba (2.14.15).тАФтАШHim who spends money unrighteously, the father shall disinherit, oven though he be the eldest son.тАЩ

┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita (Viv─Бdaratn─Бkara, p. 486).тАФтАШThose excommunicated become deprived of inheritance and funeral offerings and libations.тАЩ

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдпреЗ рдХреБрдЯреБрдореНрдмрдХрд╛рд░реНрдп рд╜рд╡реНрдпреБрддреНрдкрдиреНрдирд╛рд╕реН рддреЗ рджреНрдпреВрддрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╡рд┐рдХрд░реНрдорд╕реНрдерд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рджреН рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдпрддреЗ ред рдкрддрд┐рддрд╛рдирд╛[рдореН рдЕ]рдирдВрд╢рд╛рд░реНрд╣рддреЛрдХреНрддрд╛ рее реп.реирезрек рее

B├╝hler

214 All brothers who habitually commit forbidden acts, are unworthy of (a share of) the property, and the eldest shall not make (anything his) separate property without giving (an equivalent) to his younger brothers.

215 рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН ...{Loading}...

рднреНрд░рд╛рддреДрдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ
рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЙрддреНрдерд╛рдирдВ рднрд╡реЗрддреН рд╕рд╣ ред
рди рдкреБрддреНрд░рднрд╛рдЧрдВ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдордВ
рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рджрджреНрдпрд╛рддреН рдХрдердВ рдЪрди рее реп.реирезрел рее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Among undivided brothers, if there is a joint concern,тАФthe father shall, on no account, make an unequal division among his sons.тАФ(215)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпрджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН “рдиреНрдпреВрдирд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдзрд░реНрдореНрдпрдГ рдкрд┐рддреГрдХреГрддрдГ рд╕реНрдореГрддрдГ” (рдпреНрдзреН реи.резреиреж) рдЗрддрд┐, рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН550 рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЗ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рд╕рд╣реЛрддреНрдерд╛рдирдореН, рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рдПрд╡ рдзрдирдореН рдЕрд░реНрдЬрдпрдиреНрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН рдХреГрд╖реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣реЗрдг рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН рд╕реЗрд╡рдпрд╛ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рджреН рдпрдерд╛рд╣реГрддрдВ рдкрд░рд┐рд░рдХреНрд╖рддрд┐ рдпрдереЛрдкрдпреЛрдЧрдореН рдЕрд╕рдВрдирд┐рд╣рд┐рддреЗрд╖реБ рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдпреБрдХреНрддреЗ ред рддрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдореН рдПрдХреАрдХреГрддреНрдп рд╕рдордВ рд╡рд┐рднрдЬрдиреАрдпрдореН ред рди рд╕реНрдиреЗрд╣рд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рдХрд╕реНрдореИрдЪрд┐рддреН рдкрд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рдзрд┐рдХрдВ рджреЗрдпрдореН рее реп.реирезрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

It has been said (y─Бj├▒avalkya, 2.116) thatтАФтАШan unequal division has been declared to be legal, if made by the fatherтАЩ;тАФit is this that is denied here.

тАШJoint concern,тАЩтАФi.e., when all of them together earn somethingтАФone by agriculture, another by receiving gifts, another by service, while another takes care of what is earned by others, and invests them and uses them to the advantage of all;тАФall this shall be brought together and divided equally; and no excessive share shall be given to any one by the father, through his love for him.тАФ(215)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

тАШSaha utth─Бnam.тАЩтАФтАШJoint acquisitionтАФone earning by agriculture, another by receiving gifts, another by service, another taking care of what others bring in and so forthтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi);тАФтАШjoint concern,тАФsuch as joint trading and so forthтАЩ (N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa).тАФExplained by J─лm┼лtav─Бhana (D─Бyabh─Бga, 2.86) as тАШeffort i.e., desire to have a divisionтАЩ (Hopkins).
